When I got there, I had high expectations because of the reviews. I grew up on Chinese food so my expectations are probably much higher than most. The wait was just a little over an hours which I did not mind waiting for good food. You must go inside to grab a ticket from one of the staff to be put on the list and receive a wait time! We had to share a table with other guests, which was a little uncomfortable but I completely understand due to their high volume. The staff weren't very attentive. I had to ask for water several times b efore he got it for me. I recommend getting what they are known for which is the soup dumplings. They were juicy and delicious but you much eat them right away! The stir fry noodle were good as well, had a chard flavor from the wok. But the beef noodle soup was terrible! There was literally no flavor. It just tasted like hot water tbh. Idk if that's a mistake or that's how they normally make it but I would never order that again. The sweet and sour fried fish was good. But the strong ketchup taste ruined it. I expected more from this place. Also, there is automatically 15% gratuity added on to the bill.

Dine in this restaurant after COVID-19 reopen. The place seems ok and clean, my friend and I order a fish, and after 20 mins the waiter told us we didn't actually ordered that because he thought we're just asking for recommendations when we're ordering. Then it took them another 30 mins to cook that. And after we tried that fish, I have to say I am furious. The fish tastes like mud and must have been frozen for a long time. I understand the difficulties that restaurants were facing during COVID but they shouldn't do this. Very disappointed. By the way, the waiter just took 10 dollars off our bill while we barely eat the 20 dollar fish.

LOVE LOVE LOVE Joe's! Hands down the best soup dumplings you'll ever have! So happy I was able to go last night. Beware, there is normally a wait for this place, because it is so popular, especially on the weekends. We arrived around 7pm, for 2 people and only had to wait 3 0 minutes, was not a bad wait at all. Also something to note, most of the tables are communal style, but it kinda adds to the experience of dining here. We also had the chicken and broccoli and the veggie fried rice. Both delicious. But if you want soup dumplings, you must go here, no better spot in NYC for them.

We came for their highly recommended and famous soup dumplings! They were delicious we ordered the pork meat ones. This was our first time having soup dumplings. The order comes with 8 which was more than enough to fill my boyfriend and I up. We also ordered their scallion pancake which was really crispy. I was expecting them to have more scallions as the flavor to me seemed a little washed out. We also ordered a Shanghai fried rice for the both of us but after the scallion pancake and soup dumplings we shared it was just way too much food and ended up taking the rice to go. Joe's Shanghai is a very sought after place with limited table seating. We ended up sharing a 7 person table with 2 other parties which was a little awkward. I wish we had been able to get our own table. And the seating arrangement also made it even more cramped to fit everyone's food on the table with enough room to move around. I would come back but only for the soup duI'd definitely recommend for anyone trying soup dumplings for the first time to give this place a try just know you'll more than likely end up sharing a table with multiple different parties.

04/29/19. Recommended by hotel. A brisk 15 minute walk into Chinatown. Passed 20 Chinese restaurants on the way. Guess what? The food was worth it! Atmosphere was a bit funky. 1970's large round tables and we basically ate family style. 4 in our party and a total of 8 at each table. No credit cards taken here so have cash. Maybe debit. Not sure. Pork and shrimp dim sum were well made and full of contents. The braised duck was moist, super flavorful and the leaks were a nice side as the duck sauce was a bit on the heavy side. All in all, it was fun and tasted good. Never thought I'd go to New York to "Eat at Joe's" Chinese.

I haven't been to this location in years but friends were in town from Seattle and we decided to go for soup dumplings. They were very delicious and bigger than a lot of other soup dumplings I've had lately. They did seem to stick to the cabbage a bit and I lost some luscious broth! Â Oh, let me say that the service was very fast. Not surprising since they have to get you in and out. With that said, we never felt rushed. We ordered the dumplings, Peking Style Spicy Noodles, sautÃ©ed string beans and s&p spicy Shrimp (shell on). All were delicious. My only comment was that the spicy noodles were too salty and too saucy. They could add more noodles, less sauce and this dish would have been so much better. Â Also got the chicken with vermicelli which was surprisingly very good since I usually don't think I will like cold appetizers. Â And was so pleased that it was in what tasted like a peanut sauce. Â Once I have a good peanut sauce I kinda get hooked.

I heard a lot of good things about Joe's Shanghai, especially their famous Xiao Long Bao! Their authentic soup dumpling is the reasonable why we wanted to stop by and check it out. When we first arrived, we were expecting a long waiting line but we didn't see any. I thought they are closed today but turned out we were just lucky! We came in and sat down right the way around 1145. Highly recommend to come early for lunch on a weekday!!! With just two of us, we ordered the best dishes on their menu, Crab Flavored Shanghai Xiao Long Bao and Shanghai stir fried thick noodle. Omg! I love their food! So authentic that literally brought me back to the time I was visiting Shanghai!!! The stir fried thick noodles was perfectly cooked, flavorful, and just the way it should be. The crab flavored Xiao long Bao came as it finished in the bamboo steamed basket. So fresh and simply awesome. The size is bigger than I expected. The flavor and quality were also better than I expected. The crab flavored filling and soup in the Xiao long Bao were the one of the best that I've ever had! I was totally shocked by the flavor of Xiao long Bao! I highly recommend this place and I will come back every time I am in New York!

I was really disappointed to walk in and find out that it wasn't a restaurant that has a variety of dim sum. Pictures of dim sum are the first items shown on the website, so I took an Uber there ready and excited to eat that. I got there, sat down, and found out there are only two types of dim sum, and they are only appetizers. They were ok enough but I wish I had looked at the menu before taking and Uber there.

Love the soup dumplings here. There is always a wait but it is worth it.

While in Chinatown I used Yelp to help locate a good restaurant. Â This place is CASH ONLY. Â Hot tea is served in a normal drinking glass (which was weird) but everything we ordered was fantastic. Â Portions are large enough for sharing if you don't want leftovers. Â Two people in my group said it was the best food we ate the whole time we were in NYC.

Meh...that's my vote. It's def not 4-5 star worthy and more akin to a tourist trap. Famous soup dumplings had good soup, but meat wasn't the freshest I've ever had. The skin was more doughy than should be and not the lighter consistency it should be. Hot and sour soup came out cold, had to be reheated via microwave. So overall, very average and you might as well go to any other Shanghainese place in Chinatown without the long wait. My only consolation is that we didn't wait for seats cause we came midweek.

We stopped at Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown for a quick dinner before heading home after an exhausting day in downtown NYC! As usual the place is packed but we were able to grab a table on the second floor. Â The service is diligent and quick and the food is always fresh and delicious! Â After having spent the entire day enjoying different small plates in various places in Little Italy where we joined the celebration of the Saint Genaro Feast, we kept our dinner selection light. Â My husband and I shared the combination Pork and Crab Soup Steamed Dumplings and Crispy Shrimp dish as the EntrÃ©e served with white rice. Â Steamed soup dumpling is the signature dish at this restaurant and I concur! Â They are light pillows of dough with a tasty meaty filling enveloped in a liquid sauce which characterizes the dish.. Â Delightful! Â I can make a meal just of these!!! Â I do prefer the pork dumplings to the crab ones, though... but they are both great!!! Â The shrimp dish turned out to be in a spicy semi-sweet garlicky sauce which went absolutely well with the white rice. Â This restaurant never disappoints! Â When you are in the area and in the mood for great steamed soup dumplings do not hesitate to give Joe's Shanghai a try!

Pork dumpling are amazing ! The crab and pork dumplings are also good . The Peking pork noodle I is where it's at ! Def something you should order with your Â meal ! We also got the beef and jalapeÃ±o ... not a fan

I was excited for my first visit to Joe's Shanghai to try their soup dumplings and they did not disappoint! Â They were absolutely amazing! Â So much flavor and I'm already looking forward to my next trip to NYC to have them again. We also had the fried dumplings and scallion pancakes. Both were the best we've ever had. Make this a stop and you won't regret it.

We had a good time there yesterday food was very good service was excellent. The dumplings are awesome and the chicken broccoli I strongly recommend
Bring cash! Fill your belly with lots of delicious food. Fun time all around. Great spot to share with friends.

If you're ever in china town NY you mist stop by Joes for some soup dumplings. Try to get there when the restaurant opens to avoid the wait. Its small but most places in NY are and the turn around time is quick. Sometimes you might be sitting with another party at your table. My favorite is the crab dumplings but the pork is good too. Both are packed with flavor. It might take you a few times to master not spilling all the broth on your plate.
Always a solid experience. Â Great menu and of course the soup dumplings are among the best in NYC.
No comment

Last time I went to Joe's Shanghai (granted, quite a few years ago) They added a tip to our bill without notifying us, and then the manager got angry when we noticed and wanted it refunded as we had left one at the table. There are other better, more honest, and and less touristy places to get Shanghai dumplings in the city.

too good for words...nothing more to say gotta get back to this good grub just know it's beyond amazing. BEST LOCATION YET!

Old style feel, true New York style Chinese and just amazing. Â The dumplings are great, the garlic chicken is wonderful and the soupy dumplings as expected were out of this world. Â This place is definitely worth the hype!
No comment

Best Chinese food. I've been coming here for ~10 years. The dumplings taste like you've died and gone to heaven they are the best. I would come here just to get several servings of dumplings to myself and I'd be the happiest person alive. The atmosphere is nothing special and they pack people in by filling every seat, which means you'll be sitting at a table with strangers. However, the food is so good that the atmosphere doesn't even matter and you won't care about the weird couple sitting in front of you. You won't be disappointed-it's a must go to in nyc.

We ordered a bunch of food but everything besides the soup dumplings were disappointing. ç¤éº¸ was okay. Soup dumplings were great. Shanghai stir fried noodles were so so. Braised pork with pickles was very disappointing - full of soy sauce and nothing else. Not flavorful and weirdly sweet. Service was bad the servers ignored us several times and when I asked about their specialties and recommendations the guy seemed very annoyed and impatient. Well they don't do tips maybe that's the cause but I would still expect any servers to be kind to customers.

A classic! We started with 2 crates of XLB (SO soupy) and got the spicy boiled fish on top of bean sprouts, the chef's tofu drenched in sweet soy sauce, wrapped in delicious egg, and cooked over spinach, for the main. The stir-fried green beans, which were made with a kind of sweet vinegar topping, were also a standout. The fried rice wasn't quite worth it, but I saw a lot of people ordering. Service is efficient, tip is included in the charge. You share tables and the wait is about 15-20 minutes on a Thursday night.
No comment
I'm having a craving with soup dumplings. This is the place! Last time I was here, I think the rating was E? LOL. Still, there's a line.

I've been to the one in Flushing and quality and look of restaurant is the same. We arrived around 9:30 on. Monday night so it wasn't very busy but still a good amount of people - they sat us right away. We got the pork soup dumplings, chicken fried rice, and Shanghai noodle soup. Everything was fresh, came out very fast and was delicious. Can't wait to come back and try some other dishes!
No comment
Best place in nyc for soup dumplings, shredded beef. Always full , now in new place e better seating , cleaner
Sister and I stopped there for dinner on a Saturday Â night. Â Food was AMAZINGLY AUTHENTIC... . Excellent

I was watching the Karate Kid one night and was like wow I want Chinese food. Best decision ever. Went down to Pell St and got some love from my main man Joey Shanghai. They have the best shrimp in the state most likely from the Hudson River and their chopsticks are very easy to use they always have a custom pair with rubberbands they give to their most experienced customers. XiÃ¨xiÃ¨, Joe, XiÃ¨xiÃ¨ (yes that is authentic Chinese LeAndre is a very cultured, classy man from a classy family in the hills).

My goodness. I only had the chicken fried rice but it was simply amazing. I will be remembering this place for when I am in the area again.

Joes Shanghai has some of the best soup dumplings in NY! Their shanghai fried rice (requested to add more soy sauce) is so good too. Love at the end of the meal they give you a lot of oranges and a nice warm red bean drink which is super tasty. Just beware they automatically add a 15% tip to your bill.

Can people stop hyping things please?! I came here with my family while on vacation because it was soooo overhyped by my sister's boyfriend. We had to share tables with other tourist which I don't mind as I'm use to doing that in Chinatown dim sum places back in SF. We ordered their oh so famous shanghai dumplings, green beans, Shanghai noodles and some other dishes. Their dumpling's skin is way too thick and the soup base is way too oily. It looks like I smeared Vaseline across my lips - not sexy. I can honestly say it was one of the worst dumpling's I've had. My grandma steams better ones from prepackaged store bought XLBS. I'm not even comparing these to din tai fung dumplings just the local dumpling places in sf and it still didn't pass the bar. Don't waste your time here!

The food was great but the place is quite packed and there's not small between tables. Also, be aware that it's cash only and the sign for this is inside. We only noticed it after we sat down and had even waiting for 20 minutes. I didn't see any sign outside. This was an inconvenience for us because we had to order food within our cash limit. The food was delicious. I would definitely visit the place again.
No comment

This place was alright. Tried it for the first time, and it was not like what I expected. Got the Lion's head, which was too sweet for my taste. The salt and pepper calamari taste good but not very crunchy. The green beans is what expected of a Chinese restaurant. The xiao long Bao was better than ones in Houston but not great. Over all, I would not go back here. It is more of a one time experience kind of thing.

Half star to this place! The service was lousy! They light up incense while we were seated right next to their worship alter! The food is no longer the same especially their well known soup dumplings! The flavor has gotten worse and they all tear apart when you try to nab then! We went there with a party of 3 people and they added tips to the bill without telling us and made us pay for additional tips unknowingly! Talk about losing customers fast! This place really have gone down the gutter! Good riddance! Will never go back!
The dumplings weren't bad, although the service was not great. We felt rushed to finish and leave. Bathroom was clean.

I always find myself going here whenever I am in Chinatown. I absolutely LOVE this place! I highly recommend getting there early so you don't have to wait too long because it gets packed! It is a very touristy spot, but I don't mind because the soup dumplings are so good!

Review for take out xiao long bao: still so hot they burned my tongue, soup the perfect savory and rich, filling meaty and good ratio to soup, dumpling skins thick and spongy but strong, not weak and easily breakable. 8 for only 8 dollars..... can't be beat here. Best I've had outside of Shanghai.

Really good and hearty XLB and fried pork pot stickers. Not much dim sum but the dishes look good. We're eating our way through china town so this was our first stop. No complaints here.
Soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings soup dumplings! Do you catch what we're dropping?

I came to this place with very high expectations since there was so much buzz around it. Sadly, was greeted with a giant C health rating at the door which I felt like they tried to hid in the corner. This kinda threw me off but I was already there so I decided why not. The food was decent but I would only recommend getting the soup dumplings since they is what they are known for. The egg plant in garlic was just the same as I could get any where else - nothing special. If you love soup dumplings then defiantly check this place out besides that thought, go somewhere with a better health rating.

A must-go every time I am in nyc. I love the soup dumplings and the taiwanese noodle stir fry. Everything is very reasonably priced and delicious. It is true that the service could be better and you will get seated with random strangers but its somewhat expected of Chinese restaurants. Overall enjoy coming here and to me is the ultimate comfort food..!

Man, this place was gooooooood. Soup dumplings on point. This place was packed but totally worth the wait. Tried both the pork and crab xiao long bao as well as trying a few noodle dishes. So good!

Come here for the soup dumplings, but nothing else! The soup dumplings are great but the other dishes are inauthentic and taste more like americanized asian food than Shanghai cuisine. Furthermore, this is a very touristy restaurant; expect to wait at least half an hour during peak times. That being said, the second time I came we got a fried bean curd dish that was a seasonal special at the time and actually very tasty!

The soup dumplings were hot, fresh, and delicious. My young son devoured his chicken dish (recommended by server but don't remember the name). The service was incredible! Didn't have to ask for anything, the servers are positioned throughout the restaurant watching their tables for anything that might be needed. I was there on a Monday during the holiday break and arrived about 30 min after opening. Got a table right away and ordered food before our coats were off. Turned out to be perfect timing - 10 min after arriving there was a line out the door and around the corner!

New location, seating is more spacious and comfortable, and food is great as always. Â The soup dumplings are amazing of course, and I also got the Szechuan beef. Â It's a bit presumptious of them to add an 18% gratuity even for a party of one, but fortunately they do have good service. Â Also with the renovations they seem to have the cleanest and most modern restrooms in all of Chinatown. Â Bring cash, it's cash only, otherwise I would give it 5 stars and order even more food!
No comment
I have an asian tongue and I have to say that I love this place especially the dumplings!! The soup inside is nothing to say more than great!!!

I came where because of what I heard from others and the plentiful Zugat awards the restaurant has received. My family and I ordered 2 different types of soup dumplings - the pork dumpling and the crab dumping. The dumplings were delicious and so was the soup inside. One thing I recommend is not to order to much. We ordered about 6 trays for 8 people and that was way too much. I believe most people can eat around 3-6 dumplings before you are tired of it so order wisely.
We don't come to NYC without eating here. Simply the best! Get the pork dumplings, Shanghai stir fry, and scallion pancakes.

After reading the reviews I stopped into Joe's for a late lunch. It was a fun experience trying someone now and we had seen that there were a lot of reviews we stopped in. We had the pork dumplings chicken Kung poa and flat noodles. Â The dumplings were okay but the flat noodles were out of this world. We ordered ours with seafood. If and when I go back I'll definitely try something similar if not the same exact thing. We shared a table which was fine and atmosphere was definitelyactive. I would definitely recommend stopping in if you've got some time on your hands. Fun experience and good food.

This place is insanely popular- even an hour before it was closing, there was still a line outside. Tried both the pork and crab soup dumplings. Both had a ton of soup inside, which was greatly welcomed. Personally, I didn't get a huge crab taste (might be due to the amount of vinegar I use), but the pork filling definitely tasted good, and seemed more worth. We also tried some of the other noodle dishes, not bad but nothing stood out. Will definitely come again for their soup dumplings though!

Worth the hype! Went with a group of 3 of us and ordered 2 dishes to share plus classic soup dumplings. Perfect amount of food. Funky setup where you share a table with other groups (depending on the size of your group). We ended up sharing a table with one other group. No reservations and the line definitely takes a while to move, but it's worth it!
No comment
No comment

So I've heard that this is the place to go for bomb soup dumplings. We ordered 4-5 soup dumpling orders sharing amongst 6 people. We also ordered some chicken and noodles but I don't think this place is known for anything else besides the soup dumplings so I wouldn't come here again for any other Chinese dishes other than soup dumplings. The size of the dumplings were big enough for 2-3 bites and came out very hot and steamy. The service seemed very busy and a bit unorganized though.
No comment
Wow! Â  Best soup dumplings, pan fried ravioli and string beans I've had. Â Plus the place is clean (which is rare in authentic Chinese restaurants).

This place was amazing! It was a spur of the moment to go & I don't regret it one bit. The soup dumplings are the best ones I have ever had in my whole entire life & I am 101% sure I'm never going to find another place who makes them as good as them. They do only take cash & it was 45 minute wait with a line out the door BUT it was worth it. I would do it again if I had too.

This place is a tourist trap - NOT. This is one of the "touristy" locations that I absolutely love. I'm a big fan of the crab soup dumplings, good pricing and old school Chinatown feel. Chinatown is getting way too gentrified, Joe's Shanghai keeps it real and maintains that culture

Like usual, the service at Joe's is fast. The dumplings are hot and the broth is so flavorful, defilitly the best part of the meal. Then the sauteed eggplant comes and the meal gets even better. The sweet soy sauce on these dumplings is everything, to die for! #welovejoes it does get very busy in here though and they will not seat you unless you're entire party is present. Some tables are large, so they are shared with other customers.

Yes, it is true that you typically will share a table here, depending on the size of your party and the table you which you are seated. If sharing a table is all I have to do to get the most delicious Chinese food I have ever had, no problem.

Awesome soup dumplings. Passed by the new location, looks even fancier now!

After a 20 minute wait in the freezing cold, we were awkwardly seated at a table with four others, and after they left-four more were seated there. Our seats faced a tribute to 8 or 10 different celebrities posing with whom we presumed to be Joe. Anyway, we were hungry and definitely over-ordered. We got soup dumplings, the scallion pancakes, the Steamed Chicken in Scallion and Ginger Sauce, fried rice, the Shanghai soup and a wonton soup, and sautÃ©ed spinach. We all gave our lunch four stars.
I only got the soup dumplings so I can't speak of the other foods. It was good a little expensive but that's nyc. I'd come back for more soup dumplings if not so busy.

They will charge you 15% service fee for any party size whether you like their service or not. Their service is actually really bad hence three stars. Their dumpling it is great. That is a fact. Service is terrible is also a fact.

If you think the soup dumpling here is good, you should consider Xian house of dumplings in SF. Both are very delicious: the latter comes in a smaller/cuter size that you can eat it with one bite; the former comes with XL size and make you feel really satisfied with your dollar spent. The service is ok to terrible: the ok part comes with a 30-minute wait (which is fine if their food is actually good); the terrible part comes in when they serve me wonton with RAW/RED pork!!! Except for the food safety, everything else seems on the ok side.

Expect to be quick when ordering...which is good because that means the quicker you get to taste the delicious soup dumplings. We ordered the pork dumplings and yes they where the best I have ever had. We also ordered the Kung pao, sesame chicken, spicy prawns and green beans. I enjoyed the sesame chicken the best, so much flavor and tasted great.

Amazing dumplings - both pork and crab+pork! Succulent beef+broccoli, awesome noodle soup - best we've had in years!

This place doesn't compare to the other Shanghai-nese restaurants in Chinatown. Â Whenever I'm craving crab meat and pork soup dumplings, I go here. Â They give a good amount of dumplings (8), and the soup is thick and flavorful. Â Their scallion pancakes have the right amount of crispiness and they provide a decent amount of dipping sauce. Â Sometimes, I order their lo mein and rice cakes, but I always request them to be cooked with less sauce as they tend to be too saucy for my taste.

Stumbled upon this hidden gem when I was adventuring Chinatown and it definitely did not disappoint. The Xia Long Bao with pork was delicious! Very packed when I came here, but totally worth the wait!!
No comment

We tried their soup dumplings, crab and pork. We actually tried a few restaurants for Xiao long bao and I would give this place 2 stars. Just on their dumplings!!! The sauce they use for the dumpling is too salty, it ruined the dumplings for me. The sauce is just as important as the dumplings itself. But the dumplings wasn't good at all. We didn't even finish the dumplings, and I hate to waste food.
No comment
The food was great. Busy place! So you should be patient waiting to be seated. Love the pork soup dumplings. The fried rice as well was delicious!

Decent food, not so great service. To start with the positives, the food was good. They are well known for their soup dumplings. There are two options to choose from the pork or crabmeat. We ordered the pork soup dumpling and was fairly impressed. We also ordered the crispy shredded beef and a duck dish. Both were good but not out of this world amazing. I'm pretty thrown off with the service. We went on a Monday night, it was somewhat busy and the server decided to seat us in a shared table even though there were clearly open tables available. It also seemed that our server's favorite response to every question we asked that night was a "no"! They managed to mess up our bill in which they combined our total with the other people we shared the table with. I'm not sure if this was an off night for them since I see a lot of the rave reviews but I wasn't impressed. Luckily there are other locations in NYC (Flushing and Midtown). I'm willing to give it another go, just not at this location.

We had to make a stop here for the famous soup dumplings. I ordered carry out because of the large crowd, but when I went to pick it up just a couple inured early, they were quite rude and wouldn't give me my order. We waited for a while and finally got the dumplings, but I wasn't very pleased with the service. The dumplings them self were not worth the hype, but still had a nice authentic place. I would recommend coming here for the popularity, but I'm sure you can find better soup dumplings elsewhere.

Have come here several times with my parents who love this place almost more than I do. Most recently we didn't have to wait, but in the past we have and run across the street to get quick massages in Chinatown which sounds weird, but it's fun! My step dad gave such glowing compliments that the host gave me a bunch of coupons to bring friends back which I definitely will. Amazing time and amazing food!

column3: Far West Side, San Antonio, TX
column6: The best soup dumplings I've ever had! I would def recommend Joe's Shanghai to anyone visiting NY that is looking for a good Chinese spot. The service and the food was awesome!

It's a very small space hidden inside a dark alley in Manhattan chinatown - very crowded inside and you'll often be seated next to strangers to share a table. Not ideal for intimate dinner dates but that's not why I love it here . Their crab and pork soup dumplings are elysian and the best prices for the quantity and flavor I can find anywhere in nyc . This is my to go spot to satisfy My cravings for soup dumplings; tried a few other dishes on their menu including soups and they were all delicious
Walking hangry around chinatown i stumbled upon this hidden gem and from that time i dream of their soup dumplings which are by far the best i had

One of my favorite places for soup dumplings in NYC! There is almost always a wait and it's cash only but it is worth it. You can get a lot of food for a small amount of cash. The regular dumplings, fried rice and scallion pancakes can't be missed!

Love this place. Been here with my friends and we tried out the soup dumpling. It was delicious. This place doesn't take credit card, but they do have an atm next door. Overall it was a great experience, and I would def come back!

I dream about these soup dumplings. Fantastic food, but be prepared to wait since they do not take reservations here. Also, it is cash only! We were seated at a communal table with one other group of five, and it was fine. It does not take away from the experience. The food comes quickly, is hot, and delicious!

The soup dumplings here were amazing. The food was good but honestly I expected more after hearing about all the hype. Check it out but you won't be blown away.

I love this place! We ordered the crispy Shanghai pan fried noodles with beef, Pork soup dumpling, sweet & sour fried pork, and Shanghai fried flat rice with beef. If you go for dinner on Fri, Sat, or Sunday be prepared for a 30-45 min wait. Plan accordingly and you'll be fine.

First time visit and went for the pork soul dumplings. Â I thought the meat portion in them was small. Â Overall pretty good. That's all I got. Â Cash only and ATM is at the door with $3.50 surcharge. Â Remember the place is in Chinatown, so expect people to speak limited English. Â Also, you're most likely going to share a table with total strangers. Â Lastly, the servers aren't going to be overly polite. Â It's their culture so prepare yourself.

Went the first time and thought it was great. However going the second time it was super bland. They messed up on one of my soups which is not a problem, however, they didn't take it to well when I told them about correcting their mistake. I personally don't take it personal and even liked the gritty ness of the 'unique' customer service. It gives it the fun NYC Chinatown experience haha. If I base it off the first time experience it's 4 to 5 stars but if it was the second time it would be a pure zero for lack of taste.

Total meal cost us about $20 each incld tax and service charge, and we were super full. Good value for money! You need cash though, which in my case was a hassle because my card got locked out when I used the ATM right outside the restaurant. The cashier was flexible and accepted Venmo.

The dumplings were so doughy we couldn't find the filling. The crispy chicken was dry and flavorless!! We threw it all out and had peanut butter and jelly sandwiches along with the boring but edible lomein

By far my favorite Chinese restaurant! I crave their soup dumplings all the time. Although they are not known for their service I think that is part of the charm of it. Big group, small group, it's always a fun time. You have to have everyone in your party there before you will get seated and it's cash only. They do include a 15% tip on the check every time. Also, the picture I attached is right when it opened. I have never seen it that empty. We always get dumplings, pan fried noodles, and scallion pancakes. The price is super reasonable as well!

I wasn't ready for this experience. I had never had soup dumplings up to this point in my life and I feel like I've been seriously missing out. Straight up delicious. Keep in mind that there will be a line and that other dishes can get a little on the pricey side.

There's a bit of a wait but that's how you know it's good. You sit communal style in a large round table. Met other tourists so it was not awkward. The pork soup dumplings are a must! The Shanghai Noodles were delicious. It did not disappoint and would definitely come back when in New York
It would be better if the food could be more fresh!!! Really not as good as expected! Long queue waiting for disappointment!

What can I say that 3,218 other Yelpers haven't said already? How about thank God/dess for jury duty for bringing me to Chinatown to finally sample the many treats of this crowded, labyrinthine 'hood. Joe's had a short line, a cranky but efficient line management system, and fine enough service. You don't come here for the decor. Pork and crab soup dumplings are awesome, hot and steamy with great flavor. Scallion pancakes were solid as well. Nothing fancy, just decent food and that's good enough!

Always get the classic xiao long bao and noodle sticks! You can never go wrong with it. Be prepared to wait and don't be shocked if the make you share a table with strangers!

This place is all it's talked up to be. You must get the soup dumplings and eat them first. They are best fresh and not worth taking for later. The green beans were delicious and the pan fried noodles were very good. The place is small and you have to share a table with other people, but the great thing about that is that the people you share the table with sometimes leave you their leftovers!

Listen, I love Joe's Shanghai, their thick noodles with pork and their soup dumplings are the fucking bomb. But I don't like the fact that their sesame chicken is 19$. It doesn't taste any different than your average NYC Chinese restaurant sesame chicken platters.
Food was good but way over priced!!!! Left hungry and still paid over $80 not including tip. Rice not included with the meal and was charged $2 for a tiny bowl of rice, got 5 small shrimp for $23.
Bueno bonito y barato! Absolutely the best soup dumplings eva! Community tables, crowded even at 3pm but wait time was 15 mins. Definitely coming back and next tine ordering more!!

I've only ever head soup dumplings in Boston's Chinatown, so I can't say that I have much to compare to. However, the pork dumplings and the crab dumplings I had here were great! The service here was pretty quick as well, which I appreciated. I also recommend getting their fried rice, as it wasn't too salty and it was a great way to fill up after having some dumplings. Don't forget to sprinkle some of the black vinegar on basically everything! Also this place is cash only.

BEST DUMPLINGS EVER!!!! When I went to New York City for the first time me and my brother went to this place and loved it!! The food here it's reaaaaally great, then this second trip we really had to go and the flavor of the food was even greater!

We were sat with a different group, they try to fit as many people as possible in there. But the food was delicious! Best dumplings I've had. The portions are good sized, we got full fast. It's a cash only place so be prepared. I would recommend here for sure. We originally went because we thought it would have dim sum- it does not. But we still enjoyed it there anyways!

My friend recommend me this place for dumplings! It's quite good , however I took out one star for the service bz they can not get the order even my friend tell 3-4 times. But totally it's ok!
Soup dumplings? Yes sir! #1 late night food in NYC. Great atmosphere for big groups.
Scallion pancakes, spicy szechuan style beef and soup dumplings - you can never go wrong with this combination.

Got the scallion pancake, pork soup buns (XLB), and the Shanghai chow mein. The scallion pancake was divine , so were the soup buns, but would've rather ordered an eggplant dish instead of the noodle dish as there was not much to it.

Seating was limited and they wanted my party of 4 to seat with two other individuals I didn't know. I decided to wait for a table of 4. I got a 1/4 of a large container and like 3 spoonfuls of rice in the same container. So less than half of the container had food. I had really high expectations for this place. For $20 the food tasted average and the portion size made it completely a three time experience...... The first, the last and the never again. Hopefully someone will chose better than I did. McDonald's came in clutch tonight.

Long wait but worth it! Best soup dumplings I've ever (all of their other food is also very good!) Everytime I come to NYC I make it a point to come here. I always bring new ppl to the city to experience the greatness!

There was about 40 min wait on a Friday night, which wasn't bad given how many people were waiting outside the restaurant. Pretty crowded space and they seat smaller parties together at large circular tables. The waiter took our order first and the soup dumplings came out pretty quickly while the rest of the table stared at us out of jealousy. The size of the soup dumplings is larger than your average soup dumpling and there is plenty of soup. Compared to ding tai feng, the skin is thicker and the presentation is less delicate overall, but still delicious. My friend and his family are from Shanghai and they think that Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings are better than the ones back home, so that's saying something. Also, eight for the price of $6.25 is a steal. This location is cheaper than the midtown location which is eight for $8.25. Will definitely be coming back for more.

The best thing were the soup dumplings. Â We had seafood and pork and were really good. Â We also had a seafood noodle dish and it was OK, but really, the best were the dumplings. Â It was very busy on a Sunday night but the line went quick. Â Worth the trip.

Legit Chinese food in a hole-in-the-wall in Chinatown NYC. Seriously great authentic food. Totally packed restaurant. Cash ONLY!! We sat at a communal table with people that didn't speak English but ordered a ton of food and seemed to really enjoy it, including slurping the soup, lol. Roasted beet dumplings were good, the potstickers were good, the house chicken and rice noodles soup was amazing!

We ordered Joe's Shanghai to our hotel while staying in Manhattan on business. We got a large variety of items and all of them were very good. I highly recommend Joe's of you get a craving for some excellent Chinese delivery.

This place may be over hyped, and sure, there may be many other places that serve better XLB/soup dumplings, but don't let that steered away! Joe's XLB are widely known for a reason. They're tasty! Richly flavored pork with meaty broth. I'm obsessed with their basic pork XLB, much more than the crab ones. Each order comes with about 8. I could order so many orders and it wouldn't break the bank. This is on my list of cheap eats! We didn't get a chance to try their other dishes, but our fellow guests at the communal table ordered much more than we did and it all looked and smelled fantastic. The communal tables aren't as awkward and uncomfortable as you think. These tables are huge! Everyone minds their own business and you can barely hear others' conversations. The service is so fast, which is great. Their logistics and organisation surprises me. There were no unhappy customers. If you're new to soup dumplings, this is a great place to start. It can get extremely packed, but we came on a Saturday afternoon with no wait. Must've just been lucky!
I dont know about ya'll.. but this place freaking nailed with those soup dumplings. I've tried some soup dumplings from other franchises too, but J Shangai make the best ones.
If you're looking for a authentic Chinese food in China town in New York then this is your spot! The food is amazing!

Ordered delivery on UberEats and was unsure how it would be after the lengthy delivery. It was great! The food arrived and was still very hot & everything tasted as if it was in the restaurant. The hot&sour soup was delicious and very hot (it didn't even need to be heated up in the microwave). We ordered two orders of the soup thinking we would each have one... I don't recommend doing that unless you want a ton of leftovers. One order of the hot & sour soup can easily provide 2.5 servings. The spring rolls were also good and were still crispy (somehow they didn't get soggy with the delivery). We also ordered shrimp fried rice that was a pretty large portion and very good. The shrimp fried rice was not dry at all and hit the spot. The sesame chicken was still crispy and perfect... Joe's thought of a great method to deliver the sesame chicken (they cut out a hole in the plastic lid so the condensation didn't cause the chicken to get soggy) and it worked so well. The entire meal tasted just as good as in the restaurant. Overall, this meal was AMAZING! We are already talking about our next order. Would love to help provide business to this great place especially during covid. We look forward to next time!

Crab meat with pork meat steamed bun-delicious. So juicy and flavorful. Well balanced flavor of crab and pork. Shanghai fried flat noodle-good. Very chewy flat noodles with a small amount of pork and vegetables. A little oily. SautÃ©ed string beans-average. Fresh string beans. Well cooked. A little oily. Huge portion.

Brace yourself for the musty air, seafood stench, and Shanghainese flavors, all faintly yet pleasantly grazing your olfactory receptors. That, my friends, is a recipe for a legit Chinatown experience. By luck, our party of 3 was seated right away in a full house on a Tuesday at 7:30pm. We got 3 orders of XLB, an order of scallion pancakes, and the shrimp fried rice cakes. Soup dumplings have just the right consistency--skin breaks with the slightest puncture so handle them with some TLC before chomping down. I recommend ordering each round individually to maximize the freshness of the dumplings. The scallion pancakes were a bit drier than expected, but nothing too unpleasant. With the best for last, the shrimp fried rice cakes are a must-try. Generous portion size with a plethora of rice cakes, right amount of shrimp & mushrooms, and minimal veggies. All for ~$50 with tip. As anticipated, service moved quick. Expect to sit elbow-to-elbow with other parties in the same table, which I think adds to the experience. This place is no joke.

My brother n sister took us to this wonderful Chinese dumpling house. We tried the pork dumpling, Shanghai noodles, and fried rice. I would like to come back again and try some of the other dishes.

My standards for xiao long bao (soup dumplings) are pretty high because they're the best at Din Tai Fung in Taiwan. They're really good here, but the meat could have more crab. There's a LOT of soup in the dumplings though, so that's great. They push a bed of steamed napa cabbage under the soup dumplings, and it catches any soup that oozes out. Really tasty! The skin is really chewy as well, and it's all-in-all a great place for soup dumplings. We also ordered the Shanghai noodles, which were quite tasty too. The noodles were really chewy and tasty, and the flavor was great. Three of us got two orders of the soup dumplings (8 in each order) and a plate of the noodles, and it came out to only be $26 post-tax! Very cheap, very good. Would recommend!

I'm so glad we ended up at Joe's Shanghai and tried their soup dumplings. It was a great experience and the food is delicious. Take cash with you since they don't take cards. It as must try in Chinatown.

Every time I am in New York, I visit Joe's. Â This place is amazing. Â This is where I fell in love with Soup Dumplings and will always be my favorite. Â  A few weeks ago, I was able to bring my two children (9 and 11) to try soup dumplings at Joes and they fell in love immediately. Â Love, love, love this place. Â Thanks.

I've been coming here for about 10+ years now...introduced to by friends. Best soup dumplings I have had by far...and I've searched, believe me. The mixed soup dumplings, shanghai fried rice with a side of scallion pancakes...something that will immediately put you in a delicious and comforting food coma. If you're a local, it's the perfect lunch/dinner; a bit challenging when you're coming from NJ, but parking isn't too bad considering regulations in NYC are strict. You'll always find a spot in China Town! If you go on a weeknight, especially wknd night, expect to wait an hour for a table (a table that you may or may not share with others). Lunch gets quite busy as well, but you're in the clear if you arrive before 12pm. Absolutely worth the wait, regardless.

My uncle, who is a frequent visitor to NY, recommended this place, so imagine my joy when I found out it was located one block from our hotel. Â Came in on a Saturday night and while there was a wait, it was 15 minutes less than the hostess indicated. Â The dumplings were the star of the show for sure. Â Moist and flavorful and amazing! Â I also had the beef and asparagus and hubby had the beef noodle soup. Â Service was quick, the food was excellent and the atmosphere was great. Â Will definitely come back!

This is a legitimate Chinese place. But with flavors that aren't too foreign, it is easy for tourists to enjoy themselves while having a new experience. I would definitely recommend the soup dumplings, because that's something that you can't experience at your corner Chinese restaurant. That is, unless, you live in china town in NYC.

In the heart of China town, such a cute area. But it gets extremely busy and just be warned you might have to share a table with people you don't know. The food is wonderful! My family and I had the ?vegetable fried rice, the vegetable lo mein, and the fried noodles with beef. All super yummy! My personal favorite was the vegetable fried rice. Prices are very reasonable. Would definitely go back if I was in the area again. Such a cool place! Just wish it was a little bigger.

The food was sooooooo goood. Absolutely amazing definitely my favorite Asian restaurant in all of New York. We ordered the sesame chicken, general tso chicken, Mongolian beef, fried rice and the lo mein. Everything was perfect. Another thing is they only accept cash.
Best damn xiaolongbao I have ever had in my life. Literally just wanna go back there and eat that all the time.
Good soup dumplings and awesomely old school interior with neon lights. The place is bigger than it looks on the outside and service is quick and thorough!

Joe's Shanghai is really good. For most of my friends this is their first experience with soup dumplings-which are the must order items on the menu. Also, its important to note, unless you have a shellfish allergy, order the soup dumplings with crab in them. They are 1000x better than the pork ones. Joe's Shanghai is always a fun option because it is always busy and the food is always good. I think you can find better food in NY but for the cost and the experience, it is a must visit.

We came on a Sunday night for dinner and we ended up having to wait around 30 minutes before getting a table which is not bad. This place is pretty efficient in what they do so they get patrons in and out pretty quickly so the next group can get on in. And no seat was empty -- they would seat couples at a large table with a family if two seats were available at the table! AWKWARD! But anyway, the soup dumplings are freakin' huge and freakin' delicious!! We ordered the crab & pork -- each was full of delicious liquid!! Just amazing!! This place was ok. The soup dumplings were good but just your average soup dumpling . (All Soup Dumplings are good) The Kung pao chicken was a bit of a let down because it didn't have much flavor. A little bit of a letdown because it wasn't that great despite the rave reviews.
The crab dumplings are good. It gets busy and crowded at lunch on a weekday. I ordered for takeout and didn't need to wait in line during lunch time.

WOW! The Soup Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) was amazingly delicious! Â We had the crab meat xiao long bao that were filled with mixed crab and pork meat in very fresh tasty soup inside 'em small steamed buns! Â On a cold weather day, those steamed buns were totally a life saver that made me day! Â Prices were reasonable; about 9 bucks for an order of 8 steamed buns. Good bang for the buck, wasn't it? Â We also had the Shanghai fried noodles, which to me, was just like yaki udon in heavy soy sauce; not bad though! Â The Lion's Head, or stewed pork meat balls, were my favorite; meaty, soft and flavorful! Â The chilled pork kidney appetizer was really good; the pork kidney was thinly sliced and had a good texture (not too hard/ chewy or too soft/ mushy). Â Sour Soup was just standard, and the shredded eel with yellow chives was A-ok. Â The off-menu fried soft-shell crabs came in huge portion size, for about 22 bucks, was my mother-in-law's excitement for the money spent; she loved 'em exoskeleton-free fried goodness. Â This place was totally worth the 30-minute wait time, and I surely would come back!

The soup dumplings here are really good, along with the scallion pancakes. Â When we arrived there it was cold out, and there was space to wait inside BUT! the girl who gave us a number told us we had to wait outside ... makes no sense to me but okay...anyways, to not get confused the soup/Shanghai dumplings are listed as "steamed buns" under the appetizer section. We ordered the crab & pork ones and the pork - the regular pork ones taste better than the one with crab meat. Â The scallion pancakes were crispy and good, a little oily. Â The two other dishes (Shanghai noodle and Eggplant with garlic sauce) we ordered were way too oily, which led me to believe that every other dish were would be pretty oily. Â Overall, I would only come back here to eat the soup dumplings but probably nothing else. Â We ended up bagging the two dishes up and giving them to a homeless man on the street.

Best Xiao long bao I've had. The place is cash only like most Asian places. You share a table if you have a smaller group, but makes the wait faster. They had two types: Xiao Long Bao with crab meat pork, and Xiao Long Bao with only pork. I preferred the original, just because I was used to the texture and taste, but the crab meat pork xiao long bao was different, not in a good or bad way. We also ordered the beef noodle soup (quite bland, although the menu indicated it was "slightly spicy) but the beef itself was extremely tender and flavorful. The snow pea tips were cooked perfectly. Overall a pleasant meal, even when sharing a table with complete strangers. It was like a hibachi meal... but without the distractions from the awkwardness...

Super cramped dining room? Check. Hour long wait? Check. While these might not be the hallmarks of comfort dining, to me, they are the hallmarks of everything I want to see and experience in a restaurant deep in the heart of Chinatown. Joe's Shanghai is one of those restaurants that may be hidden in an ally but is not hidden from the people that know the deliciousness that it serves. The lines are always out the door and it is a beehive of activity. What is so good about this place you say? Soup dumplings I tell ya! Joe's Shanghai definitely does soup dumplings, AKA Xiao Long Bao, justice that many other places do not. Often times you get these semi-shrunken soupless dumplings at a lot of places. But here, be prepared to scald the inside of your mouth because these dumplings are packed with soup. Each dumpling comes out hot and fresh in baskets of 8, all nice and plump. The skins are so pleasantly thin that when you pick up the dumplings, you are so afraid that you'll pierce the skin and lose the soup before it gets into your mouth. But, for such a thin skin, it actually holds up remarkably well. It keeps everything encapsulated so that when you bite it, the soup gushes out in a glorious hot burst. The meat and filling on the inside is deliciously tender and most and complements the skin and soup so well. Sure, you may burn your mouth, but for the delicious flavors that you well experience, the pain is worth it.
Oh my god, seriously? Who said this is one of the best Chinese restaurant in NYC? He must never have real Chinese food. All dishes we got are awful. First time eating here, and last time too.

One of the more famous soup dumpling places in New York, not a bad choice if you don't have time to venture all the way out to Flushing. The clientele is mostly non-Chinese and there seems to be a lot of tourists (it is Manhattan after all). The food is average Chinese restaurant fare, not bad but not terrific in my standards. Would I eat it? yes. Would I stand in line for it again? no. If you want to eat at Joe's Shanghai I'd rather go to the midtown location which has more tables and is a bit nicer--the food is comparable.

A fixture of China Town, this place simply makes the best Chinese food I've ever had. I don't know if it's authentic, and the dining room is cramped and certainly doesn't have much aesthetic quality, but you're not going to care because the soup dumplings are absurdly great. Everything else on the menu is excellent too, and the food lacks that overly syrupy/MSG overdose tendency that much of "Americanized" Chinese food has - meaning that despite the generous portions, you don't end up in a food coma afterwards. Put simply, the place is great.

We went here 10 minutes before they closed and we're seated and had delicious dumplings and general tsos shortly after. Highly recommended, Â everyone should come here at least once in their life

I've been eating Chinese food all my life. Â So much so, that I got very tired of it. Â And because its availability is high, the quality seems to go down and I rarely enjoy it. Joe's Shanghai was recommended to us by some friends that raves about their soup dumplings. We've never had soup dumplings before and let me tell you, they are AMAZING! The dumpling skin is so thin that the soup looks like it's going to break through the skin when you pick it up (I hate it when the skin is really thick and doughey). We tried both the pork and crab/pork dumplings. Both were very very good. The only caveat to this place is the long wait - otherwise I'd be here every time I visited NYC.

Oh my gosh when I came here I was really looking forward to having some of "the best soup dumplings in Chinatown" as deemed by multiple sources. I am currently reviewing and rating for 3 stars until I go again next time so I may update this in the future. My order consisted of the crabmeat & pork soup dumplings, regular pork soup dumplings, eggplant in garlic sauce, and a side of rice. My dumplings came out very hot and tasty but over cooked and they became dry when they got to my table. The eggplant and garlic sauce dish was also very hot and tasty, but lacked that Shanghainese spice and kick I am accustomed to. I suppose it's become a very Americanized establishment to better suit a wider range of patrons. It's great that the waiters all speak English, are very quick, easy to flag down, and check up on you often. The place is cash only, a little inconvenient but it keeps the prices low. The bathroom is also decent compared to some other bathrooms in Chinatown, but would appreciate it if they were better kept. Also there is no hook on the door for a coat and bag (I was heading out with my belongings and I had all my things with me so it's important to have a hook to use lol). I really enjoyed the service, temperature of the food, and the flavors of the food however I think it could do with some adjusting. So 3 stars will be my rating for this experience until next time!

Really good Chinese food. Â Personally when I feel like a good soup dumpling, there is where we go/order from. Â Go there for the food and you will not be sorry-- but don't expect friendly service/cozy dining atmosphere.

Yeah, Sometimes I hear that there is a better place for Shanghai soup dumplings than Joe's, but I find that hard to believe cause I've been to Shanghai, China and had soup dumplings there and these are just as good and almost exactly like the ones I had there. Other places in NYC make thinner dumplings, so they tear easily when you try to lift them with your chopsticks and put it in the spoon. Can't go wrong with Joe's so don't bother trying other places, but make sure you get there early or late as the wait is long. Oh, and don't forget to get the string beans and chow fun fried rice as it's very good as well. But don't bother with any entrees, just load up on dumplings as that's why you come here.

Overrated. I might be a bit too harsh on this establishment but here's why I'm rating 2-star. For a place with thousands of reviews, I'm expecting some top notch food but Joe's just doesn't deliver. We waited about 30 min for a table. The place is crowded, somewhat chaotic with servers running around all over the place. Expect to sit at a large table with strangers. Food is served fast. With all the hype, Joe's really could've fell hard. But I was really impressed by the authenticity, the quick and friendly service, and the overall operation. Menu large and hits every American's taste buds as well as more traditional Chinese offerings. Waiters work fast but offer opinions on favorites and best ofs. I ordered quick and had sake, crab soup dumpling, cold sesame noodle, and soup pancake. Everything was good and I left still burping and tasting the meal (in a good way). Pancake essentially a latke Â with some chives and had a great dipping sauce. But dipping it in the sesame noodle sauce worked well as well. Speaking of sesame noodle, the quantity is something else. They really pile high and soak it in the sauce. Pro tip is to add tons of chili sauce. Perfect noodles and a nice change of pace from the entirely hot meal from food to tea. The soup dumplings are as good as advertised. Â Quite big and not too fishy so good for even the anti-fish eaters. Sauce overly vinegary for me but others seemed to like it. But in all the dumplings had such thick skin but a bounce to them that is just so rare and a perfect sight. Cash only but again super cheap for the quality and quantity. Definitely will get busy but come on weekday and you can sneak in under 20 minutes. Only complaint is the communal tables regardless of numbers (all seat 4 or 6) but I guess it's a family type of restaurant so makes sense so seat big rather than bars or tiny areas. Joe's lives up to the hype and is well well worth the wait.

It is very busy even around 3pm. You should expect at least half an hour's wait but it worths it. For people who don't know what to order, definitely try xiaolongbao and the salty pork soup with bamboo. I want to try the pork feet; however, it is sold out.

Food is better than average. My kids enjoyed it. We got scallion pancakes, pork & crab dumplings, beef Lo-mein & shrimp fried rice. The Lo-mein had a good quality beef & the noodles were thicker than a standard Chinese take out which I prefer. The rice was average with petit shrimp. We enjoyed both dishes. The hits for our table were the dumplings & pancakes. My children have advanced taste pallets so getting them to try & enjoy the dumplings/pancakes was easy. However, we were accompanied by two children who were not very adventurous & we ended up ordering 4 trays of dumplings to accommodate everyone. Everyone killed it. Regarding the seating process, you get a ticket & wait for your # to be called. The numbers are not called in order. I was told 15 minutes, but waited a little over an hour. We had a big party & they were really busy. At some point you've waited so long you just decide to succumb to the wait. In the end it was worth it. Nice pot of hot tea to warm us & we left with full belly's! As mentioned it's cash only, but it's cheap!

One of the best places for soup dumplings!! Love both crab and pork! Must have that they ask you as soon as you sit down. Expect for a wait but well worth it. Must have the scallion pancakes and rice cakes as well!!! Â Cash only!

Ok if you like authentic dumplings, this is the place for you. Â It is a bit off the beaten path and they accept cash only, but the dumplings are worth it. Â Really everything we had was fantastic. Â The shrimp and beef dishes were very tasty go just before noon and beat the rush. Â Note that small parties me be seated with other groups.
I've only have soup dumplings from this place. The juice is delicious. Their dumplings is pretty good size. The down side of this place = The wait is crazy.

Eh, I mean I like soup dumplings and the place is close. I find the place just 'too cool for school.' The pork and crab dumplings are good, but I've definitely had better-just not in Manhattan, but it's worth the trek out to Flushing if you really want XLB.

This place is amazing! The interior is charming with the mixture of NY 80s and Chinese decor. The food portions are huge and the food itself is delicious!!! The dumplings are great and the pancakes are to die for!

One of the worst Chinese place I have ever been to in the states and yes I am a Chinese. If you want actual Chinese place food, this is not the place to go.

In general, typical Americanized Chinese food. However, they have the best soup dumplings that you'll find anywhere. Well worth a visit.
Love love love this place. Just be aware you might have to sit with random people at a table. Very cheap and delicious chinese food.

Soup Dumplings are great but their service leaves a lot to be desired. Been a fan for about 5 years however I was very disappointed on my last trip when I saw their C grading. For a place that stays constantly busy and makes money they should really have their health inspection as one of their priorities. Having worked in a restaurant I know that there can be a range of things that can get you from an A to a B, such as leaving an ice scoop in the ice maker or leaving boxes of products on the floor instead of on a shelf. However it looks like their offenses were much greater than that such as roaches and vermin prone environments. There are certain things I can look past however for now Joe's won't be getting my business until they think about practicing safe food handling as much as getting my money. A quick Google search will give you the information you need, Joe's Shanghai health inspection grade C report results.

We went to this Joe's Shanghai in Chinatown based on high rating hype. The restaurant's on a side street was not exacting easy to find using the online navigation provided. It was busy around late lunch time but there was no wait. We could tell all customers were out of town tourists. Belatedly we found out they do not accept credit card so our menu selections were limited. We chose Xiao Long Bao soup dumplings, aka Pork Steamed Buns (the main motivation of our visit) and String Bean, a typical Szechuan style vegetable dish. Â We found the steamed dumplings larger in size than the usual, dainty ones we had tasted elsewhere. After eating 2 orders of these, we concluded that they were excessively soupy (watch out for plenty hot liquid squirting out at first bite) and doughy. The string beans were average. Watch out: we noted they automatically added a 15% service charge on the bill (for a party of 2) which seemed unusual to us.

Â I've been to the other locations with my sisters but we prefer this original Chinatown location as the dumplings seem to be more flavorful here. Â Every trip to NY in the past, present and future include a visit here.

A great no frills place to have some delicious soup dumplings. The staff is very quick and not very friendly. Don't expect them to go out of their way. I would say this is in the top 5 dumplings I have tasted. But they are not the best I have ever had. Still worth visiting though!

My favorite place for soup dumplings in NYC. As a NYC native- don't let anyone tell you different! This place is amazing, but not really worth it to get anything here BUT the soup dumplings. It is a quick paced environment and if you are a small party it is likely you will be sat at a communal table (just don't let any stranger accidentally steal your dumplings!). My brother and I come here often and get two or three orders of the soup dumplings as our meal. The other food is okay- nothing I haven't tasted before. I like coming for dinner because they give you oranges at the end of your meal!

The soup dumplings are so good Â (and so is the rest of the food here) - each order comes with 8, and they are NOT small dumplings. The service tends to be fast once you're seated, but sometimes the wait to actually get seated can be a little bit long, especially if you have a big group. Overall, the food is great and really cheap - definitely get the soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, and eggplant + garlic sauce!
No comment

The å°ç¬¼å here is definitely good. I used to come a lot, but now it's become a tourist spot and the wait is too long. They also put parties together at one large table, which is uncomfortable sometimes. While the food is good, the experience isn't that great, so it loses some stars. Also their other dishes aren't that great. There are other comparable soup dumpling places nearby that offer a better overall experience.

LOVE IT! Â fantastic selection of dim sum and usual Chinese fare all authentic and delicious! this classic NYC SPOT adds to it's atmosphere with communal table seating where you can share NYC stories (or not) with neighbors and/or tourists alike. FUN FOOD! Often crowded, if going for Sunday dim sum, get there early for a good table!

Ordered wonton soup with shrimp wontons, Shanghai beef, Crispy Duck and Seafood with fried noodles. Strangely the main course arrived before the soup & dumpling appetizer. Overall nothing to rave about.

(12.12.15) Yum, yum! Had the pork soup dumplings and the crab & pork soup dumplings. The ginger in the soy sauce was great. Line is incredibly long and they pack you in like sardines, but it's worth it for the experience. They even have pics of Jeremy Lin's visit there on their walls!
This has to be one of the best Chinese restaurants We have ever eaten at. Â Service was good, but the food is absolutely amazing.
Best soup dumpling ever, get the crab meat one. It was an hour wait for us , but it's totally worth it

Best scallion pancake I've ever had was from here. I find myself always coming back for that reason! Of course the soup dumplings are great and well as the beef noodle soup. The prices are great as this is cash only. I think the one on upper east side prices are more expensive. This is the original location and you can definitely feel the authenticity. One thing I will say is that the service is okay, they don't really give you water unless you ask which isn't a huge deal for me but sometimes they forget even if you ask! Lol. The restaurant is a shared table restaurant which means most of the time you'll have to sit at a table with other people, so if you're not into that sort of thing just be mindful when you come here. They do have two people tables but only about 4 of them. Taking off a star for not offering srirachua sauce though
The food here is amazing, but there will sometimes be a wait. Because of how busy the place is, they sometimes split a 10 seat table into several groups, but the food and price makes it all up.

Visiting a friend in the wonderful city of New York and had to make our way to Chinatown. Letting the power of yelp and hunger of our stomaches lead us here! Â We waited what felt like forever (45+Mins) to finally be seated with our new family (strangers). What has me amazed is while reviewing my fellow yelpers I don't recall the system they use to sit you down at this place being mentioned... however all in all it was a fun experience and the food was good. The Â (pork) soup dumplings are a must and (chicken) lo mein was authentic and so yummy! As for anything else I'm not won over... Â the fried rice was ohhkayyy. I've had better and we tried one other dish that was not liked by ANY of the girls...
If you want great dumplings and authentic Chinese food be prepared to wait a while for a table, this place is always busy but wort the wait. Love their ginger chicken and vermicelli dishes too.

Just don't expect good atmosphere and good service here but it's really good Chinese food though.
The soup dumplings were amazing! I will definitely go back again. Everything on the menu is so authentic and comes out so quickly. Worth the wait... even if we waited for 30 minutes.

Consistently listed on top places to get Xiao long bao but it's definitely overrated. There are places in flushing that are infinitely better...

They're a little too expensive compared to other soup dumplings around town but very good, fresh, piping hot burn in your mouth dumplings!! Go to the Chinatown location! (Or don't, so that I can get a table there quicker ;) ) seriously though the soup dumplings are to die for - if you eat here and don't get them I don't know what's wrong with you. They'll rock your world but be careful they're HOT!

I came to Joe's Shanghai with my girlfriend on a beautiful summer day in August and had her favorite lunch ever: dumplings! They can be found on the appetizers portion of the menu. We had the pork dumplings and the crab/pork dumblings as well as a cold appetizer; chicken with vermicelli. Athe dumplings were the most flavourful i've had and my girlfirend went crazy over them. The vermicelli and chicken was not amazing but still passed as "really good" to us both. Servers were sort of unfriendly but they had a full house and managed to serve us very quickly and efficiently. All in all, this is a great place to bring visitors to NY's chinatown and a great place for authentic Chinese food.

Haven't been to Joe's Shanghai in awhile but I was craving for some soup dumplings. My fave place would be Nan Xiang in Flushing for it but since I was in Ctown, I decided to come here. One thing I hate about this place is that it's filled with tourists usually, where tour buses would bring them here which I find pretty annoying. Next, they love to make you share tables which is what happened to me last night. Had to share with 3 other groups on a big table. For 2 people, we ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings. shanghai noodles and a pork chop noodle soup. I used to love this place back in the days but I feel like some things have gone down hill for sure. Soup dumplings have definitely gotten saltier and pork chop were so so. Shanghai Asian Cuisine on Mott Street might be better than them now. I won't be coming back here. Wished Din Tai Fung was in NYC.

I went here with my boyfriend and his family so there was 5 of us and we waited around 10-15 minutes which wasn't too bad for a Sunday around noon. We were seated with another group of 3 people which is a little strange and awkward sitting with other people but you could always make friends that way. We got both types of soup dumplings and I preferred the beef. The soup was really flavorful and the consistency of the dumpling was really good. Best Soup Buns in the West! Everything is terrific but you don't want to not try those!

I tried the crab/pork soup dumplings, the pork soup dumplings, and the scallion pancakes. Scallion pancakes were good... but don't expect to be blown out of the water because it's just your average greasy scallion pancake ($2.95). The soup dumplings were SO good. Make sure to eat it with a broth spoon so you can drink all the soup broth from the dumpling. I can't tell you if I liked the crab or just pork better, so I recommend getting both! Btw they included the 15% service tip. And, we came at 10:35pm on a Saturday night and they still served us, even though kitchen closed at 11:00pm
Food is OK. Service rude and indifferent always. Is it really that hard? There are better choices. No return for me.

Soup dumplings are amazing! (Xiao Long Bao) I went from Din Tai Fung to this OG spot. No disrespect to DTF but the price for the dumping's here are way better and just as good. We got an order for about $9! We also ordered the Shanghai fried rice and crispy pork chops. The outside part of the dumping was just a little to thick for me but that didn't take away from how good those dumping's were. Fried rice and pork chops were like any other place but still good. Tables were a little too small for all the food we ordered but keep in mind the restaurant is not very big. We came when it was raining and there wasn't a wait but I can only imagine how long the wait is when it's a nice day out. They make it an effort to get you in and out. Also, 15% tip is already included when paying for check.(look on the last page of the menu) Overall, will come back to this place! Cheap food for vacation! (CASH ONLY)

This place is an NYC staple! However it's hard to order anything but the soup dumplings. I would say the bathroom is a bit dirty for my comfort level and it's a very cramped restaurant. BUT that is part of the Magic of ChinaTown lol.

Food was mediocre at best. Everything we ordered was greasy (crab and pork soup dumplings and the worst string beans I've ever had). Shanghai noodles were the only decent thing we had. Don't waste your time at this tourist trap.

I love this place. It's always super busy so be prepared to wait and unless you're with alot of people, you will be sitting with strangers. Â The food is worth it tho. Do not go here and not have the soup dumplings. That is the whole point of coming here lol They are the best so far in my book. I haven't been able to find a good NJ replacement. I'm still looking.

So many pros here. The service was great, the setting was delightful and the wait staff was on point. But how expensive.. would not mind paying this price if dumplings where fresh and tasty authentic dumplings but there Not.

This place is toristy trap, foods okay, service could be better. They seem to want to rush you out of there, definitely not a place for catching up with peeps.
Crab & pork soup dumplings a must! Be ready to fall in line no matter what time or day. Also be ready for communal table, but it works
Not a real Chinese food at all!! I can't believe there were so many people on waiting line!

Very good Chinese food, even among other restaurants in Chinatown. Oftentimes there will be a long wait, but there is little else to complain about. Prices are reasonable, service is good, and the food is delicious.

Finally ate at Joe's after a year of living in NYC. I went with two other friends on a Monday night. We only had to wait 5 minutes when we were seated at a table with three other people. My friends told me that the normal wait on a weekend night would be around an hour. The food was great and the price was all great. But I loved how attentive all the workers are. There are an abundance of workers who are waiting to take away your empty dishes or bring you your food or refill your water.
Amazing food, especially dumplings (and I'm not a fan usually), the sesame chicken was really good too, we paid 60 (including a tip) for 4 people and left the place full and satisfied.

This place goes without saying is perfect. Line is long during rush hours and they don't take reservation but it's worth every minute of waiting. Coming from Shanghai, I think the food is authentic. Took my relative there too when she visited - and she loved it. Highly recommend.

Joe's is exactly what you expect in china town. its small, cramped, loud, busting etc. Service is fast. Well this place is a hidden gem of Chinatown! I mean I'm sure it's famous but you have to enter through Â like an alley to get here so it makes you feel like you know a great place. When you come in, it's family style seating, which mean you sit a big table with Probably 2 other couples who just got there or just finishing up. This place is the ultimate NYC tourist trap because it is very well known for their soup dumplings (I can see why). Their soup dumplings are delicious and addictive.
