THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!! I brought my friend to this place a few weeks ago after finding it on yelp! At first, I had no clue whether if it's good or not; however, my parents told me that this place is famous and delicious, and that they even have it at flushing (if it's in flushing, you know it has some sort of standard). I ordered my childhood dishes: scallion pancakes, cold sesame noodles, and soup dumplings. My friend ordered sesame chicken and vegetable fried rice. THE PORTIONS ARE HUGE!!! So worth it for the price! I am the PICKIEST person with my scallion pancakes; I usually judge a restaurant by their scallion pancakes. THEY WERE SO CRISPY AND HOT AND FRESH AND THIN!! If you've truly tried scallion pancakes in Taiwan, you would know that it should NEVER be doughy, and have very little scallions. Joe's Shanghai NAILED it! Even my friend, who only eats american-chinese food, fell in love with it and made me promise to bring him back here to have some more. The sesame noodle was alright; they did well with the sauce but the noodle was too thick. The portions for soup dumplings, fried rice, and sesame chicken were HUGE!!!! Perfect, if not, a bit too much (which is never bad). LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!!!!!!
Seven fat fish swim in a tank near the entrance to the restaurant. I am convinced that the souls of the waitstaff live exclusively inside of these fish.
Excellent option for this cuisine! A star cleanliness rating. Best scallion pancakes I've ever had. The pork soup dumplings were fantastic too. On top of it all, friendly service.

Order only the xiaolong bao, the scallion pancake, the chinese ravioli with soup and fried quail. Especially the friend quail, it is so good that I went back the other day and bought 5 as snacks. Good spot for brunch but the wait is about 30 minutes to 1 hour when they are busy. The one in flushing has better Xiaolong bao but the location of this store can't be beat. Â Also, be prepared to share a table with strangers because they mostly use roundtables.
No comment
Super affordable and tasty Â one of the best, if not the best place for soup dumplings. The staff are nice as well.
Very good place. Ordered takeout and drove to NJ. Food was still warm and quite tasty. We ordered Sesame Chicken, General Tsos, and spring rolls. All were quite good.
Shanghai dumplings were great. This place gets packed from what I read but it wasn't bad at all mid afternoon.

Arguably the worst service and attitude of any place I've ever been. Visiting from out of town and this is usually one of our stops. But after eating there Saturday afternoon my wife and I both said WHY do we come back ? We'll never be back. The food is mediocre at best ! And the service is atrocious. Â It's hurry up eat and get the FUCK out is there mentality. And it's cash only, can u say we're screwing the IRS ! Do yourself a favor and try some other place we definitely will on our next visit to NY.

The crab and pork soup dumpling is really as good as everyone says. Full of soupy goodness and they don't skimp on the crab either. Although I did notice during a recent visit that they skimped on the ginger in the soy sauce dip. The eggplant with pork dish is also delicious. Don't come here if you're on a diet.

As good as it gets! What a wonderful place. Every time I am in downtown Manhattan, I make a point of going there. Best nights are always Monday & Tuesday nights, because the communal tables aren't as crowded & there isn't a line around the corner to get in. Highly recommend the soup dumplings. Delicious & masterfully prepared. The ambiance is exactly what you would expect in Chinatown, with quick service and authentic cuisine. Truly a savory experience.

This review is really for the XLB. No place on the west coast comes close to this. Definitely worth the wait, if there is one. After eating here, any other restaurant that serves XLB just doesn't even come close in taste, with the exception of Din Tai Fung.
I love Chinese food, and I consider this the best place in the city to get it. And their soup dumplings are the best! Just like the ones I had in China.

At Joe's it's all about the food. Â We had the soup dumplings, a first, different. Â I didn't love them but my husband did. Â He ordered Kung pow chicken which was incredible, my son ordered sesame chicken, unbelievably good & my daughter & I shared fried noodles with veggies. Â The noodles were pretty greasy but I've never had that dish so perhaps that's normal. Â Often the quality of chicken in these restaurants is not the best, at Joes it was tender and not chewy. Â We had to wait awhile for a table, it's an attraction, but well worth the wait. Â Highly recommend!
I had lunch yesterday while on a break from jury duty. The dumplings were excellent. I would definitely like to come back for Â dinner when I have ore time and can try more things.
Famous for their dumplings however only 2 kinds served. Bad service as well. Left without ordering.
My boss and I both got sick. Terrible atmosphere and service.
No comment

I love Joe's Shanghai!!! their Xiao Long Bao are the best ever!!! I order the soup dumplings every time I go. The food is usually pretty good (last time I went, it wasn't too good) but overall, this place is great for tasty, greasy chinese food.
The xiao long bao was the bomb dot com and the broccoli and beef is the best i have ever tasted. Also, Be on a look out, when your looking for Joe's Shanghai(a little to find it)
No comment

This was not the same Joe's Shanghai experience I had when I went there ten years ago. The dumplings aren't as fresh, the meat inside is typical take out mystery meat, and the broth inside is now greasy where it was once fresh and brothy. I was very disappointed. I was ready for a one of a kind experience and got something more along the lines of Â  Â a better than average Chinese take out experience

Felt like i was back in China, the menu was quite diverse and of course we had to order the soup dumplings. Â  If your timid about sitting with strangers you may want to come in a larger group cause this place is so busy. Â Definitely worth going if your in the area.

I usually avoid touristy places but this place was too good to ignore, delicious, and it reminds me of my grandmother's cooking. If you're visiting New York City , this is a must go. P.S the Soup dumplings are the main focus , it should be the first thing you order there

I have really got to say, Â they are the best with their Xiao long bao (steam pork soup bun). Haven't really find a place better then then. Â They are good and consistent. Â A lot of place they are good for a while then.... our sometime good and sometime bad but Joe shanghai been keeping their pork bun delicious. Â Love it.

Had to wait to get seated, took 25 minutes. The restaurant was crowded, loud and crazy. Seating is family style with a lazy susan on the table. Food was pretty good. The highlights were the pork soup dumplings, the turnip buns, jellyfish and fried quail. Place only takes cash and prices are good.
No comment

BOMB. Like... the best asian food I have ever had. Â Soul dumplings, scallion pancakes, shanghai noodles and some beef dish - all insane. Everything they brought out looked amazing too, the fried chicken, all the typical chinese dishes (sesame chicken, chilli chicken, etc) and this full fish dish that looked and smelled incredible. Quickly turned into one of our favorite spots in the city!

So this place is known for its pork soup dumplings. They are definitely yummy. I would go back for that but not for much else really. There is a line and they dont tell you they will sit you with strangers. So if you're expecting to be just seated with your party of four prepare to have guests. The noise level is high and the atmosphere is like that of a frat house with mostly young people from out of state. The people who are in the know take their stuff to go. I will do the same in the future.

Oh Yelp, you led me astray with this one. Best dim sum? Really?! I mean, the food wasn't horrible, but let's not get crazy. It was good enough (especially the scallion pancakes) but the waitstaff was completely indifferent bordering on rude. My friend and I were seated at a larger table ("You sit over here! And you sit there!") and had a stranger join later, which was kind of awkward. We were given menus, but never offered drinks beyond the standard tea. Food came fast but nobody really cared whether we liked it or not. Seems like staff was more preoccupied with getting us served and out the door as fast as possible. They also add service fee to all orders but then make it look like tipping is still needed. And CASH ONLY? What is this?! Anyways, this place definitely doesn't deserve all the rave it gets. Skip.
Scallion pancakes were the bomb. Soup dumplings was good but the broth inside was a little too heavy. Crab greater than pork dumplings
No comment

Chose this place as it was the only place in Chinatown with over 4,000 reviews and four starts. Â Nothing special but nothing bad so it does not deserve four stars, just average Chinese-style fast food. Â Very busy and you will wait (even if you get there early) and it's communcal seating. Â The place is very busy so it's production style: order, get your food, eat it and that's it. Â Servers are friendly but hurried.
They still have it. I used to come here monthly about 15 years ago. I finally came back and it was so worth it. Â THE BEST DUMPLINGS HANDS DOWN!!!!!!!!!!
No comment
Tourist trap! Don't go, especially if you are vegetarian. They pre-added a service charge on our bill, even with 2 people. Food was mediocre at best.

Everyone loves Joe's. This is a soup dumpling place, but I though the Gen CHWS was better. It may be me but soup dumplings smell like my grandmothers freezer. Not the one in the house the one in the garage. I'd say go or order In if you like soup dumplings.

This place is a favorite, but lately the juice buns have been a little overcooked and burst before I get them. The ambience is cheap and cheerful, and you often get seated with other people, but it's part of the fun. I wish they would go back to making the juice buns better. Their handmade sauteed noodles are delicious. Staff is OK, not superfriendly, but they get the job done.

Soup dumplings were just okay... Some had absolute no soup some had... The reason why I gave them 1 star is because the waiters were absolutely obnoxious. Can not believe how rude they were. Would not comeback here again.
No comment
No comment

The worst service ever. The hostess skipped our group having us wait for over an hour. After confronting and asking, she continued to ignore our party until I spoke to the manager. We also sat at the table with random strangers already eating. The odor in the Restaurant smells atrocious. I would never recommend or return.
Best dumplings around! And all the dishes were excellent too. Somewhat of a wait but definitely worth it!!

5 Stars for the Soup Dumplings! 3 stars for the ambiance / service. It's crowded, you have to share tables, and the service is rushed since they are trying to move people along quickly. Great deal. Worth it. Go... right now.

haha! the wait here is ridic!!!!!!!! This place is more for tourist and white people. It can be an hour wait at times. But their soup dumplings is the best. What I don't like is, that sometimes they try to force to leave as quickly as possible so they can sit another party down. I remember having to share a table with other strangers. I did not like that.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
Very good! Went there last week for the first time and the dumplings were my favorite part of the meal.
Best soup dumpling place in china town for sure. the place is always crowded. i went there last sunday, the wait was like almost an hour but it was definitely worth. going back again!

So overrated, so full of tourists, so cramped. Asked for a table for 2. Saw 2 seats clearly available near the front and asked if those two pointing to the seats were ready. The hostess said we have to see... But then was told to go to the back. Ended up sharing a huge round table with 2 other families. Awkward and cramped. The soup dumplings were fine nothing special. The meat sauce noodles were fine but the noodles were too mushy. As we left I saw that the table that was available ended up being given to two white tourists. Interesting seeing as they don't take reservations those seats could not be reserved. I also asked for ice water 3 times because it was boiling hot in there but didnt get it until the end of our meal. Will not be returning to this restaurant.
No comment

I have to say this restaurant is like a piece of shit. The only star is for onion pancake and fried rice. Three people spent 80 bucks on lunch but what we felt is eat 20 bucks food. The other food can be directly dropped in the rubbish bin.

So, after viewing on yelp how highly recommended this dim sum restaurant was, we made it priority to go while visiting NYC.. I was expecting all the dim sum appetizer dishes to be great; but they were really nothing special.. Their dumplings were definitely delicious as well as their scallion pancakes.

So I've heard a lot of hype about this restaurant, but it was a pretty unimpressive experience for me. The soup dumplings were great, but the two other dishes my friend and I ordered were nothing special at all. One of the dishes we ended up barely touching, and neither of us were interested in bringing it home and eating later. I've had better Chinese food in plenty of other places. Also, the service was really mediocre. I never got the glass of water I asked for at the beginning, and I felt like the waiters were giving us attitude. I would give one star, but the soup dumplings were good, so two-stars.

I have been here twice 1st time I was here without the kids and thought food was ok and I would have rated it 3 stars. Noting over the top family style dining sharing Â table with strangers. Service was also just ok. 2nd time we stopped by with my kids and let me tell u service was just horrible. This is my 1st bad review at Yelp. I don't like giving bad reviews but this deserves a bad review. 1st the waiter was not polite at all, he was not trying to hep with menu and really not accommodating. We needed plates, juices for kids he left for good 5 10 min we had to ask another waiter for help. Then the waiter kept taking to the people next to us the whole time in Chinese laughing and just chatting away. At one point he was kept passing my by my chair and rubbing against my back without saying anything.. I had to tell him to stop rubbing against my back every minute. He wasn't passes dishes or anything he Â just kept talking to the people at the table not paying attention to us. We didn't feel comfortable at all. I told him straight up that he sucked and to stop rubbing against me, and then I spoke to the manager how horrible service was but nothing was done about it, just apologized. I will never go back no matter how good these saggy dumplings are!!

If anyone thinks this place has good soup dumplings is a sucker and probably a tourist. Â Absolutely the worst experience. Â Our soup dumplings were sloppily made, had no soup inside them, and sat on a bed of shriveled up cabbage that was so disgusting. Â We got up and left. Â Pile on top of that the overpriceing, the line out the door, and you have yourself a classic tourist trap. Â Don't go here.
Completely average, nothing to rave about and certainly not worth the newly found long waits due to yelp overhype. The soups dumplings are good but not worth waiting for.
Very authentic Shanghainese food! We sampled both types of Xiao Long Bao and the pan seared dumplings. Very delicious and authentic. Nicely done!

Best soup dumplings in china townï¼ Just had lunch there, have to say it was the best soup dumplings i have ever had. if you looking to try some soup dumplings in china town this is the place you want go.

I've been here twice and I honestly don't understand why it has such high ratings. The xiao long bao soup dumplings are ok, but definitely not the best I've ever had, and the rest of the food is just ok. There's almost always a wait, and you have to share a table with other people, which can be really awkward. The wait staff isn't particularly accommodating and overall it's just not really a great experience. Will not be back.
Food was mediocre at best and the sitting arrangement was terrible. The soup dumplings there was nothing special, if not below average, imo.

We came here because of many recommendations from friends who live in the city. Coming from Toronto, I guess I'm pretty spoiled in terms of authentic chinese food. I found the dumplings are very delicious and well done. We felt rushed though. The waiter basically was hurrying us along to order then threw us the bill the moment we finished eating. It was a bit unpleasant. Not sure if I will ever come back here again when I visit NYC

I don't care if it's not as authentic as some other places in Chinatown. Â It's jaw-droppingly delicious. It's hot. It's spicy. It's served with rice. Â The green beans are sauteed with bits of pickled mustard and pork. Â The soup dumplings are just right. Â And that's enough for 5 stars from me.

Love love love the pork soup dumplings and the salt and pepper shrimp! I came here on a Monday around lunch time with some girlfriends and luckily we beat the lunch crowd that were waiting in line for a good minute. I heard it gets really crowded and is usually a long wait on most days so I'm really glad we lucked out and were seated right away.The service was very efficient and the food was delicious, I will definitely be back!
Amazing amazing soup dumplings. The pan fried noodles was very good as well. We had a little awkward situation while sharing the table but the manager was very sweet and put us at another table.

Went there last night upon recommendation from a local! Very good chicken fried rice and General Tso's chicken. Nothing fancy about service but turnover is the game and they get 'em in & get 'em out!!! Well worth the visit!!!

Over-hyped. Rude staff. Soup dumplings quite ordinary. I wish my friend who referred me had told me about the awkward community dining on circular tables. Unless you' have an inside scoop or can talk to the staff, don't bother. It was a wasted meal experience.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Two words. Soup Dumplings. Best I have ever had. Pan fried noodles are also really good and crispy if I have enough room for them after the dumplings. The place has been packed every time I have been in, its family style seating so there have been times when I have gone in by myself and got sat at a table with 8 other people I dont know, but I think that just adds to the atmosphere.

Rude tourist trap. Dont get your own table. You have to share it. Treated like cattle. Food fair at best. Reminded me of frozen chinese food So many better places around, trick you too with an extra service charge. Nasty staff too. Go to Wo Hop or others around. This is bad. Yelp steered me wrong. Must be tourists leaving reviews. Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Only a B ratng...

I've been going to this place for years and it's still consistently good. I always get the crab soup dumplings and the crispy beef and am never disappointed! Everything is relatively affordable and it's nice to get a taste of China a short subway ride away.

I went there with my friends to eat late lunch :) we didn't have to wait and could get in soon! That was the nicest point because usually we have wait !! There are two å°ç± å but I recommend you to choose meat with crub ! That one is better! Make sure when you eat, use spoon ! Because there are a lot of soup in å°ç± åï¼and it's the most delicious part !!

Amazing soup dumplings, terrible service. Was seated at a table with 7 other strangers (talk about awkward!) and the waiter was practically shouting at me. He also would clear our plates without asking or before we were even finished.
I only come here for the pork soup dumplings. Everyone should definitely start with that as an appetizer or even as your meal.

column3: Avenue of the Arts South, Philadelphia, PA
column6: Good food but relatively slow service and hurried at the beginning which made it hard. Good duck though and cheap wine!

The best soup dumplings ever!! A must go when in Chinatown NYC!!! But it can get packed so you will most likely sit next to random people!! But by the time you taste the dumpling... You'll forget your name.!!
Food is pretty good, the sea bass is really fresh and shrimp dumpling was very good. but super crowded at lunch time and cramped space and noisy.

The hype this restaurant joys and the long wait outside are not reflective of the overall quality of the food. The dumplings were "good", not great. The duck was tasteless . Sesame noodles definitely had peanut butter added which is a no-no. Service was quite good. Best bet in Chinatown is to poke around and see where the locals are eating and avoid the touristy places such as this. We live in San Francisco and we follow our own advice!
No comment

Delicious food! Fast service! Well priced! Â At a non standard meal time the restaurant was full when (with lots of locals as well as tourists) every other restaurant within 5 blocks had no more then 3 tables. One thing to note is it is cash only, and a little hard to find.
No comment
short wait and the staff was friendly. After a very hectic day, we ordered dumplings and two entrees. The chicken was really good and generous portions.

The xiao long bao is really the only thing you should get here, and maybe the nian gao. Definitely one of the best xiao long bao I've had, dare I say as good as ones in Shanghai? As good as that was, I was so confused by the dumplings here. The skin was so thick and chewy, and the filling was not even that good. Those were so disappointing that we didn't even finish them. I would just stick to first two and you're set.

After heading to Chinatown and my wife telling me "NOT A CHANCE" at another place higher rated because of how it looked, we found this gem. Â Bit on the pricy side but well worth it. Â There was a bit of a wait but once again well worth it. Â My kids absolutely loved it and they are 6. that says something. Â They even gave all our chopstick incapable, everyone but me a chopstick holder. The dumplings were awesome and the General Chicken was perfect. Â highly recommend
The wait is insane for this kind of food. Â I don't understand what the hype is about. Â Service is rude and I can get better dumplings and noodles at East Dumpling.

Some of the best Chinese food I've had in a long time. Worth the 40 minute wait on a Sunday night. I had been dying for decent scallion pancakes for ages, and these did not disappoint. 5 people, after tip, $82. We had sesame chicken, szechuan beef, and shrimp lo mein, along with a bunch of appys. A must try!

Would really recommend you go try the Pork dumplings - around 6 bucks (8 pc), it was very good, and be sure to ask the staff how to eat it properly. I would say they are ok for the other dishes. Definitely try Pork dumplings out!!!
No comment
No comment
Fantastic soup dumplings, and really cheap! We (party of two) got lucky and happened to get seated in about fifteen minutes.
No comment
Reasonable price & the soup dumpling is extremely fresh. If you come here around 10PM, the line is really not bad at all.

The food is good but service is very poor. I liked the pan fried noodles, the buns, dumplings, and vegetable dishes. The dishes were surprisingly fresh and tasty. There were six of us but we were still expected to share a table when the lunch rush was over. Go because of the chef, but anticipate rude service.
Best soup dumpling of the city. Â I love the ones with crab meats.

I worked in Shanghai about one year. Joe's Shanghai has the similar food. I have to say it is real Shanghaine food. Kind of sweet. Some of my friends are fans of this. So I came here several times since the first try. Cons: Limited space. Not clean enough. Kind of noisy. Sometimes you need to wait.
No comment
The soup dumpling caught us by surprize! Â Excellent dim-sum, as recommended by our friend Joy. Â Would come again. Â Yummy

This place is known for xiaolong bao, of course. I visited 10 years ago and this is the second time. You'll leave this place full and not at all disappointed especially if you have enough of crab meat xiao long bao. Xiao long bao here is bigger than those at other restaurants, much bigger with lots of juice/soup inside. I'd give a 5 star if i'm only rating the dumplings. Other dishes weren't amazing but were decent - I tried the typical Shanghai dishes such as fish tail. Again, pretty good. Be ware of the super long wait though!

Arrived here and waited about 15 minutes to be seated. The seating is shared so you are sitting with a bunch of people you don't know. We actually liked this set-up a lot, it was unique. We started off with the soup dumplings which were delicious and then ordered the chicken and shrimp in plum sauce which was also very good. The service was so-so in regards to friendliness, but it was busy and crowded so I will give them the benefit of the doubt. Decent prices and great food. Two thumbs up.
No comment

Hand down the best xiao long bao I've never had. I'm willing to wait in line for this place. But it's super small and the tables are crammed against each other. The meat inside is decent sized. The dough isn't too thick to chew and not too thin where it'll pop when you pick it up.
No comment
No comment
No comment
One of the best authentic NYC Chinatown dining experiences you can get. Huge banquet style tables make this a fun place to go with a group of friends. Two words: SOUP DUMPLINGS!!

Their scallion pancakes are the best ! I really dislike that so many people have overrated this place. I don't have a thing for their soup dumplings. I think the soup inside is a bit too thick. But otherwise, this shanghai restaurant is pretty good. Wouldn't come here with friends because the wait for a table is forever haha.
Xia long bao blows Din Tai Fung's outa the water... hands down! Minus one star for rude service.
No comment
No comment
No comment

I LOVE their pork soup dumplings. A must experience for all the friends who come to visit me in the city. Also try the Sesame Chicken and the scallion pancake. Service is only OK but the food is worth it.

This place does not deserve 4 stars. Â I will never understand why people are waiting outside of this place, although that's exactly why I wanted to try it on a weekday afternoon. Â Complete waste of money and room in my stomach. Â We ordered cold sesame noodles and black mushrooms with bamboo shoots. Â The cold sesame noodles were so disgusting, we couldn't make ourselves eat them. Â If the staff hadn't seemed so rude (except for the very friendly lady at the front who finds you a table) I would have tried to talk to them about not paying for the noodles. Â It was like peanut butter on top of overcooked cheap spaghetti. Â They didn't taste like sesame and they didn't taste like any noodles I had before anywhere - they dissolved into a thick glue substance in my mouth. Â Maybe no one orders this dish and they found a pot of cooked noodles from last week laying around. Â The mushroom dish was maybe a 2 or 3 star rating, but left a strong cornstarch taste in my mouth. Â They didn't ask if we wanted rice (some places include it, some don't, but they usually suggest to order rice or ask you. Â Our waiter said nothing to us the entire time). Â The tea tasted weird. Â And they charge you a tip automatically! Â They also took our money before we were ready. Â I would never ever go here again, when there are SO MANY restaurants in the area and even the so-so ones are 1 million times better than Joe's Shanghai.
No comment
No comment

Still a tourist trap... Â After a few months, I gave this place another try. A Sunday lunch with friends and family turned out to be a disappointing luncheon. The pork soup dumplings, fried stripe bass, shanghai noodles were tasty but nothing to rave about. The service provided by the hostess and waiters need a lot to be desired. They need courtesy lessons. if you need a waiter, keep waving your hands. If all the members in your party are not waiting with you, you will lose your table Â asap and you'll be ignored and expect to wait another 15-20 minutes, OUTSIDE. As for the bill, there is a 15% mandatory taxable tip-ALL USD CASH ONLY. Just a note, you will share a table with other diners at the table. Go elsewhere. Try 456 Restaurant that's only a few blocks away.The atmosphere and waiters are more respectful and courteous.
No comment

THE BEST PORK DUMPLINGS IN THE WORLD!! Steamy and soupy when you bite into it, so you must eat it with a soup spoon! That's all you have to order there. That's all I remember eating there even though I'm sure we ordered a lot of other things. It's always packed and you have to share a table unless your group is perfectly a party of 10. This place is on the map for a reason! We still dream about it!!
Awesome dumplings. Â One of the 1st places I hit straight outta LGA/JFK. Â Not giving it 5 stars only b/c I just KNOW there's still better out there, I just gotta find it.
No comment

So my boyfriend had been raving about this place for so long before actually coming here, and we finally had the chance to come here during a trip to New York with a buddy.. Although the food was okay, the customer service was absolutely horrible. We each ordered one order of dumplings each and after waiting about 30-45 for our food and seeing multiple people around us who came in after got their food before us we finally decided to ask them about our food. My boyfriend then asks our waiter about our order and our waiter is completely rude and just says wait, nothing else. We keep waiting and waiting then after five mins ask someone else and this person just flat us ignores us, then we finally ask this girl at the counter for a manager and eventually get our food and they still forget one of our orders. This place might be great to some but my first impression after hearing so many good things about their food and coming from California absolutely sucked. Maybe they think because they already have so many good reviews they don't need to keep up with their appearance, but they should also realize people from all over the country visit New York and "hot spots" in New York and they should treat every one of their customers with respect, especially if they can't even get an A (they had a B rating). They also include the tip in your tab, so more of a reason to give you really bad quality customer service because there's no way I would've tipped this waiter.

I've been coming to this Joe's for I can't believe it 18 years I was part of the brave crew that discovered this place and I have brought countless people here. Well today was my last visit. After dutifully waiting an hour longest wait ever I walked up to the door hostess and she the wait would be 45 more minutes unless I pay $20. Ugh!!! I would have been happy to pay for a table when I got there before waiting, but now I've got a kid and a couple of seniors waiting isn't an option any longer so we needed to sit so I paid ten dollars got a table and had a very late lunch. But as a result will never return. And I will now share this story with the Hundred people I shared this place with.

Good lord, this place is delicious and crowded because you can't get a good "siu lohng bao" (soup dumpling) in Chicago, that's for sure! Â I don't care for the crab ones, they taste a little funny, kind of like old egg yolk. Â Go for the meat! Â I also love the Shanghai noodles, which are thicker and shorter than udon and slightly wavy. Â It is mixed with vegetables (cabbage?) and pork. Â There's another location in Flushing, Queens, and they are both equally great!

I love these soup dumplings. When I used to live near the financial district, I would stop by here for lunch with my roommates. I have never been disappointed here. The only thing is the restaurant can be a little messy but it is still cleaner than most of the other Chinatown restaurants.
No comment

The food was delicious, while the place wasn't very pleasing on the eyes, it's typical Chinatown eatery if you're looking for an affordable spot. General Tso's chicken was some of the best I've ever had and their fried rice is slightly above Par. I would recommend this place and would return if I found myself in this area again looking for a quick bite (service was quick and friendly).
No comment

Bottom line first: The hype is not worth the wait, price, nor abuse. Â Food was only so so. Since they write in a standard 15% tip, no matter the party size, they have no problem treating customers like crap. And they do. Looking at the crowd, this place got it's high ratings from Band-Wagon Zombie high star Yelpers.

The major draw here are the deceptively-named steamed buns, which are onion-shaped dumplings filled with either pork or crab and a hot broth. There's a special technique to eating them - place one on your spoon, nibble a small hole on top, carefully sip the soup until it's drained fully, then bite into the doughy goodness. Everything else on the menu, much of which - like jellyfish, fish head casserole, and raw crabs - is foreign to Western palates, pales in comparison, and most of it requires an adventurous spirit to try and a strong stomach to tolerate.
No comment

Apart from it's very "UN-romantic" seating, The food is exquisite. Â AUTHENTIC CHINESE FOOD done right. Generous serving amount and totally Affordable. You'd have to mind the wait (at times). Just don't get upset. It's Chinatown!
No comment

Some of my friend's coworkers put our names on the list way before we arrived so the total wait for a table on a sunday afternoon was about an hour. But, the food was worth the wait. The soup dumpings were phenomenal. We had the crab and pork soup dumpings and I think 5 of us put away 90-100 of them. They also come at a very affordable price of $5 for every 8 dumpings. I would avoid the "americanized" items such as the sesame chicken as they can be pretty pricey, although of good quality as well. Nevertheless, the best restaurant I have been to in new york to date...at my budget.
No comment
A disappointment. The soup dumplings weren't as good as ones I've had at other places for cheaper prices. Also had the kung pao chicken which was subpar at best.
Best Chinese. Best xia long bao! Must try when you visit China town in NYC. Shanghai fried noodle and fried rice are also good. Love everything I had here.
No comment

The hot & sour soup is smooth and sharp and simply wonderful. Pork dumplings, fried or steamed: very good. Â But it was the prawns with a snazzy chili sauce that really made me say, hey that was a nice taste sensation. Bravo! The service is pleasant and very talented, too.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Best place for crab meat soup dumplings in NYC hands down. I don't think anywhere can beat the taste of the meat and soup anywhere else. Price wise is very reasonable. Been coming here for 10 years and there still isn't anywhere better for soup dumplings. Other food is so-so though.
Ja Jang Mien, xiao long bao, and chung yao bang oh my!!! Â This place rocks! Â Great value and tasty food, you can't go wrong here.
No comment

OK Shanghainese food. Got better quality in Shanghai Cafe on Mott St. instead. This place has gotten too touristy. Most people that come here are not Chinese. We had to share a table, got so-so Shanghainese food, & got slapped with an automatic (not optional) 15% gratuity fee on the bill. There was only 3 of us!!! Like I said tourist rip-off!
Wow, everything was delicious! Highly recommend the soup dumplings and, well, everything!

Okay shanghai dumplings. This place has great reviews and was referred by a friend while I'm visiting NYC. I don't know if I would get in line for this place. (We didn't have much of a wait during lunchtime on a weekend.) I had much better dumplings in ding tai fung and other shanghai places.
I don't really care if the soup dumplings are famous or not.. my aunt and uncle took me there and after a bit of crab soup dumplings, I'm thinking, "damn, why don't other places make this?!"
Serve super fantastic xiaolongbao (dumpling). The place isn't that big so if your party is 1-3, you might share the table with others

Can you say soup dumplings? Pretty much the most well known soup dumpling place in Chinatown - and the recognition is well deserved! Very good food. Usually a wait.. expect to share tables. And as with all Chinatown joints, curt, quick and loud service, cheap cheap cheap, and overall propensity to over-order.
No comment
Out of this world dumplings. Â And I would stick with just the dumplings as the other items are mediocre American versions of Chinese food.

i feel in love this vegetarian plate instead of the dumplings. I don't know what it is called in english because my chinese friends ordered it for me; "ku foo." so tasty, sweet and juicy sorta like tofu.
No comment
The dumplings were great but the service was very slow. They place needs to expand to handle all the customers. The food also felt very rushed since they are trying to just get customers in and out.

Love the food but hate the staff. My favorites are the soup dumplings. The staff however can be really mean. They will literally yell at you, roll there eyes and walk away shaking their heads if you ask them for anything.

I do love their soup dumplings, but the rest of the food, e.g. the scallion pancakes, is oily and about the quality you'd get at another decent Chinese place nearby. The food is cheap, the service is fast and efficient. The community seating can be a bit disorienting, the cash-only policy annoying, and the wait time ridiculous. All in all, there are better places to go - try Xi'an Famous Foods around the corner, followed by dessert at Chinatown Ice Cream Factory.

column3: North Beach/Telegraph Hill, San Francisco, CA
column6: If you want to have your dinner with a stranger at the same table, you can come here. Besides, there's one waiter's attitude is really poor. He seems wants to beat me when I asked him question coz the space is too loud. Furthermore, each dish here is a bit sweet except the xiao long bao.

Decent, but overrated. I came for the famed xialongboa (steamed pork buns), which were just OK. While they were juicy, the juice was more fatty than "brothy" - and in several bites, they tasted like nothing but fat! Service was friendly, though, and the Singapore mai fun was fine. I'd consider returning with out-of-town friends - the restaurant was packed with tourists! - but I can't imagine Joe's satisfying any of my (semi-frequent) xialongboa cravings.
I really liked the soup dumplings. It's just waaay too crowded though. I would definitely go back to try other things but I want me some soup dumplings again =)

Yum soup dumplings! Based on other reviews, we stuck to the XLB -- and they were top notch. We did have to wait about 20 minutes (at 1:00), but it was worth it. Dumplings with crab was our favorite. Big portions for a reasonable price.

Their soup dumplings are incredible.... Excellent flavor and filling. I always bring friends here when they visit. Its a must try. The only thing I don't agree on is the 18% service charge even for party of 2.

I'm Chinese and i love really authentic Chinese food, this place really disappointed me. We came back to this place after many many years to check if it's still good and turns out there was not a single Chinese customer when we were there (bad sign). And we had to wait in line for more than an hour. Â  Ambience was bad, we had to share a table and the food did not even meet our expectations. Many many more authentic Chinese food in the city.
Very simple, go for the dumplings. Â Everything else is good, but your standard Chinese restaurant offering, the dumplings, excellent!

I can't believe how much I loved this place. Yeah, it doesn't look like the nicest place in the world and you might sit with a bunch of strangers, but all that considered I can't wait to go back. I'm in NYC for 2 more days and want to eat these dumplings for every meal.
Soup dumplings...the best thing to get in Chinatown. If you go to NYC, get soup dumplings.

Don't know what's the big deal with this place. Â Had to wait 45 minutes to sit. Â Their bathroom is an absolute war zone. Â It's so disgusting. Â One of my requirements for a restaurant is to have. Spotless bathroom. Â  This place was so dirty I felt like I had to go disinfect my whole body. Â The soup dumplings everyone raves about were so whatever. Â The Chinese food we ordered was a little on the pricier side of other establishments in Chinatown. Â When it came to pay the bill, I didn't realize it was cash only and pulled out a cc. Â They ran over like a swarm of bees and started yelling cSh only cash only. Â  Gottttttt it buddy. Â Heard you the first time. Â They were swarming around us like cockroaches. Â Prolly cuz they have many cockroaches in the kitchen. Â It is so dirty in there. When I was leaving. Â The waiter started saying something directly to my face in passing. Â Grrrrrr. I know what you said
No comment
No comment
I go alone so I can stuff as many motherloving soup dumplings my body cavity can hold without being judged by the people I love.
No comment
No comment
No comment

My favorite place to get soup dumplings! This place is worth the trip. Always a little packed and it feels like I'm being rushed to finish my food but the dumplings are incredible. Their other dishes are pretty good but no different than any other Chinese restaurant. The dumplings, on the other hand, are the best I've had. I love the crab and pork ones.
No comment

I've been there with my girlfriend a few times now. I think it is a very approachable option for nicer/more authentic Asian food. Their soup dumplings are a must get. I've also had chicken with garlic sauce and some items off of their specials menu and they were all very good. Great food at an affordable price. Can be crowded sometimes so make a reservation if possible.
No comment
The soup dumplings, scallion pancake, general Taos chicken are delicious and a MUST when you visit this restaurant. You may have to wait to be seated, but it is well worth the wait!!

Cute little place tucked away in a corner of Chinatown. Â Soup dumplings -great as advertised. We tried the pork and the crab dumplings. I preferred the pork actually even though they were a couple dollars cheaper. The waiter was no nonsense and all business but that didn't detract from the fact that the food is simply really good Chinese food. And I'm from Vancouver the mecca of Chinese restaurants outside of China itself. Â Also try the pork fried rice, the pan fried rice noodles with beef (they were crunchy which I usually dont like but they were really surprisingly good that way), and the eggplant dish. Â I rolled out of there only a few dollars lighter as prices were quite good. Recommend!!!

The food definitely wasnt bad but all the buzz about it is uncalled for. The xiao long bao was alright, and the same goes for the beef tendon and their house chilli. I'd head to shanghai asian manor over it any time.

Delicious soup dumplings and affordable food. This place is always packed and it's better to go for 3 ppl and under. You have to share tables with strangers and it's loud in there. My husband and I just go in, get the crab dumplings, jellyfish and shrimp fried rice and leave right after we finish eating. They serve the food rather quickly. Not a fan of their fried noodles.
No comment

best chinese in nyc. Â understated and imitated but never outdone. Â the best in dim sung and the snow peas shhots were to die for. Â overall a great experience. Â server was not the best in english but this is part of the culture.

The soup dumplings are amazing. The last time I was there, they weren't that soupy but still were delicious. The general tso's chicken was really good as well. The chicken was cooked well, and it was real chicken unlike most chinese places you go to. The sauce was a bit sweet, but that is the way I like it.
The best xiao long bao in the city! A trip to NYC won't be complete without a visit to Joe Shanghai.

I'm not going to lie to you, I haven't been super impressed by Joe's Shanghai. Â Everyone raves about the dumplings and while they're good they didn't really change my life. Â Everything else I ordered was pretty forgettable. Â And frankly the dumplings probably would have been too if it weren't for the extreme caution required to eat them. Â With respect to that, by the way, I suggest picking one up in the spoon provided, breaking it open and sipping out the juice like hot tea first and then as it becomes suitably cooled eat the actual dumpling. Perhaps add a little sauce if you're into that sort of thing. Â The Family style seating is kind of cool if you are sat next to interesting people but it can suck if your table mates are obnoxious (aka tourists).
soup dumplings. done. Â here are some more words so that yelp will let me post this review.
No comment

Best XLB that I have ever tasted in my life! Not that I have tasted that many....but still...it's the best! I went to the Midtown/Manhattan location a couple of weeks ago during a bachelorette party weekend. The crab/pork dumplings were rich, flavorful, and addicting. I really did not understand why people liked xiao long bao's until I tried Joe's Shanghai. I wish they would open up a location in the bay area.
No comment

wow! Every time I'm in NYC I make sure to eat here. The steamed pork buns are fantastic and is a must order (if your a ginger fan make sure you order extra). I also recommend the fried rice and scallion pancakes. I warn you CASH ONLY!! except a wait. Enjoy
Good soup dumplings. There is long lines. You need to go either before 11am or after 2 pm if you don't want to wait.

I used to be a frequent flyer here, I would just stop in and have an order of the soup dumplings. Lately I've noticed the skin has become thicker and it's just not the same... I don't recommend that you get any other dish here, they're standard Chinese take out items.
No comment

I would give 4.5 stars if I could, but I rounded up. 5 stars for amazing food. Soup dumplings, obviously, and doughy noodles and mapo tofu! This is one of my favorite chinese places in Manhattan. The .5 star deduction would be for the inconvenience of it all. I've never not had to wait at least 20 minutes, and they take cash only. But generally, an extremely solid chinese food place. I took my (Chinese) mother here when she visited, and she loved it. I brought my friends here when they visited, they loved it. It's a pleaser. Plain and simple. Cool, but kind of inconveniently placed fish right in front of the entrance. Must be a feng shui thing.
No comment

Finally came here last night after hearing from a friend that this "was the best place in Chinatown." We ordered the famous soup dumplings (the crab and meat combo kind) and when they arrived one of the waiters showed us how to eat them (open them with the utensil, pour the soup into the spoon, add soy sauce to the spoon and the dumpling). It's $8.50 with tax included for 6 or 8 dumplings. The tea on the table was very good too. Didn't try any other dishes but it all looked yummy - if not as cheap as other places in the area.
No comment
No comment

We came here with our NY native cousins, Sophia and Vivian, for lunch during our summer vacation. OH MY GOD!!! Â Dumplings are delicious! Â Our 3 kids couldnt get enough. Â We must of gone through 6 or 7 trays of dumplings. Â Our 9 year old daughter (picky eater) was scooping the drippings from her plate! Â We also had the crispy deep fried noodles, that was very good as well. This place gets packed! Â So make sure you get there early!

Recommended by a friend, this is a hot spot for fantastic Chinese cuisine! You usually know you're in a great restaurant when there's a wait (not too long) to be seated on a Sunday night. Â The service was great and the food was exceptionally fresh and flavorful. The portions are fairly large. You might considering sharing 4-5 plates for a party of 6. We enjoyed several plates including beef, pork, and chicken. What I was most impressed by was that the chicken actually tasted like chicken. Overall, I enjoyed every last morsel and would highly recommend Joe's Shanghai.
So good!!!! Try something new and unsusal, its really worth it!

Me and my friend stumbled on this place while walking through chinatown. Definitely one of the best Chinese restaurants I've ever been to. Be sure to get the dumplings, they're amazing and really cheap.
Absolutely incredible xiaolongbao!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Can't say anything better about it. Even better than those in China!
I set up an account to give this restaurant 5 star. Amazing price and taste made me feel like at home. I'm sure I will come back tomorrow despite of waiting.
No comment
No comment

An instituition- the soup dumplings are the best in the City. Â The menu is extensive, service is fast. Â I love the eggplant (spicy) with pork and we had the Carp belly and it was great. Â The real star here is the soup dumplings!!! They are so tasty, perfectly doughy and soupy. Â A must check out in Soho. Â The resturaunt is lacking decor, service is fast/ sometimes almost rushed but really the reason to come here is to for the food not the decor.

Wow, this place has a lot of reviews. Â So anyway, I went here with a group of 14 from work for a farewell lunch for our interns. Â We ordered food to eat family style and I will definitely say it is inexpensive. Â I thought the dumplings (pork, since I don't love crab) were delicious. Â The scallion pancakes were just okay. Â The sesame chicken hit the spot. Â I don't eat squid but my co-workers insisted on ordering that dish because they love it so much. Â The eggplant was forgettable. Â The mushroom dish was decent but a little too heavy on the soy for my taste. Â So maybe I didn't absolutely love this place because of the dishes we ordered and I might like it more if I went with friends and just ordered what sounds good to me. Â I probably won't go back though.

Joe introduced me to soup dumplings, and now I feel like I'm in a Chuck Norris film on a never ending quest to find soup dumplings of equal or greater quality. I must be in the middle of the movie because nothing has come close, and I'm ready to quit my job and just open my own damn dumpling restaurant.
No comment

My Favorite spot for Chinese food in NY...Yes its crowded and I've had better service at other places, so if that really bothers you get your food to go or delivered...because this place makes great food! The soup dumplings are a must order, I also like the shanghai fried flat noodles, crispy duck, and chicken and shrimp in plum sauce.
No comment
Love Joe's! Of course, the soup dumplings are to die for... and they're hard to get as good anywhere else. So: order up!

I think that Joe's Shanghai's xiao long bao are likely to be the best in the city and probably the best on the east coast (I've even heard best in America but let's not get ahead of ourselves). Â The soup dumplings truly are delicious and flavorful, though compared to the real deal of Shanghai, they still need work in the aesthetics area. Â Don't waste your money on the crab flavored soup dumplings since they suck and don't taste better than the regular pork ones. Â Also, the other food is pretty unspectacular. Â I like to eat soup dumplings here as a pre-meal appetizer or a snack.

Some friends introduced me to Joe's a few years ago and I fell in love. Â Now its a must visit on a NYC trip, despite the long waits. Â The soup dumplings are to die for - steamed fish, sauteed veges, pan-fried noodles were all great too. Â Don't be surprised if you end up sharing a table with strangers or if you're bumped up against the guy at the next table. Â I found the service pleasant, but definitely not super friendly.
No comment
No comment
Fantastic spot. The soup dumplings are incredible. I could eat them forever. Super good. Go
No comment

It's all about the soup dumplings!!! The key is to work down from the top instead of from the sides. Their spicy shrimp was really good as well. Crispy, tangy and delicious. Ugh but my friend had to sit next to the trashcan and she was too sweet to ask to be moved or let me switch spots with her but that was definitely a turn off. Sorry Rach.

I crave their famous soup dumplings (siu long bao) with crab ALL of the time. whenever people come into town I take them here so that we can all bite into "little pieces of heaven." Alongside these we always get singapore chow mei fun, shanghainese noodle soup, shrimp/pork fried rice cake, the drunken chicken, stir-fried baby pea pod stems...everything. And everything, at the end of day, adds up to peanuts. One of the cheapest and most satisfying meals around. But don't forget to bring cash - they don't take credit cards!!!

Joe's Soup Dumplings ($5.50-6.50) are what made the place famous, and they're hard to resist. The grimy atmosphere might make you leave our monocles at home, but so long as Joe's keeps making delicious, cheap dumplings, I'll be coming back whenever I'm back in NY.
Super yummy soup dumplings and cheap cold beer were enough to get me here, and are probably enough to get me to come back.

I came here with family and I was very disappointed with the service.although the duck we ate was really good, the crisped beef was horrible.we found easily a spot to eat at around 6pm but the waiters are very rude and seem to be doing you a favor for everything you ask.one of them spilled tea in my table and didn't even clean it and when I asked to clean he threw me a paper towel so I would clean it!!! Incredible! I didn't want to give tip but it was 15% included.food has some potential but really horrible service!

Never fails. Got two soup dumplings, a pan fried noodle and a shrimp/pork dish. everythign was good except for the shrimp, surprisingly. It had no flavor. Come for the soup dumplings - everythign else is just ok. This place would get 3 stars, but recently i've been going to nearby places to try their soup dumps and theyre just not as good, so bump up to 4 stars.
No comment
Dumping was amazing and really good. Â I ordered fish dish too take a bit long. But ok. Â I did not like service Â waiter not care customer any more
No comment
No comment
Family style seating and eating. Got the pan fried shrimp noodles. They were delish. Place is a bit chaotic but I enjoyed the experience.
No comment

Due to the high reviews i found on yelp, i decided to try this place in chinatown. Boy do i regret it! The wait was not bad for two but we were not informed we would end up sharing a large table with strangers. The first thing i noticed about this place was that 90% of the customers were well.. Not asian. Being asian myself, i have gone to hundreds of chinese restaurants. I found some of the items to be way overpriced. The 1/2 crispy duck was mostly small, boney, skin, fat and cost $18 dollars. Usually, this would cost much less in the surrounding restaurants or where im from. Although, my girlfriend did enjoy the crab and pork dumplings. i think it's truely overhyped and would never return. People should give surrounding restaurants a try as well. This restaurant is definitely capitalizing on it's yelp reviews and naive first time customers like me.

I always see these soup dumplings on the travel channel and I always wanted to try it. Â I'm so glad my first time is at an authentic Chinese restaurant. Â The dumpling comes out piping hot so be careful with your first bite. Â It comes in a pork or crab meat variety, I like the pork more. Â  We also ordered Salt and Pepper Pork Chops and Beef Lo Mein. Â The pork chops was really good, the lo mein I can do with out though. Â It was really pack so you may have to share table more smaller groups.
No comment

Serving very tasty Dim sum, however, the service was gross. I brought one of my old Japanese friend, which was, I think, mistake. It appears famous for some Japanese because it was shown in a few Japanese guide books. The restaurant does know this and pasted some ads written in Japanese. The hospitality, however, is not reached to the level which deserves for real Asian foodies.

Took an out of town visitor here based on a lot of great reviews I've read and was pretty disappointed. Â It was fine... it just seemed kind of run-of-the-mill. Â The pork dumplings were quite good I have to say. Â But the chicken & shrimp in plum sauce and seafood noodles we ordered just seemed bland. Â Also didn't love that our party of 3 was seated at a round table with 2 other people. Â That was kind of weird.
No comment

Oh my gosh. Those dumplings were fantastic. I came here because my mom's coworker recommended it. I must say though that the non-dumpling dishes that we ordered were rather bland. Their string beans were undercooked and very tasteless; my family only ate half the dish and didn't even bother to consider taking it home with us. So when you come here, JUST EAT THE DUMPLINGS.

This is one of those "must try" hole in the wall places in NYC's Chinatown. Â We discovered it on yelp and used walking navigation to find it down an alleyway. Â Expect rushed service with no patience for questions. Â Expect the food to fabulous. Â Depending on the size of your party, expect you might even share a table. Â We lucked out and had the pleasure of sitting with some hot boriquas. Â Oh, expect to pay cash. Â For sure, try the famous shrimp dumplings...hell yeah.
Super disappointing. Flavor just wasn't there. I expected more because of the great reviews in Yelp. We didn't even finish our food.
No comment

It was a bit challenging finding this place because it was in the depths of China town. Let me go straight to the point! Very busy SMALL Chinese restaurant that's serves dumplings and several Chinese cuisine! Food taste good and price was reasonable! My only problem was the tables were so close to each other it makes you feel claustrophobic! Although the food taste good I only gave it 2 starts because I'm very very CRITICAL when it comes to CUSTOMER SERVICE!! Staff was rude in a way and when you're seated they rush to take your orders right away. The server we had knew little of the English language and he was very rude and aggressive. When the food was served not even 10 minutes you are given the check right away. It seems like they care more about your money than providing an extraordinary customer service experience. There are pictures of Celebrities around the restaurant who has been there before but don't be fooled because the service you will get will not be as close to those former VIP guest.

Came here on a Sunday afternoon. Wait was about 20 mins for a party of two. It's a cramped restaurant but so worth it! We ordered the pork soup dumplings and the scallion pancakes. The scallion pancakes were amazing. So crunchy and the dipping sauce that came with it really completed the dish. The soup dumplings were just how everyone described. Delicious pork broth and tasty seasoned pork. Total came out to be 11$ with gratuity included. Not bad for New York prices and we came out really full. I highly recommend you try this place out, especially all the foodies out there.
HEY TOURIST! If you're only gonna to order Fried Rice and Kung Pao Chicken, pick any other joint in Chinatown and save yourself the wait. Sheesh.

This place is famous for their soup dumplings - crabmeat or pork. Â Once I came here with 9 people and we ordered 10 steamers of dumplings and nothing else. Â The wait can be quite long if you're going during prime lunch or dinner hours, and there's not much of a waiting room (the outside of the restaurant stinks big time from the trash, pollution, etc.). Â It's definitely not a place to go if you're expecting to have a great dinner and hang out with your friends (it's a eat and run place). Â They require everyone in the party to be there before seating you, and they give you just about a minute before they come and take your order. Â The food does come out pretty quick. Â I've also been to the one in mid-town and the food is not quite as good, but you do get more attentive service (and the price is alot more expensive too).
No comment
No comment

Semi-authentic, Americanized Chinese food. I ordered Kung Pao Chicken and it was great. Wife and kids ordered General Tso and sesame chicken and there wasn't much chicken in it, mostly batter. The hot and sour soup was awesome! They only take cash. It was pretty expensive, especially for lunch. I would probably walk around and try a place with less than $9 lunch menus outside and try that.

The greatest xiaolongbao in the world. We have frequented Joe's Shanghai since its opening in the 1990s, and though we've since moved away from New York City, we still make special trips to visit this restaurant. We've tried xiaolongbao in Shanghai, we've tried countless numbers of restaurants in the US and Canada for xiaolongbao (including Din Tai Fung), and none have surpassed the sheer greatness of Joe's Shanghai. We love the rustic nature of these dumplings. They seem to have the perfect amount of soup and filling. The dumpling skins are the perfect thickness. We recommend this restaurant to everyone. This is a must-stop in NYC!

Because of all the hype, I thought this place would be as good as everyone else said it would be. But..the food is average. Nothing special about them. Tried 3 different types of dumplings (pork, chicken, seafood). They all tasted the same. Their noodles were good but nothing to really rave about.

Soup dumplings. Shredded pork with dried bean curd and jalapeÃ±os. My new favorite Chinese. Right up there with Dumpling Inn on convoy in San Diego. First really good Chinese since I'm on the east coast.
Really good XiaoLungBaos and scallion pancakes, but food was a bit too salty for my taste.

Can't complain about the food. The place is packed which means its a great place to eat. If you have a problem with greasy food then this place is not for you. Â you must try the steamed buns. Everything else on the menu you can probably pick up at a local Chinese take out.

Foreigners and Americans have clearly marked their territory in Chinatown. Joes Shanghai is decent but unfortunately not worth the wait or expense. The soup dumplings are delicious, but the equivalent of chicken soup - comfort food at its best. Also, for the clean freaks out there - be warned - clean walls are low on their priority list.

The soup dumplings are that unbelievable. Â The charming thing was the benihana style seating where if you have a party of less than 8, odds are you are sitting around a big table with other groups. Â And its funny watching as there is no co-mingling as everyone concentrates on not burning themselves on the broth.
Rude, curt staff. Â Pell street is a shady dump. Â Food is garbage, utter garb. Â If you like shard, you'll like their dumplings. Â Joe's on W 56th is much better.
No comment
No comment

Great dumplings! Wow! This has got to be one of the best restaurants in NYC for dumplings. Â My favorite are the pork dumplings with the little soup inside. Delicious! (Wait for them to cool a little bit before popping them in your mouth. Unless you enjoy burning your tongue!) Excellent food as well!

Ordered some crab with pork meat dumplings omgddd so delicious. When u take a bite the soup and all the flavor bursts into your mouth. I must say this is something new, but would definitely eat again. Second entree was fried porkchop also delicious. It was very crunchy. Young chow fried rice was great also. Overall this is my favorite Chinese food in nyc
No comment

I really have nothing to add to the 1628 existing reviews other than to say that the soup dumplings here are effing amazing! Â Arrive early (preferably on a weekday) and order the pork soup dumplings.
Delicious dumplings and yummy soup too! We didn't have much of a wait at all, but we also split a 10 seater table with 3 other groups. Service was pretty quick and the food was pretty cheap. Yum!
No comment

During a trip to Beijing, I was introduced to soup dumplings. Â After a friend's referral I made my way through Chinatown's cramped streets to Joe's Shanghai. Â I feasted on the crab and pork soup buns, turnip short cakes, Shanghai flat noodles and braised pork shoulder. Â The soup buns were not quite the same as those that I ate in Beijing but overall the food was delicious and the portions were huge. Â Four people could have easily shared this meal that was a little over $40. Â Caution when eating the soup buns because the liquid inside is hot.

This is where you go for the fun and the experience with people who make an outing fun. The food is pretty good, the soup dumplings ARE good, very good actually if you're into them but the rest is a bit weird. I love the green bean side but most main dishes are not the best.

found this place on yelp. had to try their dumplings which i thought were pretty good. i wish they had more of a selection of dumplings. we ordered 8 and it was enough for two ppl. we also ordered a bowl of beef noodle soup. that wasn't so good. noodles were overcooked and soggy. meat was ok, but nothing special. good thing lunch came out to $11. ding ding. =)
On the night of December 2nd, Joe's Shanghai got 105 violation points from the health department... and I got food poisoning. It's too bad because the food tasted great.
No comment

1ST THING u should order is soup dumplings- shao long bao. The price is so cheap and they are delicious! Foood is great and service was good too. But my only complaint is the interior of the resturant, the light was dim and it looked kind of shady. Dont be mistakened though because the food is delicious. Other notable dishes are the singaporean noodles and fried man tao

The XLB were pretty good, but overall, it's not something to be impressed about. The chicken fried rice was okay, but the flat noodles were greasy. You can just taste the MSG. The service is bad too. (Cash only)

This place has the worst quality meat that can be used, for $15 a dish. We didn't order the dumplings as we don't eat pork. So if you plan on eating here and don't like dumplings turn around and go somewhere else. They add 15% service charge automatically for 2 people. Service is okay but when we told them one dish was bad they said that's how it tastes. They must have ate it when they took it back and I had to pay for it. Worst Chinese restaurant and definitely not worth the walk.

Soup Dumplings (sometimes also called Juicy Buns) are the specialty here, and they are definitely very good. But don't stop there, because while they're known for their dumplings I was actually more impressed by their Braised Duck and their Shredded Eel with Yellow Scallions. The Soup Dumplings are good, but I think I actually prefer them at Liberty View in Battery Park. As a side note, the last time I went to Joe's Shanghai, I ended up sharing a table with Chad Lowe.

Anything less than 5 stars is blasphemy and you should get your tongue checked for some kind of oral cancer because you obviously are suffering from some kind of condition that messes with your taste buds. Â The small juicy dumplings are simply amazing. Â Possibly the best you can get in the whole US. Â From what I've heard it's nearly as good as some particular place in Taiwan. Â Anyways 5 stars for this place. Â If you gave it 4 stars, must've been the service, if you gave it 3 stars or less you should go to the hospital IMMEDIATELY to get yourself checked out.
No comment

I've been here on a Monday for lunch, and it definitely wasn't crowded then! Â The soup dumplings are pretty big and soupy, and the other food is satisfying. Â Nothing spectacular though and a little bit greasy. Â Since I'm currently living in a place devoid of decent Chinese food, it hits the spot for me.

Yummyyy soup dumplings and reasonable price!! I would def. come back here :) The only downfall is that they seat you with a bunch of strangers so it's kind of awkward hahah. Besides that, the food is pretty satisfying.

I'll admit I've not had xiao long bao anywhere else, but I've had my share of different types of bao/dumplings and while it was good, it wasn't out of this world, knock me off of my socks. I guess so much hype, I expected much more. The bun part seemed to a little too chewy. We had both the pork and the crab... both were okay, though I prefer the pork to the crab.
great scallion pancake and fabulous pork buns and pork and shrimp buns.

Absolutely delicious. Got the soup dumplings with crab meat- holy moly, bursts of magical goodness into your mouth & the pork fried rice- good but not as fantastic as the soup dumplings. Was busy, waited about 10 minutes or so, not bad. Cash only. Service was decent. Did feel slightly rushed, but I guess that's what happens when people are waiting.

Expect communal tables and a long wait. There is another Joe Shanghai in midtown that has shorter wait times. The juicy buns are good, but there are other hidden gems in Chinatown that have comparable juicy buns. The other dishes here are OK - I wouldn't recommend them.

I feel like I don't need to elaborate on this review since it's been reviewed so many times. Â All I want to say is that I feel like this place has better dumplings than Din Tai Fung. Â These dumplings are packed with soup and juicy goodness, DTF's not so much.

Disappointment! We thought we were lucky to get a table bc it was a rainy day but the food was horrible. Â The wontons were so salty we only ate a few n left. Â Joe Shanghai...what happened to you?! Â I'll not be back.

Waited too long for a mostly average Chinese "tourist" menu. Soup dumplings, the house specialty, were hit or miss on this most recent visit (half our double order were dry inside). Fast & friendly service once you're finally seated, but count the change carefully when paying your cash-only bill. The restaurant's "ego wall" collage of reviews and kudos is sadly dated and out-of--touch with the present tense.

this was a must visit during my trip to NY with my gfs! We ordered the Crab and Pork Juicy Dumplings and they were both amazing. My personal favorite was the Pork Juicy Dumplings. Simple yet full of flavors and filled with so much goodness.
