Just try pork and crab dumpling. These two menus are enough to fulfill your appetite.
No comment

Looking at all the reviews on yelp, I thought this place would be pretty popular but we walked into a half full restaurant for lunch on a Friday. Also it's in an alley street just south of Canal street. Surprised that they make you share a larger table with another smaller group. It makes sense when it's busy but there were other empty tables. Anyways ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings right away. Then we decided on the seafood chow mein as our other dish. It was just enough food for three girls without having to take any leftovers home. The dumplings came out quickly. I, of course, couldn't wait to try it so I actually burned my tongue a bit on my first slurp of that soup. I liked the skin was thin and there was plenty of flavorful soup inside. I couldn't really taste the crab so I would maybe just stick with the pork ones next time. I still gotto say my favorite xio long bao is still from Din Tai Fung here in California. The chow mein was a bit oily but I liked the sauce and the thick noodles. And they put a lot of seafood in there - shrimp, scallops, and squid. I felt like they should because it's like $13 for that dish and twice as much if we had just gotten the chicken or beef version. I would totally eat here again for their soup dumplings.

Probably the best Chinese food I've had. Prawns, chicken, rice, all the best. Very fresh-tasting and sizable portions. Not loaded with vegetables or water chestnuts like so many other Chinese restaurants. Only complain is that they try to get you in and out as quickly as possible. When you're halfway through your meal, waiters will stand over you with their arms crossed, looking down at you waiting for your party to finish.

I feel bad that I live in NYC and am not a huge Chinese fan, but Joe's Shanghai? Ok, by me. First thing's first - be prepared to wait at both the Chinatown and midtown locations. The soup dumplings are all the rave here and they should be. They are good and CHEAP. Just little pillows of heaven. I've gotten a few other dishes here, but nothing comes even close to the dumplings. I could make a meal out of those alone!
Sitting here thinking we went for dim sum. No dim sum. Â And food is just ok. Â Dirty glasses. Â Very touristy. Â There is much better just next store.

So thoroughly overrated. So pissed that I ate here. Everything was bad- the waitstaff, the space, the food. Everything. There is 0 to redeem this place. How does it have this reputation. I've had soup dumplings in so many other places that are so much better. The only piece of food we had that was slightly tasty was the scallion pancake. My wife had noodles that were bland and tasted like they had been cooked in fat (Yuck) My father in laws dish of beef was tasteless and had been fried to a crisp. My dish of chicken was bland as well. Even their tableside hot condiment was bland (how can this be???) The service was rude, they forgot about us, our drinks were never filled, etc. The space is terribly loud and cramped, which we could all overlook if their food was stellar. But, it's not. There are so many places in this city, places in Manhattan, outside of Chinatown, in Queens, in Brooklyn, that have such better food. I would never, ever come back to this poor excuse for a restaurant.

We stopped by to try the dumplings and boy were we happy! We didn't have anything else to eat when we were there because we didn't need anything else. The dough was soft but still had a bite. The filling was simply delicious.

Don't mistake this for a fine dining experience. This is a place to come with your friends and wolf down soup dumplings. It's busy, it's loud. But the basic point is that the food is great and you will be glad you came. The downside is that you sometimes have to share tables with strangers. It's all about how you look at it - you get instant friends!!
I have no idea why everyone goes here, the food was sub par, and the atmosphere was hectic and crowded. The dumplings were very unappealing as well. Would not recommend.

Not to much I can add to what has already been said about this place. Â Yes, the Soup Dumplings are outstanding and a must have. Â I have had them twice...once to go (not the easiest thing to eat while walking but we managed) and once at a sit down. Â Typical Chinatown communal dining. Â The night we ate there, we shared a table with a couple from LA and their local hosts who were kind enough to offer us taste of their dishes when we admired them. The shanghai casserole was excellent and the salt and pepper shrimp were just about perfect. Â But be forewarned, this place gets crowded Â and there is often a wait. Â Which only means..its worth it!
Crab soup dumplings. They're as good as everyone says. Definitely a must if you are in NYC.
No comment

It would be a grand mistake to get anything other than the soup dumplings here. Â And you should stay away if you're not into chinatown style dining - sharing tables, noisy atmosphere, crowded spaces, blah blah blah etc. Â Other than that though, this place rocks!
Go there for the steamed mini soup buns, but stay for nothing else. Â For true, edible Shanghai fare, there are a couple other places in chinatown I would recommend over this place.

I've taken a bunch of friends and family here often and everyone stuffs themselves silly. Â You must get the usual, which is the crab and pork soup dumplings, that I have for an appetizer. Â I always order the shredded beef which is sooo crunchy and good. Â Everytime I order it, people sitting next to me ask what the name of my dish is. Â Today, I was pleasantly surprised when my friend ordered this tofu dish that I never tried. Â Again, everyone started ordering the same foods we ordered. Â Another favorite is this thick udon-like fried noodle with seafood. Â I don't know the name but the waiters usually figure out what I want. Â A must-go.....period!

My friends were ranting and raving about soup dumplings before i came to new york.. i wasn't exactly sure what that was. so i get here to the infamous joe's shanghai and ordered 2 Â soup dumplings and 1 pancake for my friend and i to share. when they came out to my surprise its the same thing as xlb! (xiao long bao) here i thought i was in for a treat. I still thing Ding Tai Fung in California is better. :)

If you like soup dumplings (or are trying them for the first time) -- this is the place to go. Â Order the pork or crab shao long bao (soup dumplings)... one order is probably enough for two people, if you're ordering other stuff too. Â Other recommended dishes include snow pea leaf, roast pork shanghai noodles and the jellyfish dishes are quite good as well. Â What I love about Joe's Shanghai and other similar places in Chinatown is their simple excellence. They do not put on a show-- the waiters are abrupt, pushy, and by no means friendly, but this is reminiscent of all real authentic chinese food restaurants. Â It can be touristy but I think its worth the hype.
No comment

Their soup dumplings were awesome! Â Their soup dumplings were awesome! Â We had a bunch of other stuff, but all I remember about that meal were their soup dumplings...which were awesome. Â Oh yeah, and their pan fried red bean cakes were a perfect way to finish a great meal.

2.5 stars. We ordered the crab soup dumplings and the pork dumplings. No complaints about the service, I asked for extra ginger to eat with the dumplings and the servers were quick to bring them out. I am not sure if it's fair to compare Joe's to Din Tai Fung because Joe's is a lot cheaper - for $5 you get 8 pork soup dumplings. However, the thickness of the dough and the greasiness of the soup made the whole eating experience seemed more like a chore instead of feeling like I am stuffing deliciousness into my mouth which is how I feel when I am eating at DinTai Fung. For a place so highly rated for its XLB, I was disappointed.

The soup dumplings are good but by far, Shanghai Cafe has the BEST soup dumplings out there! Skip the crazy lines of all the tourists who don't know any better. Check out the other gems of Chinatown and not fall for this tourist trap!

Joe Shanghai, what more can I say about this place, BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS, in town. Â Being that it was my second time ever eating there the experience of eating a soup dumpling is still farely new to me. Â  The first time I ever ate there I didn't know the technique of eating one and when I first took a bite of that soup dumpling, FAIL! Â Since this was my second go round, I brought some cousins along with me to see if I can get them to jump on the Joe Shanghai bandwagon. Â I have to say they enjoyed it. Â My technique this go round was definitely a lot better than the first time. Â NIBBLE, SLURP, add soy sauce and eat like normal dumpling. Â Remember that...now if I can only make market that into a jingle.

A friend and I are trying to eat at every branch of Joe's Shanghai. Soup dumplings are most certainly the highlight of this busy Chinatown restaurant. Come to think of it, I don't believe I've really eaten much here besides the soup dumplings. Maybe a scallion pancake or some lo mien once in a while.... But if I'm here, I'm 100% eating their delicious dumplings.

It was good but not the BEST of the BEST or so they say. Basically can have the same quality in any other chinese restaurant that makes soup based dumplings. Nothing special about it. Not worth the hype.

The only two things I order when I come here are the soup dumplings and the beef pan-fried noodles and it'll be a perfect day. The only thing I don't agree with is the seating arrangements because it gets very crowded in there. I don't mind eating with strangers but it gets very cramped, especially if you're seated between the wall and the table.

The food comes out pretty fast and you can make RSVP. we had a group of 12 or so and we were able to be late and get seated pretty fast. The pork and soup dumplings were good, eggplant dishes were good but maybe too much sauce, the babyshrimp dish came with huge portion, both the pork and chicke rice cakes were really good, we also got the giant meatballs which were good, etc. The food came out to be $13 a person and we ate sooo much even though we were starting with the 8 crates of soup dumplings.

I understand why people like this so much but for me the dumplings just don't live up to the hype. Or maybe it's that I'm not a huge fan of soup dumplings and prefer my dumplings stir fried. Either way, I still like this restaurant for its other food and have found my previous visits to still be quite good. I've been here a few times over the years and each time I find myself a little underwhelmed with the dumplings.
The soup dumplings were amazing! The other Chinese dishes were not as bad too. Definitely recommend :)
Came for the soup dumplings and it was worth it. Really tasty and a total comfort food. Â Even my husband who isn't a normal dumpling fan ate a whole bunch.

I'm not an expert but I've eaten A LOT of chinese food in my life. Â Anytime I get an out of towner to visit and they like Chinese this place is the place. Â I have never had anyone say that it wasn't the best. Â Yea, yea the soup buns are delicious. Â I like the string beans szechuan style. Â You can't go wrong really..

I can't get enough of this place! Every time I'm in New York, i always make Joe's Shanghai one of my snack stops before i get back on the Lucky Star for Boston. Â  Here's what i always get: pork soupie dumplings, home style tofu, beef noodle soupie, eggplant with garlic sauce. Â I'm craving the dumpling soup as I'm writing this! Â I have to admit that the staff may appear a tad gruff, but they ask what you want right away cos you most likely will order dumplings, right? Â And they take abt 15 minutes to steam into their delicious soupie pouches. Â Also, they are so so so busy they need to keep their customers coming and going, you know? Â that's why if you are waiting for a table, it's usually 20 minutes tops. Â so chillax, and share a table, you may get introduced to some new dishes, and eat dumplings!

When I heard about the soup dumplings, I literally thought I was going to get dumplings floating in some soup! but when i got there they were just giant dumplings filled with soup (which I only found out after biting into a steaming hot one and burning my mouth!) Â I got the crab dumplings and they were delicious as well as spicy pepper shrimp which I thought were great as well, especially for the price! would recommend this place to anyone!
Love the pork soup dumplings. They are simply the tastiest soup dumplings I've ever had. My brother and I had 8!! dumplings each and a soda and the total cost was $12. What a steal!
The soup dumplings are THE BEST! Â Worth the wait. Â I've tried the other location in Midtown but I prefer (and I think the dumplings are better) at the Chinatown location.

Seriously, it's good as it gets in the U.S.! Â It's good, even for Chinatown standards. Â I'm drooling as I type this....but they really are an authentic Shanghainese restaurant. Â One downside is that seating is limited and you are often forced to sit with 2 other families at one big round table....a bit awkward, but the food is worth it. Â One dish that seems random and obscure, bamboo and mushrooms, is SO good. Â The mushrooms and the broth/sauce they're in are simply heavenly. Â And of course you've got to order the soup dumplings..........they are steamed to perfection. Â Ahhhh get me there now!

Joe's Shanghai has the best dumplings I've ever tried in New York City. Â However, I'm giving it four stars for the food mainly, and not anything else. Â The wait is completely ridiculous on the weekends, so definitely avoid it if you can. Â I usually come here on the weekdays for a late lunch. Â The waitstaff isn't the friendliest bunch, and the hostesses are kind of rude. Â One hostess was actually texting on her phone while she led us to our table. Â They also have added gratuity which sucks because the service definitely does not deserve the 15%. Â The decor is almost nonexistent. Â The food comes fairly quickly though, so that's something. Â I would recommend this place only for the food because I can't find any other place with better dumplings.

Hidden in a small alley in Chinatown, I wasn't sure what to expect. But before I knew it I was gobbling these succulent dumplings, filled with steaming broth and a crab meatball. And oh my gosh, so juicy and ahh... And so cheap!!! It was only about $5 for 8 or so dumplings, and they can fill you up fast!! Warning, warning, this place gets packed!! So prepare to be sitted in a squishy environment, but it will be all worth it. =)

Came in for the crab and pork soup dumplings because we'd heard that they were the best in the world. I'm not sure you can call these xlbs but they were rather soupy and decent. Definitely not even close to top 10 best dumplings I've ever had. Â I thought the skin was too thick and overall the way this entire establishment is run is pretty unappealing. Rude service, rushing people out, pushing past customers in the narrow walkways with plates of food... meh.

Last month I ventured into the big apple with my partner in crime and indulged in some tasty morsels. One treat that particularly stood out was the concoction of pork and dough from Joe's Shanghai. As you cautiously take a bite of the hot dumpling, its deliciously fatty contents trickle down your throat and into your stomach. We left fully satisfied and continued on our food-venture.

Errrrr, as someone having Xiao long bao for over 20 yrs , I have to say this place makes something I would never consider as Xiao long .... It's sooo big and the cover is just too thick .... Can't understand y so many ppl praised it

This place is just ok, not as good as I remember it. The crab dumplings were fine but I remember the Joe's Shanghai of old being a bit more delicious when it came to dumplings and such. Still good, but nothing to write home about.

There's an amazing soup dumpling place in Flushing that's very well known, and I thought no one could top them off.. but then came Joe's Shanghai. While the place in Flushing still probably tops Joe's off SLIGHTLY in the regular pork soup dumplings, the crab soup dumplings were phenomenal. The line outside was kind of ridiculous, and it took about an hour to get in, but if the wait isn't too bad,t hen it's definitely worth it to go here. The prices are very reasonable too.. it was like $7 or $8 for 8 huge soup dumplings. And the scallion pancakes were only $3 and were also extremely delicious. Very good experience, take your grandma here.

Wow. This place was phenomenal. By far, the best dish we had were the pork soup dumplings. Other dishes were meh, but the dumplings were out of this world. Had to wait in line for about 15 minutes. Cash only. Large portions.
The juiciest Xiao Long Bao (pork soup dumplings) in this country at least! I have never seen so much juice inside of them, even more than places in China. Worth the wait in line

I had the dumplings everyone goes crazy over. They were tasty but otherwise this was just a busy Chinese food place - no dim sum, which was what I was searching for.

All I can say is...DELISH! Their pork soup dumplings and scallion pancake are so yummy. Just be careful in eating the soup dumplings since they're piping hot inside. Once you take that bite, or if you're able to put the whole thing in your mouth in one shot..it was heaven. I got that same experience when biting into the scallion pancake which was nice and crispy on the outside plus flaky. We were a party of 6 and ordered 2 orders of pork soup dumplings, 2 orders of pork & crab soup dumplings, 2 different crispy noodles, seafood noodle soup, and a whole steamed fish. The bill came out to be about $98 or so which was not bad since a whole steamed fish was ordered and there was 6 of us.

This is one of my favorite NY restaurants. Â I've been there several times, and last time went with a Chinese foodie friend of mine who did all the ordering. Sure, we ended up with tons of leftovers, but everything was delicious including the soup noodles, turnip cake, sesame noodles and lion's head dish. Â Also try the green onion pancakes. Â The fried eel is interesting, but you can only have a bit at a time. Â Make sure you order the house specialty, soup noodles. They are simply the best around. Â No wonder the place got 2 stars from Ruth Reichl from the NY Times

While meeting up with friends in Chinatown we had some dim sum and then came here. I would've preferred to just start here but for what it's worth I thought the dumplings were good. Â The green onion pancakes reminded me of the dim sum bakery in SF that I stop at once a week.

One of the first places that a couple of friends and I found when I first moved here, and it has become a favorite! The soup dumplings are absolutely delicious. Don't go on a weekend if you can help it though- it'll be a long wait outside because everyone else loves this place too!

Ordered the pork soup dumplings and was thoroughly satisfied! Â The soup was so delicious and nothing like I've ever tasted before! Â Definitely a place to try if you're craving good dumplings.

First of all... order the pork dumpling soup. Multiple orders if you are with more than couple people. Tell the waiters what you like, and trust them. This place couple possibly be the best Chinese I have ever eaten next to House of Nan King in San Francisco. Do yourself a favor, if you are in NYC and go there

Only got delivery from this place, but it is one of the best Chinese food that I have had. Their dumplings are amazing and General Tso's chicken is really good. Definitely recommend!

We ordered eggplant and rice cakes but could've went without. Â Nothing too special about those. Â The soup dumplings though... SO GOOD!!! Â We should've just got 3 orders of these and called that dinner. =) Â Too bad I don't live here or else I'd eat them all the time.

Soup dumplings! Oh, my lovely soup dumplings! Yes, this place is touristy. Yes, there is always a wait. Yes, they sometimes rush you out. But if you are prepared for these things, and just keep thinking that the food will be worth it, then you are in for a treat. Everything I have ever had is yummy. Crispy prawns, shredded beef, noodles, fried rice, General Tsao's, and their shrimp wonton soup. It's all yum. This is a cash only establishment, and even though tip is included, they will sometimes not return with your change, thinking it's a tip. Make sure you tell them that you expect change. You can, of course, then tip them over the 15%. Can't wait to go back!

You have to come here for the soup dumplings! Â If you don't, you haven't really lived life to its fullest!

The signature soup dumplings are so damn good! I havent had anything else here but watching my friends gobble away with gratification said it all. I was pretty content with my dumplings and green tea !

The Crab Meat with Pork Steamed Soup Buns are OFF THE HOOK! I don't even know how something can taste so good. If you've never tried them, get them now! Go there, order, eat them then come back here and thank me.

Of course there's going to be a wait. So be prepared! We were super excited to try the dumplings here since we LOVE XLB (Shanghai dumplings) so that was the only thing we had. We ordered both the pork and the crab. The pork had more flavor and also soup more than the crab. So I recommend on ordering just the pork dumplings!
Their soup dumplins are the best, I we also had the friend rice and General Tso's chicken. Best Chinese I've ever had in the USA. Worth the short wait, takes only cash.
They have the best soup dumpling for 100% sure. Other dishes are little too greasy for me. Hey but they taste good and cheap. Why not!

5 stars for the crab or pork dumplings. You must try these dumplings when you are there. Other dishes are very good too, just the service is not that great but it's understandable because it's always busy at this restaurant.
No comment

Tucked away on a bustling side street in NYC Chinatown, Joe's Shanghai was hopping when my husband and I arrived for early dinner. Â They have only one table for two, so we first shared a round table with a single customer and two young women who spoke in Chinese. Â After they left, two other groups joined the table. Â We did not find the setup intrusive and were able to see close up other dishes which looked even better than what we ordered. Â For starters, the crab and pork soup dumplings were fantastic. Â I was expecting soup, but these eight large dumplings are served in a bamboo steamer over a bed of cooked cabbage. Â They need no condiment; however the soy sauce with ginger shavings on the table was a nice addition. Â I was eyeing another appetizer and was glad we ordered only the dumplings because they were more than enough for two. Â For mains I got the Szechuan fish fillet, which was perfectly spiced and cooked and melted in my mouth. Â It was served with bean sprouts (only) so may be best to share, as one person eating fish and sprouts may find it boring after a while. Â I would have preferred a colorful veggie or two added. Â My husband got the double cooked pork, which was notches above any carryout version we have ordered. Â The complimentary hot tea and white rice were also good. Â Service was fine and the wait was reasonable. Â My suggestion for improvement is to remove the clutter--employees personal belongings in plain sight--and deep clean the entire place. Â I had no sanitary concerns. Â For esthetics only, as a sprucing up should improve the dining experience.

It was such an ordeal trying to find this place at ten o'clock at night. Traveling the streets of N.Y. with two 70 yr olds, one 7 yr old & two republicans was not easy. Starving for great Chinese food someone had suggested & trying to meet our cousins..... But in the end - WELL WORTH THE JOURNEY. Â If you crave good authentic Chinese food, this is the place. No B.S. just good food. For you first timers, try the soup dumplings, they're sooooo worth it!

I was introduced to this place by my friend. Their soup dumplings are delicious. The first time I went, we only had appetizers. I couldn't stop eating the soup dumplings. They have 2 varieties, The crab and pork are my favorite. Will definitely go here when in Chinatown. Make sure you get a small table if you want privacy. They will fill all of the round tables. I tend to not mind having the locals at my table because I like watching what they eat and then try it. They can recommend some great dishes.

The thing about this place is that they are always rushing you out the door. The minute your food drops they haunt your table in hopes that your almost done. They basically start clearing the minute the dish looks half empty. The dumplings are fantastic however. They really do a great job with those pork dumplings and I love them... BUT everything else is mediocre. I guess I would say get the scallion pancakes and the red bean dessert...but nothing is comparable to those dumplings. The service really sucks. I mean, they're quick and your order comes out right away...but you don't feel welcomed to stay and enjoy your meal. It feels like your in a fast food service environment so just be aware.

First time I had their steamed buns was great, but after trying a few other places. Shanghai village on Elizabeth or Mott street is much better. Also joe shanghais food is over priced. More for tourists now rather good comfort food

alright, i don't know why there's such big hypes about this place. i was expect something authentic like in Asia.. but it was more Americanized... bigger in size and doesn't taste as delicate in flavors. the dumpling wrapper/skin tasted rough not as soft or smooth. The filling was okay. maybe all the hypes made me expect a lot. but to me it doesn't taste as good as the ones I had in Asia for sure. it was kind of disappointing. Good thing we didn't wait for too long. there were 3 of us, so we shared a big table with 2 other groups. my first time seeing that in NYC.

Joe's Shanghai is one of those restaurants you'll have to try when in Chinatown. I don't necessarily recommend this place for the atmosphere, the service, overall food, etc., but I do recommend it because of their soupy dumplings. The few times I have come here, there has always been a line outside - It's a tolerable length of waiting time though, and they will try to usher you in as quickly as possible. Although, after a long day of walking through Chinatown, this would probably be the last place I would want to be. It also has communal tables because it is that crowded. You will need to sit next to strangers. This is not a bad thing though, but I personally prefer my own seating space and more privacy with my guest(s). Going back to their soupy dumplings, it's delicious and costs only $5 for 8 of them. It's sufficient enough for a meal, and you may not need to order anything else. If you never tried a soupy dumpling, then all the more reason to check out Joe's Shanghai.
No comment

Joes shanghai is as authentic as china town gets. Although it has an A sanitation rating, it does not look extremely clean. They do not take reservation and things can get a little wild / unorganized at the door. If you are looking for a date spot this is not the place. All the large tables are communal seating and you are pretty much sharing dishes with others at your table. We ordered the soup dumplings which did not disappoint. Joes is known for their soup dumplings and they were extremely juice. I also recommend getting the shanghai flat noodles. The noodles are very thick and delicious. Aside from the mess at the door and the communal seating the food was delicious.

Joe's Shanghai is by far my favorite "Real" Chinese food Restaurant in (China Town) NYC. The Place is a little "Overrated" but definitely the best Chinese Food your money can buy. The Place is always packed, there is always a wait of 20-30 minutes, and always a line of people that spills out the door into the Street. Your Patience will be rewarded. Once your number is called, you are entering a Frenzy, the Restaurant is always super packed, you are guaranteed to sit in a table with complete strangers, Its cool I've never had a problem with it, just a bit awkward lol. There "Soup Dumplings" is a must, its the first thing the waiter asks you when you are seated, "what kind of dumpling"" Ordering these dumplings is a must. We always order the pork & crab dumplings, they come out hot and Steamy served on a steam tray, the dumplings are full of Flavor Liquid and just pop in your mouth with flavor, they are literally full of soup and are to die for, but careful because they are so hot that i always burn my mouth lol. They have an extensive menu, everything I've tried so far is pretty good, Beef with Scallions, Shrimp Fried Rice, Pan-Fried Flat Noodles and Seafood, Salt & Pepper Pork chop etc. The Staff is very attentive and service is pretty quick. This is not the Typical place where you sit for hours and spend time conversing and sipping your wine or eating desert, You almost feel the common courtesy to eat rather quickly to give courtesy to the 100 people waiting in line outside for their turn to enter and take your place next lol. That overall decor of the restaurant is not fancy, the Atmosphere is Lively, (Very Busy). I recommend this place to anyone who is interested in eating "Real" NYC Chinese food in China Town.
Excellent soup dumplings -- love how they explode in my mouth. My boyfriend recommends the vegetarian duck, a small yet really tasty appetizer.

On my last visit to NY I made my friend drive me to Joe's Shanghai to try their soup dumplings. Â I was not disappointed. Â In my 3 day mini vacay, I ate @ Joe's twice! Their soup dumplings are DELICIOUS! I tried some of their other dishes but nothing stands out like those juicy, delicious dumplings.

Decided to pay this place a visit while in Chinatown. I tried the shrimp dumplings, Shanghai's fried rice and veggie dumplings. The portions were quite generous, we even took some food to go. A good option if you happen to be in the neighborhood.

Joe's Shanghai was once THE place for soup dumplings in NYC. Â Unfortunately, that was 15 years ago. Â Yes, their soup dumplings are good but it's not worth the wait. Â Their shanghai noodles are too oily. I only go if visitors insist on trying it and the wait is minimal.

I have died and gone to dumplings heaven . Â If given the option I would seriously consider trading my first born son for some crab dumplings . The service is the only thing holding me back from giving this dumpling house 5 stars .

This place should be 5 stars. The xiao long bao here is as good as the street vendors in shanghai. Lots of soup inside the dumpling, which is the authentic way to do it. The pork is the best but the shrimp is also ok. I've been here every time I'm in NYC, which is about 7-8 times in the past couple of years. There might be a line outside since the place is really popular. I haven't been to any of their other locations but this one is enough to satisfy my cravings. One more thing, the seating is combined tables, so you'll probably be seated with strangers unless you are in a big group of 7-8 people. Check this place out!

I am not a fan of Chinese, but this is definitely my favorite Chinese food I've had. I'm from Southern California, and Chinese food is huge in Monterey Park and Alhambra. I would never crave Chinese food from the top restaurants here. Joes Shanghai was something special. I highly recommend it.

Joe's Shanghai has a reputation for being one of the Chinatown eateries that you have to visit. Â One thing to note, Shanghainese dishes are a little different from other Chinese dishes, which is why eating at Joe's is such a treat. Â The two more popular dishes are the xiao long bao and the Shagnhainese style fried noodles. Â I could stuff myself with both of those all day. Â Some of the other cold appetizers aren't bad either, I'd say order one or two dishes, say the chicken, jellyfish, or beef, just to try them out. Â While you could order some of these dishes at other restaurants, this is the spot in Manhattan where they are the most authentic.

I havent had many experiences with Xiao Long Bao but this place was by far the best i have eaten. Â I am from Texas and there arent many good places to get it. Â The soup was perfectly flavored and the meat was tender. Â I was careful about how i picked up my dumpling so that it wouldnt break since the skin was rather thin. Â This is actually a good thing for i have eaten some with thick skin which just wasnt my taste. Â Overall it was one heck of an experience! NYC food is amazing
No comment

So regardless of my negative reaction from Joe's Shanghai a couple years ago. I decided to take the plunge and risk the being of my digestive system. I was craving for shanghai soup dumplings. I got it for take out and it was ready to go in 15 minutes. I must say, compared to Full House, the quality was much better. I had the crab meat soup dumplings. The wrapping didn't break and it came through after my first bite. Compared with Full House, it has a different taste to it but not a bad taste. Both are good in their own ways but I think I'd prefer Joe's over anywhere else. Definitely trying their wontons next week! Stay tuned!
Small line when we got there but only about 15 minute wait. Â Food was excellent. Â Enjoyed Dumplings with 3 sauces, Sesame Chicken, and Shrimp Fried Rice. Â Yum!
The soup dumplings are simply the best! They are so delicious and authentic. I crave them on a weekly basis. The service is also spectacular. Servers are kind and accommodating.

My original intent for going here was to try their soup dumpling, which I found to be underwhelming. (Between Din Tai Fung and Joe's, I'm with the Din Tai Fung camp.) Anyways, we ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings, pork only dumplings, snow pea sprouts, and the spicy beef noodle soup. Surprisingly enough, the highlights of the meal were not the soup dumplings but the snow pea sprouts and spicy beef noodle soup. Both of these dishes were flavorful with quality ingredients... would come back for these but not the dumplings.

Place is packed 15 minutes after they open. It's so clear why! Services quick, dumplings are spectacular, and even the other dishes were really out of this world. Definitely worth a trip to Chinatown!

Everytime I'm in New York, I spend the first few days saying "I want to go to Joe's Shanghai" over and over again to anyone who even mentions food. Eventually I talk someone into going with me (usually lured by my promise of bringing them to Chinatown "back rooms" where you can get Luis Vuitton knockoffs for 25 bucks). I order the pork and crab soup dumplings and a Tsing Tao, and achieve true happiness which will last me until I'm in NY again. Akshay is right - don't bother ordering anything else. The soup dumplings will set you straight.

This is most popular out of all their places but the wait can be so long and you will have to share a table. The soup dumpling are best here but also in Flushing location. Â The one in uptown is overprice and the dumpling fall apart before you even get them. They make a great onion pancake and the combination fried rice is really good here. We usually get both the port and the crab but we end up always liking the pork better.
The best dumplings! Â Place that little dumpling in your soup spoon, break the dumpling skin so that the juices flow out into your spoon, and place in your mouth ... Mmmmm, heavenly ...

Total tourist trap. The signature crab and pork dumplings are ok but definitely not great. The worst part is the MANDATORY service charge on top of which they tried to get away with stealing some extra for themselves but not giving back our change! Don't waste your time unless you are too intimidated to go anywhere else in Chinatown.

The place told us it was a 25 min wait and we waited an hour. Tables are shared and the food was not all that for the wait and line outside. The dumplings were not even that good. We orders beef that was shavings and was not good at all. Don't believe the hype.

The reason for 2 stars has nothing to do w/ the food-- in fact, the food was fabulous. Soup dumplings (xiao long bao) were amazing and definitely hit the spot the night I was there when it was 1000 degrees below freezing. However, thanks to the bitchy hostess who screamed at us for not being accurate about how many we had in our party, this place gets a meager 1-star rating from Clee. We could have easily squeezed in that extra chair, but nope-- apparently, saying you have 1 less person in your party than you actually do is a heinous crime.
No comment
No comment

The dumplings were AWESOME! We got both soup dumplings. The service was loud. I also saw Kevin from Top Chef! which gave the experience a big plus. Other than that, we were situated with another family (awkward). They expect you to order as FAST as possible. We had to wade off waiters asking us multiple times that we weren't sure what to get. The food was pretty good (not extraordinary good), but the soup dumplings were one of my favorite experiences in New York. Price was reasonable, but I would totally come here again, even if it means sitting with another family.
Xie fen xiao long really the best!!!

Joes provides a great shanghai dumpling for a great price. Â The crab dumpling you can skip but the standard dumplings are some of the best I've had. Â These along with everything else on the menu at joes tastes great and as they should for a good chinese restaurant. Â Two thumbs up. Â Pick any thing on the menu. Â Everything I've had here so far had been tasty.

Warning, this is a cash only place. The food was exceptional. The beef tendon noodle soup and crab dumplings were super good. I especially like the carp belly with buffalo sauce.

Thinking of Joe's Shanghai dumplings makes me miss NY so much!! Â Delicious hot and juicy dumplings! Â The line was long. Â Get there early. Â Get your name down. Â Share a table and you're all set! Â You can tell who were the veterans. Â You want to watch how they bite into their dumplings to get the maximum pleasure. Â I was surely a newbie. Â We ordered other things other than dumplings, but I can't remember them because they did not stand out as much as the dumplings. Â The wait for the food wasn't very long once you're seated. Â All of the staff were very fast and pretty friendly. Â My friend will be moving to Shanghai, I guess I'll finally get to try the real deal once I visit. Â I'll have a better comparison. Â But so far, this has got to be the best ones I've had in the states.

XLB were good, but some were a bit dry at certain parts. Turnip cake was very tasty, as was the roast beef noodle soup. Extremely reasonable prices. 2 hour long wait for Christmas dinner, though. Honestly, not worth more than a 45 minute wait... the prices definitely justify the wait.

My friend hyped this place up so much that I hauled a bunch of friends here through rain, traffic & a 20 minute wait. Â Too much hype, too touristy and pretty average. Â I would pop in this place if it was in my hood, less crowded or cheaper. Â Otherwise this is not a destination resto. Â Big ole Meh...

No. Just plain no. If you're going to come here for dumplings be prepared for them to only specialize in pork. Which would then lead you to sit down and order something else (Considering you already waited for about 40 minutes outside to get seated). Their regular food is a little below mediocre considering they have such high ratings on yelp. The service was disgusting. I understand that there are tons of people in need of service but slow down and wait to hear my order before assuming what I want. Thanks. Not pleased at all and will probably never come back.
I love this place. The dumplings are great. Waiters can be a bit pushy & I don't enjoy sitting with strangers and hearing x-rated convos about exes as I eat but other than that I love it !

Been here twice. Packed both times. Very busy in Chinatown but this was the only place we saw with a crowd of people waiting to get in. The soup dumplings are definitely a must. They are hot and difficult to eat but well worth the trouble. It's hilarious watching people try to figure out how to eat these things. Almost everyone orders them... The dish that bright me back was the Â Szechuan beef w/flat noodles. Similar to udon noodles. Not sure if they are homemade but they sure taste like it. Love em!!! Service is like a diner. You might wait for over an hour in a dirty alley to get in but people will put up with anything to eat here. Amazing food!
Delicious food. If you asked me to recommend a place to eat in Chinatown I would recommend this restaurant.

Soup dumplings are why you come here! Â We only had to wait 10 minutes for a seat on the Sunday lunch I was very pleasantly surprised. Â Fairly cheap food that is very good. Â We ordered the squid dish that was awesome! Â This place is great for a medium size group. Â I'll be going back after I try New Green Bo.
No comment
I stumble upon this place while I was visiting NYC. I order some food for to go, and it was some of the most amazing food that I had in NYC.
No comment

The nyc gold standard for xlb. Â My first bite completely scalded the inside of my mouth which was embarassing as 20 plus strangers are seated with you at a large table staring at each other, yet it was still delicious. Â  Wait was long but worth it.

So good. so good. soup dumplings. go and go again, until you can eat them right. :)

best. soup. dumplings. ever. great place...will always come back.

There's a reason why people wait inane for 3 hours to have dinner here. Fresh, delicious, tasty, great service. Ambiance is functional not romantic. If you are on a mission to get the best chinese meal in the United States-your mission begins and ends here.

Great Chinese! The soup dumplings are awesome! The general tso's is always crispy and spicy. The food is good through out the menu. The only problem I have with Joe's Â is that you have to share most times or if you ask to wait for a single table they always seem to give a stare because you don't want to sit with a bunch of strangers. That's my only real complaint about Joe's.

Overrated spot in Chinatown, if you're an out of towner there are better choices. I was disappointed from my eating experience. Be prepared to be packed like sardines because of the crowds. I don't think many in the "know" go here. I normally wouldn't choose a place like tis but I went with a friend. Never going back. I've been in NYC all my life, and have eaten in many of the area restaurants since a child.

Sat us down at a large table with strangers and pretty much immediately asked us what we wanted ... never being there, we just yelled out a bunch of dumplings and a couple of veggie sides (pretty much going with what people at our table got who had been there before)... dumplings were very good, everything else was just OK...stick to the dumplings and don't feel awkward about your table situation.

I'd call this incredible Chinatown landmark a "gem", but that implies that its relatively undiscovered. Legendary soup dumplings, authentic Chinese mixed with westernized fare is more than worth the wait in this cramped, communal dining room. Beware of soup-dumpling imposters- this is the real deal.

I came to Joe's Shanghai when I was in New York on vacation, and one of my friends insisted we go here for the best soup dumplings ever. Â Maybe I shouldn't have gotten my expectations up, but I did, and when I bit into it I was pretty disappointed. Â I never thought the soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung were anything that special until I ate this one. Â It didn't taste bad, but it didn't make me want to eat more of them. Â The meat chunk inside was a bit too large, and the soup was a bit oily. Â The flavor was a bit too pungent and pretty heavy. Â Also our other dishes weren't that great. Â We had the eggplant which was good, but I don't like when eggplant gets so soft it's unrecognizable as eggplant, and our pork/beef dishes (I don't even remember which one they were that unmemorable) were just so-so. Â Overall I was pretty disappointed. Â However, it was very cheap so that is a plus.

Just stopped by Joe's and noticed that it has a "B" health department rating. Â Thought you would want to know. Â It still has a line waiting to get in. Â I think I'll wait until it gets an "A". Â Too bad, I was looking forward to trying the dumplings.

4 star for their pork soup dumplings. Really liked those! Rest of the food was also good and the portion was adequate for two sharing one plate! However the concept of sharing tables with others was not appealing to me. Kinda looks weird when you feel people are looking at you while you eat! And the service was not prompt. For example, I find it difficult to use chopsticks and hence asked for a fork! That took almost 5 minutes for them to deliver! However, you do get authentic Chinese cuisine and I shall go back for their special dumplings :)
Pretty good but not worth it if it is a long line. We went on a weekday and the wait was about 15mins. Service is mediocre, typical Asian restaurant.
No comment
Excellent Chinese soup dumplings but nothing spectacular about the rest of the menu.

The soup dumplings here are overrated because they are not very good especially when compared to Nan Xiang Dumpling House's. The soup in the dumpling was thick and gooey and the skin was too thick. I ordered the ones with crab and they did not have the usual crab flavor that you would expect - very disappointing! The seafood pan fried noodles were even worse because they didn't even use the right kind of noodles - the thin yellow ones that are very crispy when fried. Instead, they used these thick whitish noodles that tasted so bad that we didn't even want to finish them. I don't understand why this restaurant is so popular. I went for lunch on a weekday but it was still very crowded.

I was a fan of the whole experience...as some other reviewers point out, this place is a little divey, you sit with strangers, and the waiters are pushy. BUT the dumplings are pretty tasty, the food comes out fast and the price is good. Dining here made me feel like i was on an episode of Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations. I'll definitely stop in on my next visit to NYC to try the crab,pork dumplings.
This is easily the best Chinese food I've ever had. Go with the soup dumplings and the orange beef, trust me. Don't forget to bring cash...no credit cards accepted.

Are u serious to give 5 starts for this trash restaurant? Food is OK. Service is garbage. Cash only. Tip is already included for every single bill regardless u asked or not. Just backing fire on travelers for easy money rather than working on better service and food. Please try other chinese restaurant before u have all NYC restaurants, please.

BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS (Xiao Loong Bao) IN NYC!! Everything else is average. I personally love the crab meat soup dumplings more than the regular pork one. When you're here, please say hi to my mom Elaine (the cashier) :)
Excellent food, terrible service. Â It says it is family friendly, but it really was not.

Honestly I've eaten more delicious xiao long bao/soup dumplings and I won't say theirs are the best I've ever had. Â BUT theirs are likely the best in the city. Â Compared to other soup dumplings you can eat elsewhere, theirs are more toward "Shanghai" style. Â I love their flavorful and juicy soup dumplings and I would recommend you to eat, especially the regular pork ones are good enough.

It's too touristy for me. I don't understand why every book is so in love with this place. The soup dumplings are not that great compared to some more authentic places in chinatown. I guess it's worth a visit for the hype but I wouldn't go back. The lines are always impossibly long? Why?

I ordered their dumpling which is a MUST order for shanghai restaurant, pretty good food but the service is average. The place itself is kind of crowded and I don't like the fact that i have to share table with someone else.

If you love dumplings, meeting new people and speedy in & out service, this is the place for you! Today we had the pork soup dumplings, General Tao Chicken & Shanghai noodles with my party of 3 and the bill was $40 with tip. The food is fast, looks and tastes delicious and the price point is fantastic -if you stick to water and tea which is complimentary. The seating arrangements allow you to meet new people (as you will be placed at a table with others) and find out about other great restaurants in NYC if you're lucky.

Hands down the best Chinese food ever! I was never a fan of Chinese food but my god Joe's Shanghais has changed it all. Â Problem is I live in Chicago and Joe's Shanghai is in NYC (Chinatown). Â I have been craving the food every night since I left NYC. Â If your in NYC you have to go here! Â They have banquet tables so don't be surprised if you have a small party you will be seated with people you don't know. Â Our experience was awesome and so fun! We sat at a table with a couple from Antigua and a NY native with his wife and son. They recommended what to order and we were not disappointed. Â The food is outstanding!

Waited in line for an hour just to realize they forgot about us. When we approached the seating staff, she insisted that we didn't have our whole party with us when we actually did. No apologies either. Sat us down with some random strangers, waiter delivered food without telling us who it was for. When the food came, it was horribly mediocre. Screwed up service and run of the mill food. With the long queue to boot, this place hardly deserves half a star from me.
No comment

their soup dumplings really deserves 5stars but I just couldn't bring myself to do it because every time I've been there, service has been so bad. host ignores you as soon as you walk in, so be aggressive about putting your name down. nevermind the long wait for a table, but when you do get one, expect to share it with three other parties. and by share, I mean CRAMPED next to because the waitstaff wont even let you leave an empty seat in between you and a complete stranger. im starting off with a lot of complaints, but the bottom line is, you have to try these soup dumplings. skin is incredibly thin, soup filled like no other, bursting with flavor, and soft melt in your mouth pork, atopped with crabmeat (i recommend highly you get the crabmeat ones). suck it up with the other nuisances because it's gonna be the best dumpling you've ever had.

Some will tell you that this place is riding on the coat tails of its former glory but I still love it. Yes there is typically a long wait and it is definitely touristy but it still holds a special place in my heart. The soup dumplings are really what you come for here. I've tried other things and it's always good but never memorable. Can you get good soup dumplings elsewhere? Yes but if the wait isn't insanely long I would absolutely try it out because they do the soup dumpling right

I don't know many other places where you can go to eat for $80 for a group of 7 people. The line was a bit crazy (lots of tourists and we waited 40 minutes on a Sunday at 7pm), but I'm really happy we waited! Our waiter was so sweet and helpful with vegetarian options.

I have dreams about Joe's pork soup dumplings. Holy bajeesus those things are good. I usually take friends from out of town there and nobody has been disappointed. Yummy scallion pancakes, and all their chicken dishes are bomb! All white meat, well cooked, and flavorful. I love the family style seating. The wait staff are efficient and patient with tourists. Definitely a Chinatown classic, and one of my favorite places.
Great soup dumplings, shanghai beef and everything else. Wonton soup is also quite delicious!
SOUP. DUMPLINGS. really really great...efficient service and a good late night meal, but as for the rest of the food, just decent. Not bad, just nothing to write home about.

The atmosphere is your typical busy and loud chinese restaurant. Â But that is part of the charm. Â I was skeptical about their famous dumplings but after having them I thought they were good. Â I prefer them without the soy sauce. Â As far as the other dishes are concerned, definitely very good. Â I would definitely visit again.

You've got to try the dumplings at Joe's Shanghai when you're in New York. They're pretty spectacular. Other than that, Joe's Shanghai is an authentic Chinese restaurant, unlike P.F. Chang's or those other Americanized Chinese chains that don't serve real Chinese food. Joe's Shanghai is where the Chinese and Chinese-Americans go to eat Chinese food.

Is it possible to say something good that hasn't been said about this place? Sure, it may be packed (packed being an understatement,) and there may be a long wait but it is definitely worth the wait. If you're looking for a safe, obvious choice go with the dumplings. You will not regret it one bit.

We came here for a late lunch. It was pretty packed but we got seated right away. I think the pouring rain outside worked in our favor. I would normally get this place 3 stars because I don't think the soup dumplings were amazing. I actually prefer the ones in Arcadia better, however the jumbo prawn was amazing and so was the string beans! Yums! I was a bit annoyed that they take cash only, specially because I has to run out in the rain without an umbrella to find an ATM. Will I be back? Yes, for the prawns!

Food is great. Could be cleaner. Hygiene is not their strong suit.

The line is always long, and there are very limited seats, so they put you with strangers at a table sometimes. Definitely something to keep in mind if that makes you uncomfortable. The soup dumplings are their signature items. I didn't care at all for the seafood soup dumplings, but the pork was alright. I've had better.

This is my spot. Soup dumplings all day. This place gets pretty packed on the usual days obviously. All types of people come here because it is that good. I come just for the soup dumplings only. Me and my gf order 3 orders and we always devour the crap out of it. The price is cheap and always leaving smiling and happy.

On our rare weekend free, we decided to grab some Chinese food in the City after failing to find much good Chinese food in the Jersey area we were living in. After hearing the recommendations from natives in the area as well as seeing the awesome reviews on Yelp, we ventured out that Sunday afternoon to see what all the hype was about. Maybe it was the fact that my expectations were too high (after all, my family is from Shanghai and I was just there that summer eating the most authentic of xiao long baos), but the soup dumplings at Joe's didn't impress me all that much. The soup inside was overly oily and they were just so large that it was a bit overwhelming. However, I do have to say that it's impressive that there was a spoonful of soup in each dumpling. We tried the pork and the crab ones...definitely go for the pork ones if you do decide to go. The crab ones were too ... I'm not sure what the word is in English ... but almost too fishy/seafoody tasting? We also got wontons and an eggplant dish which were pretty average as well. The next time I'm in the city, I'll probably be trying something new...

Every time I go to New York, I have to stop by this place. Â The pork dumplings are amazing due to the thick flavorful broth, tender pork, and fresh dough. Â However, you have to eat it fast (an order comes out with 8 for about $5) or else it'll get sticky and break apart when you lift it. Â I've tried several other dishes such as the lo mein and green onion egg cake, but both were nothing special. Â Expect a long wait, especially on the weekends and at dinner time. Â In my opinion, the soup dumplings are much fresher here than at their other location near 5th.
I mean what can I really add that hasn't already been added? Nothing! The food here is authentic and fabulous. I'll be dreaming of soup dumplings for the next week until I return! Hooray!

I was so excited to try soup dumplings in New York. Â It was worth the wait. Â The other dishes were good and being Chinese the dishes seemed pretty authentic to me, it just seemed really expensive for what we got. Â Guess that's what you get for eating in the city.
Joe's is loud, overcrowded with tourists, and the food is subpar in my opinion. There are far better places like New Green Bo to get "famous" soup dumplings. Joe's = yawn + eye roll.

Too much hype! I was really excited to try their famous xiao long bao, but I will have to agree with a bunch of other Yelpers that this place is overrated. Maybe it is just because I found the dumplings to be too flavorful and fatty. Â I must admit the dumplings had the most soup that I have ever seen inside a xiao long bao, but the soup got sickening. Â After a few I would bite the skin, and pour the soup out into a bowl. Eventuall I started only eating the skin and tossing the meat as well. Â The scallion pancake was good, but a little too doughy than what I am use to. Â Joe's Shanghai was a cheap meal compared to other eats in NYC, but I still wouldn't choose to revisit this establishment. Oh and being Chinese, of course, they seated us at a table with three other pairs of people. Â I like to be able to eat my food in the company of the people I came with, not strangers!

Soup dumplings to die for. Â I remember a blur of a meal with 15+ people scarfing down food after one of those Seaport shows, but there remains searing image burned into my gustatory retina of those killer soup dumplings. Â Slow-mo of (cue 70's porn music bow-chika-bow-wow): biting off the chewy dough of the top, slurping brothy goodness, spooning in dipping sauce and the revelatory goodness of that meaty center. Â Swoon.

The soup dumplings here are so f'n good! Â Just mentioning it on this review is making me want a batch of the pork and crab. Â The soup dumplings alone are the only reason for me to come to this place. Â The other food is pretty good too and even though there are a lot of tourists, the prices aren't that bad. Â Just docking one star because of the long wait for the table, especially during the weekends. Â And if you go with a fairly big group (mostly it's big groups there), it's harder to find a table and if you have tardy friends, good luck eating at the time you wanted to.
