Oy Vey! This place looks like a Subway station in rush hour...very loud and crowded and all the staff running around with plates and glasses. It was a quite of a great experience. The Â fried Pork Dumplings and the Onion Pork Soup Dumplings are to die for. Very good food! The staff were very fast but very courteous and helpful. I love the fact that you share tables and I was lucky to be surrounded by gorgeous Asian girls, the food tasted even more better looking at these beauties. I will come back. Totally recommended. Cheers or Ganbei!

Place is known for their soup dumplings but it's just another Chinatown locale. Â Just tasty, greasy, Chinese food. Â The place is fairly dirty, needs to clean up a bit but what do you expect for Chinatown! Â I would still recommend going there over other Chinese restaurants.
Extremely rude service! The food is not bad, but just ok, I've had better Shanghai food. I wish they would not take their customers for granted and that waiters would be more respectful.

Those mouthwatering dumplings are to die for! Out of all the restaurants in NYC, the infamous soup dumplings was the only dish my sister recommended...and remembered. So I had to come here. And finally! I get to say that there is an Asian dish that I can't get in the OC! At first, it was difficult to prop the dumpling on my spoon quickly enough before the soup seeped out of it. As I was devouring them one by one, I realized that this was my first meal at NYC! And I was so thankful that it was a memorable dish that I too, couldn't forget.

The main reason you should step food into Joe's is for the soup dumplings. Â they're very, very good. Â soupey, porky, savory, and delicious. Â Everything else is marginal. Â but seriously- why are you looking at the rest of the menu?

Down the alley known as Pell Street in Chinatown is Joe's Shanghai. Out of the three that exist in the city, this is the best of them all. A tourist trap - absolutely, but I have yet to taste a better pork soup dumpling in Manhattan. Is it really worth the 45 minute wait during dinner time, probably not since I think the soup dumplings here are just marginally better than some other Shanghai-nese restaurants such as Moon House, New Green Bo or Shanghai Cafe which have shorter waits.

Ahhh, Joe Shanghai. How I love you. Although every time I visit I forget that you're tucked away on Pell Street and inconveniently almost completely on the east edge of the island, when I arrive you never disappoint. Of course I'm not the first to write about your heavenly soup dumplings, but I will indulge the details of my own experience: I love the first bite that scalds my tongue, the delicious pork nugget that sits inside you like a pearl at the bottom of your floppy soup-filled pouch, the spiked tongs that i use to pluck you from your bamboo and lettuce lined palace, and the taste of the warm broth rushing into my mouth through the small chopstick size tunnel i poked in you. Yum.

Best soup dumplings I have ever had. Â Honestly, I have tried and tried to replicate their taste by ordering them at other restaurants, and I have never been able to. Â The best! Â Pork and Crab are the way to go. Â JUST DO IT.

Hands down the best soup dumplings this side of the Great Wall. Â I haven't, nor care to, try anything else there. Â They dumplings are pretty big and the order exactly fills my belly (and heart) with happiness.
No comment
No comment

Joes shanghai has the best soup dumplings I have ever tasted. I have tried their crab soup dumplings and their pork soup dumplings and both were AMAZING. This is the perfect thing to eat on a cold day. This is the perfect thing to eat on anyday. Inside the dumplings is liquid soup with crumbles of soft meat inside. It all, sort of, comes together in harmony once in your mouth. It is a must try, very memorable food that will create an experience that will last a life time.

If your come here order a number 1 or 2 thats what they are famous for. Dumplings have soup inside and are always cooked fresh comes with vegetables which I don't eat. If you plan on dining in make sure you havr reservation because the wait can be a while.

I give these five stars to what i've had at Joe's, and it's their xiao long bao's or steamed dumplings. The key is to wait for them to cool down a little, and eat the whole thing in one bite, if you let the juices flow, the dumplings aren't as tasty. I personally prefer the crab, but I've grown up with crab. I would recommend this place for a snack, and I would only recommend the dumplings, the place is so packed that you get crammed with other groups, it's nice just to dive in and out.

Joe's Shanghai is the closest you could go to Shanghai for lunch in NY. Start off your meal with some awesome appetizers like, soup pork dumplings and scallion pancakes. Then for main course, I highly recommend either the steamed spicy yellow tail (or deep fried yellow tail), its a whole fish that is served on your rotating table that is ready to be picked with chopsticks. In addition, I recommend singapore style chow fun which are basically vermicelli style noodles in curry sauce. To appease people who may not be adventurous in trying new foods, you could get kang pao chicken and eggplant in garlic sauce. However, I don't recommend beef with vegetables and jalapeÃ±os because the steak is not that great.
You end up sharing a table with random people and it is kind of chaotic. Â The soup dumplings were amazing since this was my first time. Â They only take cash so they lose one star.

I want to start of by saying, I didn't have the soup dumplings. But I did have the scallion pancake, which i'm Â completely in love with now and a shrimp noodle soup, which was very good. The best part of my experience here is the price to quantity ratio. My soup which was huge and is usually shared (but I didn't) was $4.95 and my scallion pancake (which again I didn't share) was about $2. 50. So ultimately I was stuffed and my wallet was still also.

Good service, and really good food for the price you pay. We ordered fresh bacon w/ preserved veggies (very nom), clams w/ blackbean sauce (nom nom too), string beans, snow pea leaves, and pan fried noodles (not so nom kinda greasy actually). Considering it's my first time in NYC, it was really good Chinese food and we were very satisfied with our meal..... also pork dumplings were delish
No comment

The best C rated restaurant in the city. If you can ignore the scarlet letter it's an adventure worth risking. Dumplings were delish, Tsing Tao was flat. For what it is it was good. Go for the dumplings and ignore the bathroom.
No comment

Most of the time, unless you go during off hours, you wait forever for a table, get seated next to slobbering strangers, then get rushed out the moment you're done with your last bite. But being treated like such crap has never felt so worth it because those soup dumplings are soooooo good. I've definitely eaten fourteen or fifteen in one sitting, which is kind of gross (but it felt so right at the time!). If you've never tried them yet, just get up and go now. They're like heaven in a bamboo steamer.
I love the soupy dumplings!!!! Â I don't come to NYC that often but when I do this place is a must go every time!
Great food and good find. A bit tight on the inside...
Fantastic spicy calamari in black bean sauce and steamed dumplings!!!
Soup dumplings and fried rice are good. Everything else on the menu was lacking, especially the beef noodle soup.

Went there the day before Thanksgiving. The soup dumplings are interesting and good AND everything else was terrible including the service. When I returned the pork dish because it literally was slices of fat covered with sugary sauce the waiters were rude and almost insulting. When I refused to pay for the dish, they became very aggressive. The soup dumplings aren't that good! Â I will never visit this restaurant again - EVER!
No comment

Love this spot! Â Some quick tips: Â Get Pork Dumplings, Shanghai noodles, and bring your own Saki! Â Get there early because the lines are out the door! This place is by far one of my favorite resturants in NYC!!

These soup dumplings will haunt you long after you have left those smelly, too-small, overcrowded streets of chinatown. Can't really speak to the other food, but if it was actually dog food aside these golden lilttle dumplings of heaven, it would still warrant a 5 star. Yeahyeahyeah- soup inside is hot and takes a college level course of its own to learn how to eat them, but isn't that part of the appeal?
No comment

As great as everyone says it is. Stay away from the noodles, and stick to the pork soup dumplings (xiao long bao). The pork/crab ones are also not bad, but not as good. Don't expect to have a table to yourself. Expect a long wait in a smelly alley and to share a table with tourists.
Like everyone else, I was blown away by the dumplings. Some locals will say it's too touristy. Disregard!

It's a pretty basic restaurant . We had the 1/2 duck, noodles, and dumplings. Duck was salty and they serve it with salt on the side! Noodles had some nice big spinach on top which was great. The dumplings interior was very dense and couldn't really enjoy it.

Soup dumplings remain exceptional...but service has deteriorated from casual to downright sloppy and inattentive. Â When we finally received the food we actually ordered, we found the quality poor. Â Joe's is no longer the special destination we looked forward to.

Favorite Dim Sum restaurant of all time!You have to wait 15-20 mins to get in as the line is long, but it moves fast. Amazing food. Fantastic prices. Fast and furious table service. Fun shared tables. Just a great experience all round.

Tucked away in an alley. Â They seated our small party at a large communal table so we got seated without a wait and met some other nice people. Â The others were regulars. Â The beef noodle soup was good and were the dumplings. Â The dumplings were nothing like DIn Tai Fung, but acceptable and cheap. Tip is included, so don't add another unless you want to!
No comment
The crab & pork soup dumplings are simply the best in the US! Worth every second of the hour + wait outside. There would still be an hour wait if they only had those 2 things on the menu! G.O.A.T.!!!

Tis true the soup dumplings here are amazing. I don't even like crab but I found the pork and crab dumplings to be superior. The rest of our food was fast and delicious as well. It's very easy to over order but it all taste delicious the next day too. Very quick service but they manage their wait like your at a deli counter so that may be a little overwhelming. It's a no frills place but the food is worth it. Be prepared to wait awhile (at least 40 min) because the word is out on Joe Shanghai's. You will also sit at a table with other people and you will wait pretty long if you are with a big party. Great place to bring someone who is visiting New York and wants to try something yummy in Chinatown.
There's insect in the food!!!!!! And terrible handling services. Food taste great but just dirty as hell

I had no idea how many people had yelped/raved about this place before going in. It was cold, I was in Chinatown, and all I wanted was some soup. So I followed some locals into this place to try it out. This was quite possibly the best shrimp noodle soup I've ever eaten. The shrimp was perfectly cooked and fresh, and they didn't skimp on the shrimp. The vegetables were fresh and also perfectly cooked. Â I will dream about this soup on many a cold day.

Pork soup dumplings are virtually identical to pork and crab, so don't both with the crab. Â  Shanghai noodle with beef are also delicious. Â Salt fried pork chops are not worth it. Â Cheap and delicious.

now i know why many single people go there just to eat the shao long bao and nothing else. Â the dumplings are excellent, on par with the ones i tried in toronto (had metal tongs, lots of soup inside, tasty); you should eat them and go and try other restaurants nearby cuz the others just stink. Â maybe the scallion pancake is worth it, but that's about it: 2 things very well done.

the soup dumplings, period. Â if you only want soup dumplings, then heres your place. Â if you dont care about sitting next to strangers or getting mediocre service that push you out as fast as possible, then come here. Â luckily, most people only care about that because its always crowded. Â best soup dumplings around. Â tried a few other places too, but nope not as good. Â besides those, they have a really tasty pan fried noodle. Â great taste. Â so come for a quick great meal and maybe even meet a few strangers who have the same crave for a yummy soup dumpling. Â a side note, the joes shanghai on fifth ave is terrible! way more expensive and food isnt as good. Â only go to this location in chinatown. Â cash only tho.

Joe's Shanghai is bombtastic. My only complaint would have to be that they need to expand more, and have a larger restaurant. This place is so good. I've had plenty of XLB but wow it was my first time eating the crab ones. I was pretty mind blown. Only advice I'd give when eating soup dumplings is to be careful because it's really hot and they burst relatively easy. It's a must for me to go here everytime I hit up NYC.

There is a major lack in the authenticity of their cuisine. Â Many of the standard Shanghainese dishes aren't even offered. We ordered the snow cabbage and shredded pork noodle soup. Â The broth was awful. The soup filled dumplings were mediocre.

This place is SO BUSY! I went there with friends at 2:30pm on a Friday and waited for about 30 minutes outside. I like the soup bums, especially the crab meat with pork steamed ones. Six soup bums are enough for a girl. It only cost us about $7.5 per person for that meal including taxes and tips. The restaurant calculated the taxes and tips (15%) for the customers.

YOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOoo this place is super cheap and super good! I recommend going here if you love green onion pancakes and xiaolongbao. It is a small restaurant tho and realllly crowded so don't be surprised if you have to sit at a big table with randos. That's what happened to me and my sister but hey they seemed like a friendly family who obviously didn't know what to order because they got fried noodles. WHY. NONONONO. Anyways the other family across from us got kungpao chicken and fried rice so i guess that's not any better. Anyways service was fine and the food came out decently fast. This place is cash only so be prepared! It's not expensive tho so you should be fine. The restaurant doesn't seem that nice from the outside but the inside is cozy and feels very typical chinese which is obvious since it IS in CHINATOWN. Get the xiaolongbao and green onion pancakes for you will not REGRETTTT. Get the pork ones okay no questions asked. Chinese love pork.

I went there my first night in NYC. It was great. If you look for an intimate place you better go to another restaurant cause they offer large circle tables. Thus several people can sit around one table. The food is really good! It's definitely a place to good with friends and enjoy real Asian food!
Pork Soup Dumplings. They were so uh-maze-balls. And the pork jalapeno dish along with their regular dumplings were also superb. Ugh I'm getting hungry now. Just try those, you wont be disappointed.
you cannot ever go wrong with these dumplings. Grade A delicious. My only thing about this place is the food is not always consistent, however it is still good.
the soup dumpling is the best...others is ok and the service made me speechless...by the way 15ï¼ tips wtf!!!

I usually get the pork soup dumplings and the scallion pancake. Â The soup dumplings are consistently delicious but the scallion pancake can be greasy. Oh well they're still pretty good anyway. Â Its in flushing pretty close to the muni lot. Â I've been there for lunch a few times and leave super full but happy from the dumplings.

I was visiting from LA and was passing by and decided to stop in and get one tray of soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. I wasn't that impressed. My NY friends to me this place was better than Din Tai Fung, but I didn't love it. The soup felt greasy. The pancakes were too "bready". We wished it were crispier. Overall service was good and there was no wait, always a good thing.

The brazed Duck was amazing! I wish the place was less popular, the wait to get in on a Friday night for 4 people was an hour. We ordered the pork dumplings, sesame chicken and a noodle dish. Everything was fresh and delicious.

So far these guys have the best xiao long bao that I have tasted. Get the crab ones for a little bit more flavor. The skins are solid on top to facilitate grabbing, and stretchier on the bottom for texture. Soup is really, really tasty. The only problem is I got some crab shell pieces in one of my dumplings. They were so small they could be crunched away, but it still wasn't 5-star perfect because of that. The price is great for a place that knows it is so famous and can probably get away with adding $2 or $3 to every plate. Wish they were in SF!
The best soup dumplings. Â Be sure to try the crab ones. Â Delicious! Â Please be careful when you bite into one...they are crazy hot...don't want a lawsuit for a burnt tongue.

The best dumpling soup ever. I ordered the scallion pancakes and dumpling soup (8 piece per order). You won't be disappointed. It was heaven! Small restaurant and you share tables with others. The food comes out fast. Other dishes were good as well like the seafood fried rice cakes. By the way, don't expect any good service here... It's a Chinese restaurant! LOL
No comment

Best (Xiao long bao) soup dumplings I've had anywhere and blows LA's Din Tai Fung out of the water. Expect a wait. Expect chaotic (but organized) service. Be open to sharing a round table with strangers. Their regular pork soup dumplings are the best. The crab and pork ones are good too but can sometimes have a fishy taste. I have but usually don't order other Chinese dishes on their menu since the dumplings make a great meal on their own. Worth the wait! This is a repeat visit resto for me, and the quality has remained consistent over the years.

Returned to Joe's after an 8-month hiatus and my love for this restaurant remains unwavering. Our wait for 9 people wasn't too bad for a Sunday evening (approximately 30 minutes). We had a really funny waiter who helped us pick entrees (as I'm always at somewhat at a loss for what to order other than the soup dumplings and green beans Szechaun-style, especially when I'm put on the spot to order for the table by my darling father). The pork soup dumplings were delicious as always. Other dishes we had that were really good - scallion pancakes, sliced beef with jalapeno, pork fried rice, prawns in chili sauce (though it's not really a chili sauce and more of a sweet sauce), kung pao chicken, and water spinach. Not a fan of the curry noodles so I wouldn't recommend that. Oh and good to know: it's cash only.
Fabulous! Â Gotta stop here and make sure and order the soup dumplings!

You know what you're here for. You're here to inquire about the soup dumplings. It's like famous, right? You heard about it from your friends, a local, on tv, or somewhere on the internet. Well, I'm pretty sure at this point you already made your decision so if you're here, you already have the address. Just know that it comes in trays of 8 and cost like... $5. You have the crab or pork option. Honestly, nobody cares about the other items on the menu. They're just there to make the restaurant not look like a dumpling place. Come here and get some soup dumplings.

The soup dumplings are AMAZING. Shanghai noodles are also good, and the cabbage with black mushroom. I've never had a dish here I didn't like. The midtown location is prettier, of course, but Pell Street is the way to go. In midtown you get six dumplings per basket; in Chinatown you get eight, and they seem fresher. Plan to wait in line outside the restaurant, and plan to be seated at a large table with other parties.
This place blew my mind and changed everything I thought I knew about Xiao Long Bao's

They make one of the best soup dumpling I ever had! It is soooo good. However, I always need to share the table but the taste totally make sharing the table worth it. I usually don't go during rush hour so I never had to wait long. The price is reasonable and location is convenient.
No comment
No comment
The best soup dumplings anywhere. The crab version is awsome. My family always eat at Joes Shanghai when visiting NYC. Gave only 4 stars because we had not tried any other dishes with all our visits.
No comment
No comment

A good place for soup dumplings. You know it's authentic because of the curt service and grimy environment. It's good for a quick and dirty meal. I personally don't really care for soup dumplings because the soup tastes so fatty and gelatinous, but I think they're one of the better ones.
No comment
The XIAO LONG BAO is so good!!! I went there with my coworkers after work and had the best XIAO LONG BAO in manhattan.. :) Their service is fast and their dishes are really authentic.. I LOVE IT!!!!

Price v. performance this place is amazing. Â I went to the place rather late, but still had to wait a while for a table. Â The XLB were nice and juicy, and their green onion pancake had a really good flavor. Â I grew up with chinese food, yet this place still stands out. Â It was a bit greasy, yet so good. Â I have to say it's probably one of the cheapest and juiciest XLB that I've had, it almost offends me when I see people poke a hole in the bun and drain them of their succulent juices. Â That is just wrong, they are missing out on the best part, and one of the attributes that sets Joe's XLB apart from other restaurants. Â Definitely a must order for anyone who visits.

Was not blown away. I liked the potato pancake. I would get that again. There are no vegetarian options for the soup dumplings, just so you know. They are all about efficiency and getting the most customers in at a time instead of service. It's pretty comical the extent they will go to get the customers inside. I waited for 45 minutes with a number. It was crazy. Potato pancake, yum. Wish I could it to-go to avoid the wait and service drama.
Crab soup dumplings! Shanghai noodles! Green beans! This place hit the spot after a 6am kinda night. Fresh, hot, & not too greasey.

Very yummy soup dumplings, which is what I came here for. However, I discovered my favorite was actually their noodles (forgot the name, but there were vegetables in it). Absolutely delicious! Just wish I could've been seated at my own table instead of with strangers. The decor and service weren't good, but what can you expect from Chinatown?

My friend, who is from China, took me here for soup dumplings. Â It was right after the New Year parade, so it was crowded and there was a wait. Â We sat at a communal table, and things were a bit rushed. Â But that's understandable. Â We got crab and pork and just pork dumplings. Â They were delicious. Â I had never had them before and didn't know how to eat them, but my friend showed me how. Â Now I'm a huge fan!
SOUP DUMPLINGS are the BIZNESS here!! droooooool.............
No comment
No comment

I've said this before, but let's say 3.5. Â Chinese food was pretty run of the mill for what I'm used to in NY/NJ. Â We got the pork fried rice and the sesame chicken. Â Nothing too adventurous. Â The main thing that gets me to the 4 star rating is the soup dumplings. Â Delicious and unique. Â Not the finest service or decor in the land, but about what you'd expect at an affordable Chinese place. Â Will definitely be back.

Do you eat pork? Do you like dumplings? Are you near Chinatown? Yes? Go to Joe's Shanghai, order some pork soup dumplings, and experience bliss. There are better places for Chinese food in NY, so just stick to the dumplings.

We lined up for over 40 minutes to be served. We ordered soup dumplings, baby shrimp, beef and vegetable. It is fair to say only the taste of soup dumplings and vegetable could be accepted from a Chinese point of view.
No comment
No comment

Best soup dumplings I've ever had. The restaurant is family style, so your party shares a table with other people. It sometimes takes a while to be seated, but service is fast once you do sit down. It's best to know what you want to order by the time your server gets to you for the first time -- the place has a busy, chaotic vibe.
Long wait outside (40+ mins in a Friday evening). Lovely dumplings (pork were best). Colorful service (brusque but comical). Great price. Green beans were tasty, fried chicken was okay.
No comment

On a rainy night in the city, this was definitely a great stop. There was a short wait, and you may have to share your table with strangers, but sucking the broth from those pork dumplings was awesome. Is this place better than Din Tai Fung in Cali...not quite, but close. Their dumpling were a bit too thick skinned for me, yet they are larger in size. Also, the meat mixture in Din Tai Fung's is better, and at Joe's, they don't have the red vinegar with ginger.
No comment

I found this place a few years ago from a friend and have been going back ever since. Every time I am in town I stop in for some soup dumplings. I haven't had anything else here so I cant talk about that but the soup dumplings are the best I have had. Oh bring cash cause that's all they take.
No comment

Not to be a downer, but maybe soup dumplings are just not my thing. Tried two varieties of XLB as well as the green onion pancake and thought it was pretty good but nothing special. Nice to say that I've tried it, but not crave-worthy.
Came here with three other people and had an obscene number of xiao long bao. They were pretty juicy, but not as delicate as I'd like them to be.

Place is definitely over hyped. Â Yes, they have extremely good soup dumplings, but let's also judge this place for other things. Â The place is crowded and packed like a sardine can. Â It's noisy. Â The waiters rush the heck out of you. Â Aren't you here paying for the whole experience? Â So why is it I feel like the one that must bend over backwards to get some service? Â Remember, you are the paying customer, not part of their, "they get rich, you get out asap," plan. Â The decor started out nice, but is really in the need of a make over now. Â  As for the other food here, it's okay, nothing above the other area establishments. Â The price is slightly higher than the area competition.
Well known with good food. Felt rushed.

Awesome dumplings and scallion cakes. We got some noodles too and they were delicious. I would suggest going at an unpopular time to limit your wait. However, if you have to wait, please note that it's worth it. The food is really cheap and it's delicious. Service was good enough and the overall experience was fun. Everyone should check this place out.

Our go to place when in Chinatown. Â The soup dumplings are quite delicious and filling and the scallion pancakes are quite possibly the best I've ever had. Â Even though I'm not a huge fan of communal sitting, the food and the prices are what always have me coming back!
Go... either location ( Pell or 35 Pell). I like the 35 Pell better. Good greasy soupy dumplings. Try them today!

Joe's Shanghai has a been one of my favorite places for many years. Â I just went this week and was surprised when my favorite, soupy dumplings tasted awful. Â They were Â filled half way with some oily brown broth not there usual delicious tasting yellowish broth. Â The crab/pork filling well lets just say I would question whether it was crab/pork. Â It was pretty bad. Â The worst of it was that I took friends who also ordered it (because I bragged so much about them) and they couldn't even eat one. I tried to eat them anyway and after the 2nd one I through all of them out. Â Very disappointing. Â I'm hoping the Chef was just having a bad day.

Of course the downside of this place as many people come to realize is the rudeness of the waiters and management but we all keep coming back because the food is good. My friends and I do a monthly soup dumpling outing to Joe's because it's just the best comfort food. And its cheap!
No comment
Super delicious Xiao Loong Baos (dumplings filled with soup base and shrimp and crabmeat). Had a great meal here and very reasonable/cheap prices. Had a short wait but was well-worth it.

...man these are some awesome tasting XLB (Xiao Lung Bao) that my tongue has to thank me again and again long after we left the restaurant. The place is hella noisy, crowded and minimum customer service but that's the Chinese way. 5 stars regardless as the food is what this place is famous for, and it does its food good justice.

Yes, I went there as a tourist, but I'd highly recommend it! Â A total must for anyone visiting. Â The dumplings were awesome! Â The other people at our table got a deep-fried fish that looked so delicious. Â I wish we'd gotten that too. Â We also had some type of scallion pancake - also super yummy. Â The only thing I didn't like was the beef and veg dish - I think it was picked or something and it was too salty.

On a cold winter's day, there's nothing better than some decently priced Asian comfort food to warm you up like Joe's Soup Dumplings. This is the only reason I go to Joe's - because they are usually really busy, and the tables are pretty cramped. If you go during a busy hour (like dinner) and are a small party, you could be seated with another group of people at their shared, common round tables. It's the only way they can keep their queue moving...but if you don't feel obliged to talk to your neighbors (IF this happens to you), then it's totally worth it once those Soup Dumplings hit your belly.

I was so excited to try this place after friends have raved about it. Â After trying the pork and crab dumplings, I was pretty disappointed. Â Maybe I just had high expectations, but with as many reviews as this place got, I expected better. Â Oh well, I guess I gotta go to Shanghai one day.
No comment

If you're a fan of xiao long bao -you just can't go wrong here. often a bit too busy -I stopped in late with 6-8 people and completely demolished the place. If you will picture stacks of soup dumplings so tall that you can't see the people on the other side of the table -I wish i was exaggerating. Â The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that the soup inside can, at times, have a touch or two more vinegar/taste of vinegar than I'm used to. Â Beyond that, it's usually an excellent stay -the other items on the menu are just a bit better than average.

The soup dumplings are to die for. My girlfriends kept telling me how good they were but I'm more of person that has to see things with my own eyes. I was absolutely shocked and pleased by how tasteful the dumplings were and the price. I didn't want to move after I finished. Joe's Shanghai is a must in Chinatown.
No comment

I have to say I haven't been to this place in a while so this review is probably not as relevant as others. Â I've been to this location many times and I've always been impressed with their food. Â It's simple Shanghainese. Â Sure the wait staff is rude but it's NYC and wait staff are rude in Shanghai too. Â The dumplings were always delicious and fresh. Â Bring cash since they don't accept CC.

I wish I lived in NY just so I could eat here every weekend. By far the best Chinese food I've ever had. You won't be dining in for the experience or the ambiance but the food makes up for it tenfold! You walk in, take a number for the hostess, and wait outside. Don't be frightened by the amount of people waiting outside, our wait went by really fast. (10 minutes or so). You sit at a table with other diners so there won't be any privacy. We ordered the scallion pancakes, pork dumplings, and shanghai noodles. All were AMAZING! It was my first time at a restaurant like this so my bf and I didn't know the way to eat the dumplings. You place them in the soup spoon so that the broth ends up in the spoon instead of your plate. Mmmmm they were sooo delicious!!! I hope to go back the next time I'm in NY!

Came in for xiaolongbao because the place is famous. Â People are right : tourist trap!! Â The service is poor. Â My friend and I were seated at a large table with strangers. Â We were not given the option to wait for a private table. Â Before we had a chance to look at the menu, the waiter barked at us about "soup dumplings" (apparently, everyone comes for the xiaolongbao). Â We ordered the standard pork/crab combination, as well as an order of mapo tofu (called something like "home style spicy Szechuan bean curd"). Â The xiaolongbao were decent, but just decent. Â No need to write home. Â Grand Sichuan's are clearly better, soupier, and tastier. Â The mapo tofu was bland, not spicy at all, very little taste. Â Had a generic feel to it. Â Again, Grand Sichuan's mapo is much, much better--tastier, earthier, spicier.

Soup dumplings were the best. It was the right amount of soup and meat. The crispy duck was tasty. The quail app was a little dry. There's already a 15% gratuity added no matter what. Don't over tip if you don't want to.

SOUP DUMPLINGS!!!! Â why do they not have these in miami. Â Its a huge shame. Â Breaking into them and watching the steam pour out is like fluffy clouds in heaven. Â I haven't had them anywhere else but I don't need to. This place speaks english, is clean, moves quickly and is CHEAP.
No comment

If you are in New York's Chinatown and need a place to experience the best ever soup dumplings head over to Joe's Shanghai on Pell Street. Â Amazing, fresh, hand-made daily little yummy parcels of pork and crab broth filled dumplings are to die for! Â Just heave these and maybe some green beans or rice cakes as a side. Â Be careful not to burn your mouth as the scalding hot broth escapes onto your spoon. You won't be disappointed! Expect a wait of up to an hour though but that's all part of the fun. Speak to your fellow devotee's as you wait to get inside. Cash only, no cards or debit.

Very juicy xlb. I liked them a lot; Â it was good . The restaurant filled up quick, we arrived before they open and had to line up outside the store . I didn't try anything else just one order of pork and one of crab to go since it was almost time for us to check out of the hotel. Â After we walked back to the hotel, the xlb were still steamy hot. Â I will come back for more next time I visit NYC.
No comment
This place is great. It's not fancy at all, but if you are just looking to sit down and have some tea, dumplings, and soup then this is a good place to go. I felt like I was in Hong Kong again.
No comment

This is a well-known restaurant for Soup Dumplings, so there will always be a long line outside waiting for a table. If you come in a small group, most likely you will end up sharing a table with some people. I didn't think their soup dumplings were that great. Â They were VERY greasy. Also, I don't like the seating arrangements. Another issue we encountered was that we found TWO HAIRS in our food (and in separate dishes)!. One thick greasy hair was in the center of our rice cake dish, and another one was actually WRAPPED INSIDE of a soup dumpling. Â It was gross! We won't eat in here again.

CASH-ONLY! Push your way up to the waitress, get your name on the list, wait 5 minutes, and be seated at a table with others already with their mouths full, and say "YES!" to SOUP DUMPLINGS - one of each! Two layers will come out and they'll teach you how to slurp these surprising dim sum yummmmmmms. It's super cheap and super packed. Yum yum!

Everything was good but nothing to rave over. Apparently this place draws in a huge amount of foot traffic and we just happen to go through on a snowy weekday so seating was a cinch. Crispy duck was crispy, the soupy dumplings were strange but pretty good, and the green onion pancake was fluffy. Recommended by several frequent NYC visitors and I now know why but my next visit might only be if I happen to be by Chinatown.

BEST Soup dumplings eveeeeeeeeeeeer ! The price is pretty good too ^_^. The noodles and rest of there food that they serve are pretty decent. Well this spot is known for soup dumplings anyways. It cost about $5 for 8 soup dumplings. Def worth the money. MUST TRY IT !!! (:

A totally unnecessary review since Joe's is (in)famous, but just to put it in writing: sit down, don't ask many questions (prepare to feel rushed/confused), but order so many soup dumplings. Rinse and repeat. Joe's is perfect.
For me the best soup dumplings Â ever ever and soooo cheap. Place is only simple but you don't go here for that go for the soup dumplings then go further for some other Chinese if you are not full

There's always an annoying wait, but the soup dumplings are WELL WORTH IT. Also all the sides, and the free tea, and all the other food. Make sure you eat the food you order though, awkward mixups have happened with table neighbors. Hopefully they're friendly like you!!!
The soup dumplings are great (but only the pork), and everything else is sub-par. Have been twice, and that's once too much.

Extremely bad food and bad service. It is not worth the wait. They gave us table for two next to a dust bin - this is not how you treat customers who wait for an hour. The food was not cooked well and priced high

Was greeted in the beginning by a nice young lady. As soon as we hit the table the service was bad, poor customer service and the food was mediocre. For having so many celebrities here I was surprised.
No credit cards accepted. Â Very good but small place. Â You will be seated at a table with other people. Â The food is very authentic and good. Â Prices are reasonable.

Joe's Shanghai on Pell St. on Sunday night with six friends. Mobbed. We were told 20 minute wait for table--we waited 45 minutes and got seated with two strangers who hogged the table. Obnoxious servers who declined to offer any hints or suggestions from their multi-page menu. We each ordered different dishes with intrnt to share, but soup, appetizers and main dishes arrived all at the same time making it impossible to try to share anything. Waiters brought stacks of bowls and plates which we passed around the table. Empty dishes remained uncollected which made the table more of a garbage can than a place from which to eat food. Requests for tea refills went unanswered as did rÃ¨quests for water. Food was serviceable but nothing memorable. The din and crowd noise was headache level. Of course no credit card service and our individual checks were written in pencil on scraps of note paper. None of the waiters was able to decipher the bill or tell us the cost for individual items. So our group of seven got ripped off to the tune of more than $350. Mediocre food, absolutely the worst service since the Soviet Union went out of business. With at least a dozen superior restarants within a five minute walk I am totally baffled by the rave reviews for this unremarkable at best second rate dive.
This place is awesome. Shared a table. Good sized portions. Definitely get dumplings. Super busy and a small wait but you'd expect that with such great food.
Delicious chinese food. i love their soup dumplings & the mu shu pork

Came here for the soup dumplings which were quite good! Â Can't review anything else because that's all I ate...and quite a bit of it I might say. Â Will definitely return here on my next visit to NYC.
No comment
No comment
The best crab and pork soup dumplings ever! It's a must if you're ever in chinatown. They also have a very good onion pancake. There's always a line, so be patient, it's really worth it!
No comment
Soup dumplings are great, but the mandatory 15% tip + tax "for my convenience" is a little telling. I still like shanghai cafe better because they have bubble tea.

Dude, I hate to say this, but I think this spot is overrated. Â After many rave reviews from friends, I went way out of my way to eat here during my last visit to NY. Â Braved the weather and the wait for some very good but not spectacular soup dumplings. Â Places like these are kind of a dime a dozen here in California. Â Though the dumplings at Joe's are huge and soup-y, more so than I've encountered before which was cool, I don't know if I'd go out of my way again.

I enjoyed my first visit here. Â It was hard to eat the soup dumpling but its a fun experience trying to figure it out. Â It was definitely yummy! Â We also had a beef/scallion dish that was good and my friends sesame chicken was yummy. Â We shared a table with others, not a big deal. Â You go for the dumplings and the experience. Â Try a massage while you are down there! Â Might as well! Â So cheap!

The soup dumplings at Joe's Shanghai have a pretty thick skin. They're also not made very well, so the little twist you usually get on top of the dumpling forms a big, chewy knot of dough. Maybe you like that. I don't. The filling inside isn't spectacular either- I think they overfill the skins, so that by the time you get your dumplings, most of them have already burst and all the soup has leaked out. Joe's is pretty overrated, IMO. I'll stick with Shanghai Cafe- it's cleaner, brighter and cheaper.
No comment
No comment

one word. Â OILY! Â everything OILY!! the din tai fung in LA is wayyyyy better. Â the leaking soup in each dumpling was cool but the taste was OILY! Â wasnt' satisfied at all so we went to the halal cart within the next hr and pigged out on a gyro & rice dish. and then, THAT hit the spot. we had to wait an hour for a table,which we shared with two other couples. suuuuper crowded and for what? some oil... i had to drink hot tea to oil it down.
No comment
Hmm...I'm not sure if I just had high hopes or if we came on an off night. I really was not wowed by their xlb or their other dishes. Â Everything was ok but not impressive.

There is a shainghai dumpling place 6 blocks from my house in SF which I absolutely love so I couldn't wait to try Joe's. I was planning on going to the midtown branch, but after consulting yelp I decided Chinatown would be a better choice. The wait staff is snippy and all the tables are family style so you get seated with lots of strangers but I didn't even care because the pork shainghai dumplings are so effing good. The broth is really meaty and flavorful and the sauce it comes with compliments it perfectly. We also got the pan fried vegetable noodles which were incredible. The noodles were light and crunchy, the sauce was garlicky and thick and it was filled with lots of fresh veggies. Plus the bill came to $18 for a filling meal for 2 people. I think I'd be happy repeating that lunch every day of my life.

This place had good xiao long bao and shanghainese style fried noodles. The xiao long bao tastes a bit like they were frozen and then thawed, but overall, tasty. Would reccomend you check this place out if you have some free time.

This place is usually packed with a diversity of people from all over. Their hottest item on the menu is the juicy pork buns. Today I got to try some of the items on their menu and were not very crazy about most of them. I guess the only dish, besides the pork buns, I would have again is the pan fry noodles.

The soup dumplings here make me so happy. The wait to be seated is usually long. You're not going to get top notch service here, this isn't a fancy place. You may even get seated with complete strangers. But when those steam trays come out with your dumplings, everything is right with the world. They are flavorful and just damn good. I could eat a whole tray of these by myself. The green beans and green onion pancake are also solid menu items.

Got to say I was looking forward to eating here with my friend Michele from China who's choice it was to come here. Â We bothwere not so impressed, I didn't lead on that I wasn't enjoying the food though, didn't want to ruin the date. Â The dumplings kept falling apart before they got to our mouths, they then brought out the wrong steamed fish and the pork dish wasn't up to par as well. Â We should have stuck with the wrong fish bc the white fish that they finally got right wasn't good at all. Â Very disappointed, the saving grace of the night was walking around the block for ice cream at The Original Chinatown Ice Cream Factory...yummmmm...

I come here for the soup dumplings when I'm in NYC. But, it is always pretty crowded and hard to get in at night. Be prepared to wait in line and you usually have to share a table.

Juicy soup dumplings are perfect for snacking in between your meals while bustling through the crowd on Canal Street. Four stars only because of the long wait (sometimes) and not so good service. Dumplings are good. I'd rec the crab instead of the pork. It's cash only. I've tried other dishes and they are decent so stick with the dumplings.

My girlfriend is not going to like my review because she thinks this is four stars but you know what I didn't like it that much. Â I didn't dislike it, I just thought it was okay. Â The pork dumplings with crab soup were tasty but the veggies had some black stuff on there which made me question what was it. Â The noodles I ordered weren't great, it was just okay, and that is why I am giving it three stars. Â There isn't much more I can say.

I LOVE LOVE LOVE shanghai dumplings! I haven't had good shanghai dumplings since my go-to shanghai restaurant shut down a few years ago back in the bay area. I was so excited to try their dumplings after reading the yelp reviews. We ordered the shanghai dumplings, fried bean curd, vegetarian duck & shanghai noodle soup. This place is sooo cheap! The meal was about $23 for all we ordered! Everything was good!!

Not too shabby for a touristy spot, but I was expecting more. The soup dumplings (xiao long bao) from Shanghai Dumpling King in SF are better. Joe's are bigger, the skin thicker, and the meat felt more processed. Their kung pao chicken, however, was decent. (I know what you're thinking.. minus credibility points for ordering this, but don't judge until you try it!)
The biggest xiao long bao I've ever seen! Â It's great because there's more soup to slurp out of the dumpling. Â The dumplings themselves make a trip here worth while!
It was everything we hoped for and more. We were craving soup dumplings, and soup dumplings we had. Cheap, tasty, and relatively healthy.

i went here because a friend told me of this place, i went in and it was kinda busy, i was sat away at a table. i was by myself so it was kind of awkward. i ordered the scallion pancake and the pork dumplings. both were really delicious. i lost my money and they were nice enough to tell me where an atm was and let me go get that money. i'd go back here.

Last fall I took a trip to NYC with my wife and friends and we had the best soup dumplings. First time I've ever try something like this and it was fantastic. I don't know how they got the wrap to hold the soup inside of it but once you bite into it, it burst out hot tasty soup. I think once you've eaten here, i don't think you want to try any other soup dumplings elsewhere. It was so good we went back to get some more the next day. Make sure you go to the one in Chinatown, it's cheaper than the one near 5th avenue. Â Also, their green onion pancakes are amazing. Reviewed by BN.

I personally thought this place was over-rated but a good value. Â The soup dumplings were large but not as delicious as i've had in other places. Â The fried noodles were pretty good. Sharing a table wasn't too fun, but not horrible.

This place is best known for the soup dumplings. The waiters are shocked if you don't order them. If you do wish to have them get them immediately upon sitting down as they take a bit of time to cook. The soup dumplings here are quite good and I really liked them until I had the crab filled soup dumplings at Shanghai Gourmet. They are even better. The remainder of the food here isn't very memorable, but not bad and certainly well priced.

Another amazing Chinese food in the New York City. Â Thank you all, you Yelpers! Â Being 2 days new in the city, we had to rely on Yelp search and reviews for great restaurant. Â After the finding of Prosperity Dumpling, Yelp did it again. Â We were pleased with what we have ordered; two cold plates, scallion beef, shrimp and pork wonton soup, and this amazing soup dumplings. Â I look forward to my next visit at Joe's Shanghai!

Everytime i head back to NY I always try to squeeze in a lunch at Joe Shanghai. I'd say that other items on their menu are ok, but the xiao long bao are good. Cash only establishment & you'll prob have to wait a while to share a table with someone else, which is why i took off a star.
No comment

If you are looking for some authentic chinese food that is easy on the wallet but fills you up, Joe Shanghai is the place to go. Every time my friends and family came to visit me in New York, I took them here. Â For three people you can spend less than 20 dollars and the food quality is very good. Â Their popular dish there is the pork soup dumpling, which is about 6 dollars for 10. Â My favorite is the pork and crab soup dumpling. which is about 8 dollars for 10. Â But these little suckers are so filled with flavor and the meat inside is so tender. Â The only reason why I gave this place a 4 star and not a 5 is because this place can get very very crowed and sometimes you have to share tables with strangers which is a little weird for me.

Love this place! One of my must go to places in NY for their stream soupy dumplings. Â This place always have a long line, but they work fast and it's cheap! Â Can't beat it! Â If you're new to NY, I would highly recommend this place...it's so popular...it comes up on google maps when u're looking at the area.

Didn't see what was so special about this place that warranted the reviews it is getting. The service sucked and was rude ate that. The restaurant was a hot mess and the food was nothing special. We had gotten Crispy Pork Chop with Pepper Salt and pork dumplings. Which were good, but nothing to rave about. Not to mention the location, on Pell, a dumpy back alley street that stank. Will not be coming back.

The Xiao Long Baos here set the standard. Â I've had this dish at many restaurants, but I keep coming back. Â My fiance and I split an order of their famous steamed buns and scallion pancake as a mid-afternoon snack. Â It set us back $10 (including tip), but I was a bit annoyed with the fact that they tacked on the 15% tip to our bill.

Well we came here just for soup dumplings. And it was good. We got the pork soup dumplings and it was good, but not great. In addition, the place was PACKED, we were crammed like sardines...but at least the waiting time was within 5 minutes. Like typical Asian establishments, we were shown a table with people already eating. Classic.
No comment

Came in with some kitchen co-workers...Ordered the Pork Soup Dumprings, Braised Pork Shoulder, Noodles, Crispy Pepper Duck, Fried Squab...Etc, etc...We pretty much ordered alot of shit...Had the itis as a result...Anyways, the Dumprings were out of this world and the Braised Pork Shoulder was off the hook...You get a lot of bang for your buck at this place...Our check for a 4-top was 80 bucks and we ordered enough crap to feed an army...Fatty, Rich, Disgusting Goodness at this place...
No comment

Good food and good prices. Crispy beef tasty. Black mushrooms and bamboo shoots would have been nicer if sliced bite-sized. All-round acceptable. Would recommend esp for small groups watching their spending money.

I only come here for the soup dumplings. They are a good deal and are one of the best things i've ever eaten. However, my family only orders takeout now. The restaurant is very busy with tourists and the wait can be up to over an hour. Other then my favorite dumplings, the rest of the food is okay. The restaurant seems kind of dirty and the chairs are the old metal kind last time i went inside. Also, i don't really like sharing a table with a group of tourists that are looking at me the entire time. Last, the bathrooms are something i do NOT want to venture to. I recommend ordering takeout to same time and cleanliness.

I LOVE LOVE the soup dumplings here! Â The Shanghai fried noodles and the grilled/sauteed bok choy and green beans are delicious. Â The portions are large so don't go crazy ordering a ton of food unless you are with a large group. Â This place is popular so be prepared to wait for a table.

I prefer smaller soup dumplings... things were ginormous. Still tasty. Also ordered the shanghai noodles, which were good. The fried quail appetizer was bland. Was seated at a table with another tourist, which turned out to be good conversation. Fast, no-nonsense service.
No comment
No comment

You wait in line a while to get in this place. The primo is their steamed dumplings, which are excellent and stack up against the best I had in China. Â The grilled green beans were also excellent. Â The noodles were meh. Â Service is great and people really seem to be having a good time there.

Pork soup dumplings were GREAT! Service was excellent, and the pan fried seafood noodles were also delicious. Braised duck was juicy and the fell off the bone. I would def return. Also, go early so u don't have to wait outside like a schmuck for 75 mins lol

More like 3.5. The hot and sour soup was good. The shanghai noodles was also good. However the XLBs were ehhh. We ordered the pork and the crab. At first taste it was good but the thick skin over powers the meat and soup inside. When it sat on the table for a bit the skin got hard and certain parts became inedible. My heart still belongs to Din Tai Fung for XLBs.

One of my stops during my NYC trip. Everyone raves about Joe's Shanghai so I had to give it a try. It's so busy here you have to share tables and it's cash only! As soon as you sit down they ask if you want to order dumplings. Well, i guess if you push one product I can see how you'd become known for it. Honestly, it was tasty but no different than the ones I've had here in San Francisco. I guess then it would make it average. I also ordered the shanghai noodles, also no different than SF. Sad to say, it wasn't a let down but probably not worth a stop when I visit NYC since I can get the equivalent back home, without having to share tables.

all I have to say, is go with 3 people and just order this. Â An order of soup dumplings, some rice, some fried green beans, and the CRISPY BEEF. Â While this isn't the most relaxing place in the world and you do have to go early, cuz there is always a line, it is totally worth it. Â It was my first time going there, and I have had a lot of good asian food, but this crispy beef thing is something I think about when I am not there. Â We all agreed that this flavor is the exact flavor we are always looking for when getting Chinese food. Â Slightly sweet, a little sticky, and oh so good. I need to come here again but would only order the exact same thing because we so hit it out of the park!
Since my last review when I moved out of NYC, I probably went there another 10 times; pretty much everytime I go to NYC... This is THE BEST, period.
The cold sesame noodles are delicious! But the "C" on the storefront leaves me thinking...I hope it was cold sesame noodles I ate...

I'm giving it 3 stars just because i feel that people hyped up the soup dumpling so much for me, and we waited about an hour to be seated, and I thought it was ok. Â It was good, don't get me wrong, but I just don't think soup dumplings are my thing. Â The Â other dishes we got were good. Â Glad I crossed it off my list of places to go, but i think i would only go back if I had friends who really want to try it out.
soup dumplings are good especially for the price but they're just decent with no huge wow factor. definitely a solid choice if you want something cheap and filling though (also great for groups)

Amazing dumplings! Tried the crispy beef and beef and broccoli dishes. Not to happy of the wait and the restaurant is a bit small. But... My go to place for the best Dumplings I have ever had! Highly recommend!

What I like - The food, quick service, price, and the oranges after the meal. What I don't like - The stink of that whole area when you are waiting outside, the rushed service, no rating on the window. I am so torn about this place and only go here (my third time) because my wife and our friends really like it. Chinatown is just really nasty.

Yes the soup dumplings are amazing but that is it! The attention seems to be on raising prices which makes it less attractive for a Chinatown location. Sorry last time as a local visiting this tourist trap!

This place was pretty underwhelming considering how much hype there is when you look at the yelp reviews. Far from being the best XLB. Dumplings are a little bit over sizes, the flour skin is also too thick. Definitely worth a try. It's cheap and I would definitely go back but it's nothing to rave about.
i'm a fan of their soup dumplings, quick service and moderate prices. Â the dining area is frugal. Â don't expect fine dining. Â its cash only and they include gratuity on the check.

I really like this place. The soup dumplings, scallion pancake and cold sesame noodles were all absolutely delicious. Icy Tsingtao beer is the perfect accompaniment. Servers are great, and the price is right.

This was a one time fun experience. It was a family style dining, they sit you in a big round table with others (must have not read that anywhere), but I thought it was fun and different. The food wasn't bad it was okay, we both had kung pao chicken. Noodles werent very good though.
came for the soup dumplins. we did a take out order, so they suffered a little, not a lot of soup bu they come with the authentic black vinegar

Perfectly good Chinese food...pork soup dumplings were quite satisfying...the smoked fish was good too. Â I've been here twice for lunch and would go back. Â Cash only. Yes, it's crowded, with tourists...and the staff is not very pleasant.
Decent soup dumpling, not as good as it used to be. Packed with tourist. Cash only. Long lines. Plenty of waiters and waitress standing around.
No comment
If I lived in NY, I would go to Joe's tomorrow. Â These are the best dumplings in town. Â We live in San Francisco now and have yet to find any here that compare!
This place is always good for the soup-filled pork dumplings. The long wait for a table and then the community table is less desirable.
No comment
Soup dumplings are tasty, but the rest of the fare is nothing special.

The dumplings are really good but the prices shot up a little since I last visited. Usually really crowded and you have to wait to get in but pretty much worth it when you have the munchies. The wait staff is a little rude and tend to rush you. I tried their place in Mid town but I didn't like it that much. It was even more expensive and the place smelled.

Wow, simply one of the best soup dumplings in manhattan, among many other strong dishes. They get you in and out fast, so don't expect a place to sit and relax, but the quality and depth of flavor here is worth it. Speaking of price, extremely reasonable! You'll get more food then you expect so don't over order... although I am a shameless doggy bagger.

Quite tasty soup dumplings. Â Though, "soup dumplings" are nothing new and part of Chinese cooking. Â These dumplings would be crushed in Hong Kong.

The soup Â dumpling where was the best I ever had. The skin held together and yet thin when picked up so you don't waste a drop of the soup inside. The soup and meat was prefect, moist and juicy. The service although quite fast was unfriendly. Through out the whole meal we only hear 3 sentences. How many people? You want soup dumplings? How many orders?

What is all the hype? Yes greasy broth can be tasty, but overall quality of the soup dumplings are edible, but forgettable. Â The Lo Mien noodles were ok but I've definitely had better as well. Â I'll stick with the oh so much healthier and tastier Korean style steamed dumplings or dumpling soup. Â Oh and cash only if you didn't know.
Can't get enough of their soup dumplings!!!! Â Dinner gets packed...the wait is crazy so i tend to go to the midtown or flushing location. Â The flushing location also gets busy.

Forgot to review this when I went to NYC for vacation. But, for record keeping sake, come here to eat the XLB! Great prices and it's one of the juiciest XLB I've eaten! (Disclaimer: I have not been to Shanghai; just comparing SF XLB to NYC/Joe's) Stick to the traditional XLB. I recalled the scallop one not being as tasty.

Despite the downsides (shared tables, chinatown type service, being a little touristy), I still give this place 5 stars for the food which happens to be AWESOME. Â loved the crab dumplings, which i expected to love. Â also loved the pan-fried noodles, which I only expected to like.
Soupy soup dumplings, cheap and made to order, quick service, just stay away from the Joe's in midtown. Â I dare say this is better than the West Coast Ding Tai Fung.
