I loved the crab steamed buns here! The food is better than the flushing location. The vegetarian duck appetizer is also my regular side.

BEST SOUP DUMPLINGS I'VE HAD IN THE UNITED STATES! Their soup dumplings are pretty big. Nothing you can eat in one bite easily. Usually when I go somewhere and order soup dumplings the amount of soup in the dumplings is lacking, but that was not the case with the soup dumplings at joe shanghai. It gets pretty cramped in the restaurant however, and you most likely will have to share a table with other parties. The first time I went, I accidentally went to Joe Shanghai's sister restaurant. I can't remember the name, but I know it was Joe something. They serve the same soup dumplings and it's much more roomier and a nicer atmosphere.

There was a line at 2pm, but we decided to wait anyways because it took us forever to find the place and we've read so many good reviews. The hostess is rude, she threw our menu on the table, but I can understand because the place is packed with lines out the door. We ordered the Crab Meat with Pork Meat Steamed Bun (really juicy and tasty), Sliced Braised Beef Noodle Soup (a good warm soup with fresh noodles), and Shanghai Fried Flat Noodle (my ultimate go-to item). I really enjoyed the food, but don't expect a great atmosphere. They were watching our every bite to see when we would be done to get us out. Again, I can understand, it's just really crowded! Also, they don't use a lot of MSG as other Chinese restaurants, which was a big plus for me, and the food tasted very fresh.

came several minutes before it open to avoid the crowds. Â Let me tell you, the crab soup dumplings were awesome. Â Pours some vinegar and hot sauce and you are all set. Â This is by far the best thing i ever ate in my new york city trip!

Absolutely love this place. My favorite place to get shanghai buns is from Joe's shanghai! It is so delicious, once you've tried it, you'll be looking forward to the next time you'll be able to get your hands on some more. If you've never tried it, better get it to it then! My favorite way to enjoy my shanghai buns is to open up a small hole on top and drizzle a little bit of the sauce they give then when it's at the perfect temperature, stuff the whole thing in my mouth, doing it like this, you have the juices pouring out to keep the bun moist as you chew. *drool*
No comment

Delish! I went here last night with a group of friends. We ordered a lot of pork soup dumplings and some other dishes. Each order was piping hot, Â soupy, and filled with meat. They are priced well and really are so great. I've heard some say that this venue has better soup dumplings than some places in China. I've been down the street to Joe's ginger as well. While I prefer Joe's ginger's atmosphere a bit more than Shanghai's, this place still gets 5 stars. Definitely recommend it.
Long wait and always a crowd. Decent steam dumplings but I've had better. Cheap food but they force a 18% tip. Weird for Chinatown in my mind.
2 Words. SOUP DUMPLINGS. I have never had anything of this sort and now I'm on the hunt to find a place that makes these magical balls of flavor if it even exist!! Must have in NYC!!

To start, I enjoyed fabulous scallion cakes.... Â light, airy, wonderful. Â I then ordered the famous soup dumplings. Â I couldn't decide which to try, so I ordered both- the pork & crab and the pork. Â The waiter could see I had never eaten a soup dumpling, so he kindly offered a couple tips- Â poke a hole, "slurp" the broth and then add a small amount of the sauce they provide with the dumplings. Â What a lovely dining experience. Â They weren't too heavy and were packed with flavor. Â I'm so glad I took the advice of several dear friends to try Joe's Shanghai. Â Now go, enjoy it yourself!

I don't really go out for Chinese food very often, but if and when I do, it's for xiao long bao (soup dumplings) at Joe's Shanghai. Try to go during off/weird hours because you'll have to wait in a super long line to get seated at a random round table full of strangers. Slurp away!
No comment

Shanghai dumplings is what this place is all about. We had an order each per person. The first three was very good and then it went downhill. The dumplings were either broke when I picked it up (was very careful) or there was barely any juice inside. If all were made nicely, I would've given 4 stars.
No comment

We wanted to try soup dumplings and heard great things about Joe's. Â Upon arrival, i was a bit turned of by the service and the unpleasant server. Â However, the food definitely made up for everything. Â We ordered the crispy duck and beef, soup dumplings and noodles. Â Everything was heaven in your mouth. Â I would have given it 5 stars but the service is horrible. Â We had asked our server what he recommended and he looked at us with annoyance and was very unhelpful. Â :(

Very good and authentic chinese food. They are best known for your xiao long bao's. I usually get both the pork and crab kind...both equally good! I also think the kong xin cai here is really good...better than kong xin cai elsewhere. get it cooked with garlic. scallion pancakes are also not bad. everything else is pretty standard.
No comment

For what it costs, the food is great. However, I've had better Chinese food and steamed pork dumplings elsewhere. If you've had the dumplings at Din Tai Fung in Southern California, then Joe's Shangai doesn't even compare.

Joe's Shanghai was nothing out of the ordinary Northern-style Chinese cuisine. To be frank, it was actually sub-par compared to the other restaurants of the same type of cuisine. The service was fast. If you have a small party then you'll most likely have to share the table with others. The food was greasy even compared to other Chinese restaurants. The dumplings aren't as hyped up to be. They don't make any dumplings without pork! You could definitely find the same exact food down the street for a lower price. Wasn't anything out of the ordinary. If you are really craving Northern-style Chinese food then you'll do much better at a Chinese-Islamic style restaurant. Where they have better quality meat, larger portions and cheaper prices. There are plenty of those sprinkled all over the 5 boroughs.
No comment
Steamed soup dumplings were superb! Very authentic. Snow pea leaves and fish in wine sauce were great too. Reminded me of home :)
Shanghai dumplings..mmmmm 2nd time here since my last visit to NYC.

We typically try to get to Chinatown when we're in NYC. This was rated high by Yelp so selected this one for a try. Â It measures up well with our local favorite Chinese cuisine (see my Char Koon review), some in family said no, but others thought it was close. Â To be fair, more visits are needed for comparison. Â The Soup Dumplings are unique to this place, and worth it just to try those. Â They were very good, but you may hear so much about them beforehand, your expectations may get too high. Â Expect to wait at peak meal times, we waited about 30 minutes for a party of 6. Â They work hard to keep things moving. Â Our service was very good and prices were reasonable, good for NYC.

The food really does live up to the fame. However, the service is always the downfall. They pack the restaurant where it is simply uncomfortable to sit. There is no room and I always fear things being spilled on me. The worst experience was when I was with a group of friends, and the waiter kept leaning on my friend's chair when he was waiting around. When we finished our meal and he was bringing out the oranges, he spilled juice down my friend's back. If you want good Shanghai food, this is the place to go, but be warned that it is extremely crowded, noisy, and the service may be lousy. For me, I prefer going down the block to Joe's Ginger. Relatively the same without the cramped space.

Everyone comes for the Soup dumpling (xiao lung bao). The ones with crab are amazing. An overlooked dish is the braised pork shoulder and the stir-fried Shanghai Rice Cakes. Â I love coming here from time to time to get my fix.

I came in during the late afternoon on a weekday and didn't have to wait. Their menu is pretty extensive and I felt rushed to make my order. It was my first time and I didn't even know where the dumplings were on the menu. I found it once I asked. I placed an order for the crab and the pork. Very good and flavorful (I liked the crab more). They were also pretty big.. I over-committed by ordering 3 more small dishes (the scallion pancakes, pot sticker, and jellyfish) between two people. All the food were good and cheap too.

Amazing soup dumplings! When I first came here, I didn't realize what they were (my Canto friend ordered), so I took a big bite and carelessly sprayed scorching broth everywhere. After that lesson was learned, I was able to enjoy these dumplings with a lot more caution. The best way I found to eat them is to take a teeny bite out of the skin, dump the broth into the spoon they give you, sip the broth, and eat the rest of the dumpling. Like many restaurants in Chinatown, they give you free tea too!

I know a lot of people are tired of this restaurant because they think it's too touristy and not worth the wait but I LOVE IT HERE. Their pork soup dumplings are amazing and I can eat them everyday. The crab ones are okay but I'm not that huge of a fan. Their scallion pancakes are really good too. Thick and chewy. I also like their beef with scallions. Oooh and their seafood dishes are really good -- especially the one on the 'Special Menu' page... orange shrimp I think it's called. Also note that their noodles are below par.

Hai okay-la. I grew up eating soup dumplings in Taipei and SoCal so I am never thoroughly impressed with Joe's. But when I have a craving, it is adequate. For me, it's not worth the wait. You should just go to Joe's Ginger a couple of doors down.
Soup dumplings were melt in your mouth savory. Â Thick beef broth flavor is probably its selling point. Â Delicious, but I'm a dumpling lover.

We really wanted to try this! Went all the way down only to find it has a C rating? To get a B is hard to do, so to have a C it must be filthy. What a huge disappointment after coming all that way. Diners beware

Most amazing Crab XLB. Of. My. Life. I've had them at Nanxiang in Shanghai, Din Tai Fung in HK and SoCal, and everywhere in between, but these were completely life-changing. When you first try them, you might notice that the broth is much thicker than you might expect. I must admit, it took me an entire day's time to actually evaluate if I enjoyed them since the taste is so different (or innovative). I recommend loading up on the vinegar, since it helps cancel out some of the greasiness when you inevitably stuff your face.

I was disappointed at the Xiao Long Baos.. It wasn't what I expected. I've definitely had better. I also ordered the Shanghai noodle and I think that was even better than the dumplings. I had saw the reviews and since it was our first time in NY, we went all the way to Chinatown from Times Square to try it. Definitely was not worth it.
Good dumplings, nice braised pork shoulder. Â Service was fine. Â Cash only.
Best dumplings, beer and customer service sucks though. Â This rating is for the Chinatown location.

I finally decided to give this place a chance after constantly hearing my friends brag about it. I went here with my boyfriend on a casual Wednesday afternoon. We were seated immediately in a large family style table. We started our meal with pork soup dumplings and lets just say they were beyond delicious! My boyfriend and I wanted to order more dumplings because they were just that good! He had an eel salad and I had general tso chicken, I was extremely happy with my meal and so was he. The bill was around $54 and it was worth every bit. The only downside to this place was that they only accept cash and gratuity is already included. Do yourself a favor and check this place out!
The chicken w/ steamed veggies was horrible. Â The soup dumplings were just ok.
Good old school food. Cash Only is an issue for me anymore or would have rated higher

Wednesday night at around 8:30pm and the line are still long with about 30 people waiting to enter the restaurant. No reservations waited about 30 minutes and most tables are communion and shared with others. Only cash. It is all worth it. Known for their soup dumplings, 8 in 1 serving, we had the pork, and crab fillings. They are served very hot and you need to wait before diving into them. We continued with the chicken orange and the Shanghai Fried Flat Noodles. Inexpensive and good.
No comment

I have been coming here for years and feel that the quality of the soup dumplings is the same (AMAZING). Yes, there are a lot of tourists but the food is consistently fantastic. In addition to the soup dumplings, I especially like the Sezchuan style green beans. It is chaotic in this restaurant but that's all part of the fun!
Fantastic dumplings. Service was fast and hostess was rude. However the food makes up for it.

I live in a nearby neighborhood so like I like to walk to Chinatown. Â All,that is to say I am no stranger to Chinatown. Â I have enjoyed Joe's Shanghai in the past so I was happy to go for an early dinner with the hubby. Â Sadly, like many places that become popular JS Â has taken a bad turn. Â We ordered crab soup dumplings ( cause you always order soup dumplings here). Â They were just okay. Â We also,order cold noodles with sesame sauce, which was awful. Â The noodles were over cooked and the sauce was too thick with unmixed globs of s

With over 3K reviews, I'm pretty sure they don't need my 5stars but this place is my favorite place in the city. Anytime I have visitors, I bring them here for soup dumplings. We've tried other things like: pan friend noodles, bakchoy, general tsos, scallion pancakes, lo mein, fried rice, and many other dishes. I've been extremely happy with everything I've eaten there. LOVE me some Joe's!

the foods are good..but always pack with customers which create problem for getting seat! the waitress is extreamly easy to forget your ticket # and skip you! the worst part is THEY DON'T CARE! so...take it or leave it...
Expect a wait. But... thats what happens when you are about to indulge in some of the best soup dumplings I've ever had.
Soup Dumplings were great but regular menu items are hit or miss. If you do order something other than dumplings, the fish belly is really good.

The food is mediocre. SERVICE IS HORRIBLE. When I arrived, there were about 30 people waiting outside so I thought I'd be in for a treat if that many people were willing to wait. After being finally seated an hour later, I was eager to taste their famous soup dumplings, given all the great reviews. The soup dumplings were good, but I've had better and I was expecting amazing. As for their wonton soup... My homemade version beats theirs by miles. Decent prices and ok food but definitely not worth the hype. I guess they have a big ego because they treat customers like numbers rather than people. People arriving after me, were seated before me. Even those people apologized to me. I will definitely not be returning. Despite poor service I might have returned if the food lived up to the hype of the plethora of newspaper clippings on their front windows. Obviously, it didn't.
This place is disgusting! I don't understand how they got a 4 star! Don't come here.....

The soup dumplings are so amazing here. Â It's the perfect cure for a hangover. Â Do not come here during peak hours as you will end up waiting (most likely outside). Â But if you come here on the slightly off hours, you'll get a seat right away. Â I will keep coming back for the soup dumplings!

Not worth the wait and hype. Soup dumplings are fine but you get more of the same almost anywhere else (or better) with better environment, service attitude - waiting to eat here on a weekend night is like standing in line at Boba Guys on opening night for 3 hours: not worth.
No comment

We went because of the high number of reviews but failed to see whats so great about it. They will make you share the table with a random party to fit in more customers. Food was strictly ok. We had ordered crab dumplings and kung pao chicken. There are definitely better chinese food places out there.

Certainly agree on what everyone says about this place - the best soup dumplings in town. I could go all the way to Chinatown only to eat some soup dumplings here. So good. I've tried the sesame chicken the other day, it was also really yum. Normally there's a line.

I had lunch here when I was in Manhattan for a visit. My friends brought me here and we had dumplings. I thought the dumplings were very good and fresh. Â The same quality you get in San Francisco Chinatown, but I prefer the Bay Area Chinese food, overall. The onion bread was very good too. Similar to how my mom's makes it, but of course not as good as mom's. Â I could tell this place is a local favorite. I saw a few white collar workers were having lunch here and they seem to really enjoy it.
No comment

Good soup dumplings, a bit of a wait at times, not as cheap as some of the other options in Chinatown, but a nice place. Â Friendly service, efficient, good number of dishes - a lot of good spicy food. Â Not very big on the communal dining aspect though.
I am salivating just thinking about Joe's soup dumplings. A required stop every time I'm in NYC.

Meh. Â Nothing special. Â The soup dumplings were thick and chewy and very awkward to eat. Â The ratio of meat to broth was off (too heavy on the meat in my opinion). Â I like a smaller soup dumpling (like Yank Sing in SF). Â Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings don't even come close to the deliciousness and perfection of their Yank Sing brethren. Â Oh and to top it off the last dumpling that my husband bit into was garnished with a loooong black hair. Â I'm a blonde. Â Check please!
No comment

Thought the meat dumplings filled with spoon size soup were delicious and will revisit soon. Only wish, I had known about the restaurant's unusual practice of including 15% tip on the bill- Won't double tip next time, thanks to yelpers.

Pork soup dumplings!!!! This is one of those places you bring someone who is visiting you in NYC. It is delicious! Â Also good is the crispy beef. There is sometimes a wait, but you can always walk around Chinatown. It is cash only and gratuity is included. Not a place to bring a girl on a date. This place is a must try. First thing you need to say when you sit down....pork soup dumplings!!! Be careful they are fragile. Here is my soup dumpling strategy. Carefully put it on your spoon. Bite off top. Slurp out soup. Then insert in mouth. Enjoy!
Above average Chinese food and I'm super picky. Good prices!
No comment
Great Chinese and excellent dumplings. The vege dishes are very fresh. We loved the shrimp and chicken w plum sauce. Been going for 10 yrs and it's always an experience.
No comment

We had a hard time finding this place, which was recommended by friends of ours. People come here for the food and the famous dumplings. Otherwise, there's not much to appreciate. Service can be sporadic, prices are Disneyland-like, and seating is uncomfortable. If you're not in a large group, you will most likely be seated with other parties around a large circular table. It's not all that weird because many Chinese restaurants do this, but I don't like hearing other peoples' conversations.

Everyone always raves about this place, so I just had to try it out. It was pretty empty when I went there, perhaps it was too early to really be dinner time. I tried the regular soup dumplings and I wasn't that impressed. Perhaps I eat frozen ones too much? I didn't really like it all that much and I feel like this place is pretty much over-hyped.
It's the crab meat that makes these soup dumplings good especially since the classic place to go in Shanghai also does the same.

Great deal for amazing soup dumplings! Â (I recommend the pork over the seafood dumplings.) Â Inexpensive, good place, especially for groups of 5-8 people. Â Share the dumplings, drink some hot tea, leave happy. Â Great service. Â On busy nights be prepared to wait outside in a line. Â It's worth it. Â I don't think they take cards, but there is an ATM nearby.
No comment
Great xiao long bao! i thought Shanghai's dumplings were excellent but Joe's topped it! worth the 15 minute wait to get a table! i highly recommend this place for soup dumplings!

This place is known for soup dumplings, and they're okay, but not stellar. I prefer Shanghai Asian Cuisine on Elizabeth Street, a couple of blocks away. As I'm from the neighborhood, I am fairly familiar with the restaurants, but out-of-town friends have heard rave reviews and must stop by, regardless of the wait and sharing of a table. Well, we came on a Monday afternoon and didn't have to wait for a table, but we waited 35 minutes for the soup dumplings. We kept asking the waiter where they were, and he told us it was crowded - no, it was not. Finally, we told them to cancel the second order of dumplings. After having noodles and scallion pancakes we were already stuffed. I had the Shanghai noodle soup - it was savory, if not a bit salty.
Xiao long bao here is great. Â Would recommend Shanghai cafe over Joe's but this is still good stuff.
Was worth fighting the Chinese new years crowd to get their food. Dumplings, chicken fried rice, and fried beef were great.

Shanghai buns. Pork or crab, you ask? Â I usually get pork, just cause I personally think they're better. Â But don't knock the crab. Â If that's all you're gonna get, it's one order per person and you're happy. Â The pan-friend noodles also rule. Â Just because it's a tourist spot doesn't mean that locals don't eat there either. Â You're gonna love it.

The best authentic Chinese food I've had since I got back from China. It was unfortunate at the time I was not eating meat for lent, so I was not able to partake in the dumplings, but you can just tell they were amazing. According to everyone, including my Chinese friend, said it was the best that they had. I had the breaded yellowtail and it was RIDICULOUS. Super flavorful, with just the right amount of lemon. The entire experience is exactly how a restaurant experience in China is - rushed and forceful, but that's apart of the culture. Be prepared to wait for awhile for a table. I went to the restaurant across the way to enjoy a beer, and get out of the cold. :)

As everyone else have raved the Soup Dumplings are DELISH. Â My favorite are the pork dumplings. Â My fiance and I came here and got 2 steamers of the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. Â They are a bit greasier than other xiao long bao places I've been, but great flavor! Â  I haven't been to Joe's other locations, but I like how the Chinatown location retains the "get in get out" charm of most busy dim sum establishments. Â We were only a party of 2, so were sat at a big table with 2 other parties. Â We don't mind as we expect to be seated with others when it's just the 2 of us. Â For $20 we stuffed ourselves and tummies were very happy. Â Cash only!
No comment
This is just great...it's so addictive, I'm already missing this pork soup dumping!
Good baozi. I went there once, only for its baozi. Credit card not accepted.

As perfect as a restaurant gets. Â Dumplings were amazing. Â Eggplant incredible. Â Best green beans EVER! Â We ordered stuff we didn't even know what it was, but it was all great. Â The staff isn't exceptionally helpful, but take their suggestions and be daring. Â Everything was good and sooooo cheap!

Been here three times and it definitely hits the spot. Â Not anything fancy and you will most likely have to share a table with strangers, but it's good stuff. Â Get the dumplings, they are piping hot and delish. Â Had the orange chicken or beef, can't remember which, but it was goooooood. Â We order a ton of food when we go and finish everything. Â And sometimes, order seconds of the fried rice!

I came for the dumplings and like most reviewers was happily satisfied. As others have said Â -be prepared to be seated with other diners. We had a group of six and still ended up sharing a table - which just adds to the whole experience. I think this place is definitely worth a stop in Chinatown!
No comment
This Joe's is not as good as the one in Flushing. This one is bit greasier and definitely more cramped. Still good food but not as good as the original. Very greasy rice cakes and scallion pancakes

We tried both pork and crab xiao long bao, which were both tasty. Â I don't really mind the hall-in-the-wall atmosphere of Asian restaurants as long as they deliver the taste. Â But if you're looking for ambience, this is not it. Â We'll return here for sure for more xiao long bao!
This place is packed with Good Chinese Food! The Soup Dumplings are to die for!We'll defly go back to this Place!I just dont like the idea of sharing table with other People.Otherwise its A okei.

I had the (crab) soup dumplings, absolutely delicious! Â And cheap! Â I'd eat this everyday if I could. Â I don't care much for the vinegar sauce.

I love soup dumplings and joes got some decent dumplings. But to wait for a table and to deal with the staffs that thinks their better than their job, I'll pass. So many places in Chinatown to get decent dumplings, I'll have to pass.
Soup dumplings!! Joe makes the best in the city. Whenever I have a craving I have to order from here. They are always perfect. Get the pork stuffed, divine!!
Best soup dumplings ever! Â Although I've tried a few of their dishes, which are tasty...I only go there for the soup dumplings.

This is the best Chinese food in NYC. Hands down. I have been coming here for my entire life. The steamed buns are an absolute must, and the jelly fish is amazing. Go out on a limb and try it. Don't bother with ordering American Chinese food, because this is a legit establishment and they will probably laugh at you. I have heard the soft shell crabs are great and I will be trying them in a few minutes. Seriously it is worth the wait, as hesitant as I am to write this review and make the wait longer for myself. Enjoy!

OK so Joe's does not have the best soupy dumplings in a four block radius. BUT it still has great soup dumplings AND, moreover, it has a great environment. I ordered pork tiny buns. The broth was pretty flavorful, though not as flavorful as other places I've been, and the skin was a bit too thick. I did have a really wonderful noodle soup though and a really entertaining conversation with a table of women who all happened to originally be from the same part of LA as I am. If you are a little bit bored on a weeknight and definitely hungry, I recommend going to Shanghai Joe's.

This place doesn't need my review, but I am going to write one anyway. Â I LOVE this place!!! Â The soup dumplings are to DIE for. Â Seriously, they are magical, but don't burn yourself. Â I have never had anything here I didn't like. Â Don't miss the deep fried whole sea bass, it is ridic good!!! Â Plus, added bonus, they are open super late at night for those much needed 2nd dinners..... ;)
Average quality food, no lunch menu visible. $14 for lemon chicken and white steamed rice - not a one $ price by any means, more like $$. Try other $$ places instead that are nicer inside

Crab meat dumplings and scallion pancakes are my top choices in this restaurant. Been here plenty of time, those 2 items were a must order every time I go here. Awesome food. Crowded atmosphere. If you are a party of 4 or less, the chances of you having to share tables is very high. If you don't mind that, then this place is a must visit!

SOUP DUMPLINGS! I'm not particularly a fan of sharing tables with complete strangers. I honestly do not think that anything else is really that special and stands out as much as what it's known for, soup dumplings. A must stop if you are visiting in the winter! The wait is pretty long, but it's worth every second!
No comment

Vacationing in NYC with my wife and three kids and wanted some authentic Chinese food without the tourist feel. Â Found this place through Yelp and was thrilled we did. Â Although the restaurant was packed, we got a table for five within 15 minutes. Â The pork dumplings were the best I've had, and more importantly, the entire meal was outstanding. Â Service very good, not great, but it was packed. Â Might return before we leave NYC.

We had dined here numerical times. Every time when I visited New York China Town, this was my must go place. This time I noticed the food was not taste the same and the quality of the ingredients were not good. The fried rice was liked just mixing the meat with the steam rice. The rice noodle dishes tasted disgusting. What a disappointment. It's a shame to see one of my favorite place going downhill. This is a cash only place, be aware of what you ordered !!!
Great dumplings and fast service. Â Always Â a short wait, but worth the wait. Â A bit pricey for flushing, cash only Â and kid friendly

My boyfriend and I were dying to try dim sum in Chinatown and looked up a place on...Yelp...and found Joe's Shanghai. It was beyond our expectations! We got the pork dumpings, curry scallops, and beef with scallions. The pork dumplings were AMAZING!! Best meal I had in New York and since it was the first time I had something like this, I was happy to have it in Chinatown. Service was ok but I expected it to be fast and to the point. Since it was communal sitting, we ended up sitting next to a couple from Dallas and it was their first time in NY. They ordered what we ordered and we had a nice time getting to know new people. Great experience and wonderful food! Totally 4 star worthy.
My first time having soup dumplings and they were very good.

The soup dumplings were pretty good, service quick and attentive, especially for a Chinese restaurant. Â We had some great prawns as well, the were in a red sauce (hot pepper prawns??), sorry I wish I could remember the name but they circle the item number of the popular dishes on the menu with ball point pen, so I think if you go with any of those items you are probably going to be OK.

There was a time when I would come here with my friends in earnest. We'd wait outside for an eternity as the hostess kept promising everyone that their table would be ready soon. After an hour, sometimes two, we'd go in and see who could eat the most dumplings. I usually got to two baskets before keeling over and dieing. The soup dumplings are still good, but no longer the best in the city. They're definitely not worth the long waits. The rest of the menu is surprisingly good as well. I love scallion pancakes and they do a great one. All of the usual Americanized stuff is there and executed much better than expected. And it's still pretty cheap.
Soup dumplings were on point! Really fresh and delicious! The rest of the food was average. It's mighty packed and you'll have to make up your mind quick or wait a bit.

Food was great as usual. The major issue was I saw one of the service staff leaving the bathroom immediately after flushing and there is no way he washed his hands. The sink and air dryer are very noisy and it would take at least 5 seconds to complete that process. Gross!
I like the place and the surroundings near to this I just loved it. Basically this place is known for their Xiao Longs Bao. Â Will surely visit soon again.

I don't normally write reviews but I felt compelled to because I came to Joe's Shangahi with a friend based on a recommendation and also reading Yelp reviews. First let me preface by saying I'm from Singapore and have eaten at some really darn good Xiao long bao restaurants in Singapore and Taiwan. The friend I was with had also lived in Singapore and Taiwan before though she's not Chinese. We ordered the regular pork XLB and the crab meat and pork XLB, plus the scallion pancakes and crispy pork based on Yelp reviews. I have one word - NO. To anyone expecting anything resembling Din Tai Fung XLB, you couldn't be further from this. Even though the skin was thicker than it should be and a lot of it, every single XLB tore off the lettuce leaf, but at least that gave us a chance to see the fat scum in the broth that came out of it. What we could salvage of the broth tasted blah. The scallion pancake was thick, deep fried and soaked in oil. The crispy shredded beef was really mediocre. Needless to say we didn't finish anything even though we had arrived with a XLB craving. The next day I went to another Shanghai Asian Manor for round two, I was hesitant from the previous experience but it was waaaayyy better - definitely go there instead!
Dope as fuck, get racks on racks on racks of soup dumplings and then leave. Theres no need for an entree. The crab one sometimes tastes kind of fishy, so get the normal one to be safe.
quite frankly, this place has been overrated by many, and i don't know how it started but the dumplings are not bad at all. Â although my favorite is still at a hole in a wall places nearby...

I go here every chance I get when I'm in NY! I missed xiao long bao so much from my time living in China, & this was a godsend. They only have 2 types, pork & pork w/ crab. The pork ones are definitely the better of the 2. The scallion pancakes are quite tasty & they offer free Jasmine tea when you sit down. If you're craving your soup dumplings, you can't go wrong!!
No comment
Soup Dumpling was definitely worth it but what is underrated was the age shredded beef.
No comment
No comment

I came here for dinner with a group of 12 on a recent Monday night. Â The place was PACKED at 8:30 and we had to wait a bit for a table (they don't take reservations). Â Don't come for this place if you're looking for any sort of charming or cute atmosphere, because you will NOT find it. Â They staff is very rushed and abrupt at times. Â Luckily much of the food makes up for all of this, but not enough to earn it more than 2 stars from me. Â Note, there is no bar and the only alcohol served is beer.

Crab Shiao Long Bao and Scallion/Green Onion Pancake are the way to go here.

If you're looking for good Chinese food, then look no further. Â The pork soup dumplings was a different experience for us Californians. Â I made the mistake of stuffing the whole thing in my mouth and burning it. Â But other than that the food was good. Â My favorite dish there was the clams.. Freaking a was it good!
BEST soup dumplings by far that ive tried!! I love how its big and soupy and CHEAP! Â Way better than din tai fung.
